All Reviews

  1. What in god's name were these a-holes thinking when they designed this product??? Yes, the toothbrush itself is very effective and the travel case with the built in charger is totally clutch.....but the charging / storage system for use with the toothbrush in the bathroom is COMPLETELY WACK. Let me break it down for you.<br /><br />You have a tall, fairly heavy toothbrush. Then, you have a silver, plastic base. On top of that base sits a squat little GLASS CUP. The glass cup DOES NOT attach to the base. It just rests on top of it. In order to get a charge up through the plastic base and into the toothbrush, you have to put the toothbrush in the short little cup. The toothbrush is several inches taller than the cup, making the whole thing wobbly and top heavy. And, remember, the glass isn't attached to the base. So, one day let's say you brush up against your toothbrush while going about your business, and that toothbrush happens to be sticking three or four inches out of the glass cup. Well, that top heavy mother f-er is going to tip over, taking the much shorter glass cup with it because, as you recall, THE GLASS DOESN'T ATTACH TO THE PLASTIC BASE. And then, wouldn't you know, you have shattered glass everywhere and NO MEANS TO CHARGE YOUR TOOTHBRUSH ANY LONGER.<br /><br />This is not only seriously dangerous, but also makes the product pretty frickin' ineffective. It completely boggles the mind why they didn't design this with a plastic cup or a cup that attaches to the base - or literally ANYTHING sturdier and less likely to SHATTER ALL OVER YOUR FLOOR. If you have children or pets or people who like to move their arms around in a bathroom, this is NOT the product for you. And if you do take your chances and buy this thing and then almost certainly wind up with a shattered charging cup like me and many others, then be prepared to call the awesome folks at Sonicare to try and buy a replacement cup, only to be told that the cup is the ONLY componentof this stupid toothbrush set that you can't buy replacements for AND even if they do find a replacement cup for you, it isn't covered by the warranty....even though this is CLEARLY their design issue.<br /><br />Thanks for nothing, Philips Sonicare...
  2. working good the only problem I have when the charge gose doen it vabreate in my hand
  3. it's like you're at the dentist, but the dentist is... YOUR HAND.
  4. After my dentist told me I was literally getting long in the tooth, I decided I need to upgrade my toothbrush to an electric one. It takes a little getting used to, but really is superior to brushing the old way. The brush has several modes, and tells you when to switch quadrants of the mouth, to ensure each area gets proper cleaning time. The vibration feels good on the gums and leaves teeth feeling really clean. The case is slick and can charge with an outlet or usb, very smart. It also comes with a charger stand or a cool little glass you can just put the brush in to charge. Changed my life.
  5. First, I'd like to say I am a skeptic and brand loyalist. I've used Oral-B toothbrushes for over 30 years. My Oral-B electric toothbrush recently showed signs of dying on me, so I started investigating a replacement. I'd seen pamphlets for the Sonicare in several dentist offices and the dentist and staff at my dentist office all used them. I figured maybe they got them free for allowing advertising material to be placed in the office.<br /><br />I checked the Sonicare and when I saw the price, I immediately switched back to looking at Oral-B toothbrushes. Something kept nagging at me, so I returned to the Sonicare and read the reviews. I asked myself if it made financial sense to purchase such an expensive toothbrush. Then I realized that the cost of repeated dental visits and potential of having to wear dentures in the future overshadowed the cost of a good toothbrush. My teeth are not in the best of condition and I have several fillings and crowns.<br /><br />First time users, please take the following under consideration:<br /> 1) DO NOT deactivate the 14 day Easy Start feature. The Sonicare operates and feels totally different than the other toothbrushes. I was tempted to stop using it on the first try even with the East Start feature on. I felt a strong ticklish sensation along the gums...especially behind the teeth. The vibration was also strong. This was not uncomfortable -- just very annoying.<br /> 2) If you think you might have a cavity, start of gum disease, or sensitive teeth, start out by using the sensitive setting. I have sensitive teeth and some crowns, so I was worried about starting out immediately with the clean setting. I noticed some bleeding around a couple of teeth, which was an indication of the start of some gum disease. After three days, the bleeding stopped and hasn't happened since.<br /><br />I was tempted to stop using the Sonicare after the first brushing, but reconsider after the results.<br /> 1) I read reviews from some people who said they felt as if they had just stepped out of the dentist chair. I figured they were full of what it takes to make the grass grow green. Now I'm one of them. Not only did I feel like I'd just stepped out of the dentist office after a cleaning, but the feeling of freshness and cleanliness lasted throughout the day...even after eating and drinking.<br /> 2) I have yet to use the whitening and polishing settings and my teeth already look whiter. I can't wait to see what happens after using these settings.<br /><br />In conclusion, in my opinion, this is the best toothbrush I've ever used. I wished I had it when I was younger and maybe things would be different. I can't wait for my next dental checkup to see how well I do.
  6. Just after one usage...my teeth feel cleaner, some of the tartar or tooth film is gone and I am very pleased. I am looking forward to trying all the settings.
  7. Short: Buy a FlexCare or EasyClean instead. You'll save yourself over $100 and have a better tool.<br /><br />To use this toothbrush you must turn it on while it is in your mouth (this is what the picture instructions indicate too) or the toothpaste falls off. To find out which of the programs you've selected, you have to read the little words on the handle that light up. That writing is tiny, it's about four inches from your eyes and it is at an angle; it's very hard to read. I have to guess based on the approximate shape of the blur. Happily the program I use first has two words in it so I can make out the space in the middle; but it's really hard after that to read &#34;White&#34; and distinguish it from the other words.<br /><br />The problem is that there's only one button to do two things: on/off and program select. The FlexCare has two buttons and I loved mine but I wanted the &#34;White&#34; program - which means that after I squint at the lights to brush my teeth I have to squint again to whiten them. I can't even learn how many times to press the button and just count because it depends on how long it is since it stopped *and* the button doesn't always depress properly; so I have to squint at the lights under my nose. When I put it under the faucet to rinse it, I have to press the button five times to turn it on and off. It doesn't take all that long but it's awfully annoying. I suppose that if you use a car that takes two or three or four attempts to start in the morning then this may be the tooth brush for you - although you might prefer to spend the extra $100 on a mechanic.<br /><br />* If you want only one program, buy the (much cheaper) brush with only one program; you can still use the &#34;diamond&#34; heads if you want to.<br />* If you want gum care, buy the FlexCare. It has two buttons and it's half the price.<br />* If you want the whitening program... well, you're stuck with this one.<br /><br />Perhaps a magnifying mirror would help, or you could color in the lights for the program you want so they're easier to distinguish. That'd look nasty, but since the design seems to be all about appearance and not usability, it feels somehow appropriate to deface it in order to make it work. Yes, I'm a bit bitter about it. Very disappointed with the design. If the packaging hadn't been plastered with design awards I'd have given it an extra star but Philips seem to think the design is important so it deserves to be penalized.<br /><br />To be clear on the *function* though: The thing works well as do the others in the Sonicare line-up. This is a review for the DiamondClean version, not the whole Sonicare line. My dental hygienist says that my gums and teeth have improved tremendously over the years I've been using Sonicare brushes and I wouldn't use anything else.p, or you could color in the lights for the program you want so they're easier to distinguish.   31. This is my second Sonicare toothbrush, and I have to say it is a huge step forward- and I loved my first one. Once you have gotten used to using a Sonicare toothbrush your teeth never feel quite as clean from manual brushing, because they aren't. I love how clean my teeth feel after, its honestly like I just got a professional cleaning at the dentist. The new design is sleek and clean; I love the all white look and the lit up settings, real classy. The new charging dock is pretty slick look too.<br /><br />I noticed that some people had issues with the multiple settings on the toothbrush. I'm not sure if they wrote their reviews after only one use, but once you click through to the setting you want, it automatically keeps that setting as the default the next time you use it. For example, the first time I used it I had to click once to turn it on, and then three more times to get to the \\"Gum care\\" setting. After going through the full cycle (3 min) it turns off like it should. The next time I pressed \\"on\\" it started right at the \\"gum care\\" setting, and it has for the few weeks that I've had the toothbrush. I can see how it would be annoying to have to click through 4 times every time you use it, but the guys at Philips are a little smarter than that.<br /><br />On top of how great it makes my teeth feel, it is it also is a great motivator for me to floss more- I'm not sure why, probably because I've made an investment and I want to see the greatest return. 100% Recommend. You will never go back once you've tried it.

  33. I had high hopes for this toothbrush after reading all of the reviews and seeing photographs of it. I loved the sleek, minimal look of the entire kit and decided to order one, despite the expensive price tag. Upon unboxing, I was really impressed with the included accessories (especially the charging travel case, wow!). The compact charging stand (if you didn't want to use the larger glass cup) was a bit loose fitting on both top and bottom sides, but I decided I was able to live with that. When I opened the travel case to reveal the actual toothbrush, I wasn't nearly as impressed. The material they used (a soft, matte, plastic) just felt cheap to the touch. It is however, much more grippy when wet. As mentioned in some other reviews, the one button toggle system is really not an efficient one. Sometimes it'll turn off the brush, other times it will toggle. I wasn't able to get it to consistently do what I wanted. Then there's the matter of the gap between the brush head and the handle. Again, this has been mentioned before, but unlike ALL of the photographs of the product, there is a 1-2mm gap that (in my opinion), ruins the refined and polished look of the unit as a whole. I understand that it doesn't affect the functionality of the brush, and that space is necessary for the head to vibrate, but the ultrasonic motor could get away with just a hairline with the way that it operates. I just felt that the build quality was just not there. I have used both Sonicare and Braun units in the past, but this one just seems particularly off. I also don't care for the fact that the unit is manufactured in China, unlike the German-made Braun brushes (there is an inherent difference in feel between the two). Overall, it's still a great functioning sonic toothbrush -- I was just expecting a bit more for the price I paid. I'm debating on whether to just downgrade to the model just below this one, as the extra cost doesn't really seem to be worth it.
  34. Unlike the Pro Results Plus toothbrush, it is difficult to switch modes because the toothbrush stays on and you have to keep pressing to go to each mode.
  35. Over the past 10 years or so, I've owned three other electric toothbrushes: two other Sonicare models and one Oral-B. This is my favorite, though it cost twice as much as any other. It might be worth the incredible price difference for these features:<br /><br />- It can be charged via USB (very handy for international travel because the normal Sonicare does not accept 220V).<br />- I like the QuadPacer feature (also available on some other Sonicare models), because it lets me think less while brushing.<br />- The toothbrush is lighter than other Sonicare models (about the same as the Oral-B).<br />- The [[ASIN:B0052JN8QM DiamondClean brush]] material is finer than other Sonicare heads; it feels like it might clean a little better.<br />- The replacement head is smaller than other Sonicare models.<br />- Includes an attractive carrying case.<br />- In my opinion, the unit is more attractive than any other brush I've seen; it just looks good on the bathroom counter.<br /><br />All the modes seem silly. That said, I do use the Gum Care mode because I have bad gums and I figure an extra minute of brushing them can't hurt. And that leads to my biggest gripe about this brush (other than the price): There is no way to switch modes without turning the brush on, and there is no way to turn the brush off without switching modes. To switch from the Normal mode to the Gum Care mode, I have to put toothpaste on the brush, put it in my mouth, and then hit the button 4 times. After brushing, I like to rinse the brush and then run it for a couple seconds to shake off the excess water. With this brush, hitting the button after I'm done rinsing doesn't turn it off; it switches to the next silly mode.

  42. No Complaints!! Really like Sonicare
  43. I began using a power brush about ten years ago. Since then, I've entered and graduated dental hygiene school and come to value power brushes as a great tool for everyone to improve their oral health. Even though it is possible to maintain a healthy mouth with a manual brush, it is more difficult and, for some people, not possible (due to coordination issues, arthritis, etc.). My first ten years of power brushing was with Oral B products (I've owned two of their models). I loved their brushes and felt they kept my teeth perfectly plaque-free and they did not exacerbate some recession I have on one tooth from previous orthodontia.<br /><br />Then I got my DiamondClean while I was in hygiene school and I was a convert. The Sonicare seems much gentler than the Oral B brushes. At first it was a bit ticklish but I realized it was because I was so used to the more jarring sensation of the Oral B. The DiamondClean is aesthetically pleasing and the chargeable travel case is super convenient (and cute!).<br /><br />Let me just break something down for anyone who is trying to decide between this and a comparable Oral B brush: They will both remove plaque if you use them correctly, for the full two minutes twice per day. Nothing will save you if you do not use these things the way they are meant to be used. There are plenty of studies available that support one type of power brush technology versus another, but nothing is clinically significant. That means that neither the Oral B nor the Sonicare is so vastly superior in bacterial plaque biofilm removal that I could recommend one over the other to my patients, based on that criterion alone. If you use the brushes correctly you can keep your mouth perfectly healthy (e.g: Prevent gum disease/periodontal disease if you don't already have it and improve your ability to control periodontitis if you've been diagnosed).<br /><br />A systematic review was conducted by the Cochrane Library and this is the conclusion:<br />&#34;There issome evidence that rotation oscillation brushes reduce plaque and gingivitis more than side to side brushes in the short term. This difference is small and it's clinical importance is unclear. Further trials of good quality are required to assess the superiority of other modes of action for powered toothbrushes.&#34;<br /><br />So, until there is more conclusive evidence, everyone should use the brush that they find most comfortable. My husband prefers the Oral B, FWIT. He just likes the little round brush head and, for whatever reason, likes the more jarring sensation from that brush.
  44. Expensive refills, but worth it! It's the best!
  45. Never thought I would indulge in an electric toothbrush, but I have only been using this since December 7th, and I won't be going back to a manual.....EVER!
  46. Bought this for my husband for Christmas. He said he wants to die with all his teeth. He said it was the best present ever and he is very picky!
  47. This is number 2. The first one failed to charge after 15 months - battery was dead. I angrily invested in a second handset that worked for almost 24 months but gradually (and almost not noticeably) got weaker and weaker. It now failed completely. Naturally, the handset is completely sealed with no non.destructive way to change the battery. The latter are freely available for about $15 on the web but you need to dremel the handset in half, unsolder the old battery and solder the new battery in place. Although I do like the cleaning performance of the Diamond Clean, I am not investing $200 in yet another handset. I now have two handsets, which are mechanically in perfect shape and am told by Philips support to throw them away after I hit the bottom of the handset with a hammer to discard of the battery separately. Ridiculous. Edit: One thing I forgot to mention: what always made me shake my head with those handsets was the fact that Philips turned the principle \\"form follows function\\" around. The pretty, smooth surface looks great but is really not what you need in a moist bathroom environment. I had it slip out of my hands several times.
  48. Great brushing action, but the material is very slippery unless wet (which is odd but true). The shape of the handle is wide at the base and narrow at top so it has a natural tendency to escape your grip. If your hands are dry and the handle is dry, it will slip out of your hand before you even know what is happening. I run some water over the handle now and find that it adds a tacky feel that helps a lot. It has a visually sexy design, but ergonomics could be improved by adding a ridge or contour to grip the handle better. Overall I am happy with the results I get.

The reason for this is that my gums have a tendency to bleed, and I have very sensitive teeth. I found that I had no problem using the system, that my gums felt better, and that my teeth did look whiter, as promised, with no other product (such as a whitener) needed.<br /><br />The system comes with a charger glass and a USB charging travel case. When I read on the box that the toothbrush could be charged by placing it in the glass (which also functions very well as a glass to hold water to rinse your mouth out with), I stepped back for a moment, thinking I had entered the twilight zone! Upon unpacking and closer inspection, I found that the glass is placed on a charger, which is plugged into an electrical outlet.   59. I recently upgraded from my old sonicare toothbrush to this one. I must say, I like it a lot. It's not much different from my old model (flexcare), but the battery pretty much died so I needed to make a new purchase. The design is by far the best one out of the other sonicare models. It's really beautiful, the LED lights on it look great. On the rest of the reviews, everyone is spot on. But there are some flaws: - The travel case is fantastic, but when it comes to charging it has some issues. It doesn't always charge, and the brush base has to be in the perfect position for it to charge. If it moves SLIGHTLY the LED battery light will stop glowing and the menu options will light up. It's not the most stable. - In my past sonicare toothbrush (flexcare) I always would turn it on for a quick second after I rinsed the brush off. With this brush you can't, whenever you hit the on/off button it will go directly to the next speed. So you need to go to all speeds to eventually turn them off. I've now learned to just shake the head after rinsing it. - The battery life has not yet made it to 3 weeks for me, simply only 1.5 weeks (on standard clean twice a day) Overall this is the sonicare quality, and a great brush. It's a bit high, but it's totally worth the investment.
  60. ***FIRSTLY A BIG DISCOVERY***: I bought 2 Diamondclean brushes and had a problem charging both, but only in one specific outlet. Everywhere else it charged fine but the one outlet I needed it to charge in (bathroom) it wouldn't. It drove me crazy to the extent that I had 2 different electricians out and not until just now on my own, did I discover the problem. The base was sitting on my metal medicine cabinet which sits below my mirror (older style built in to apartment prob from 70's) and the metal was preventing the induction charging!!! If this brush's base sit's on metal it WILL NOT CHARGE!! To make matters worse the indicator lights behave as if it is charging so you have no way of knowing. Shame they don't tell you this, would have saved Philips a return for no reason, and saved me 2 electricians and DAYS of headache. I'm a LONG time 10+ years sonicare user and have always had the latest model, last being the flexcare with UV sanitizer. Although this Diamondclean model looks very cool and appears to have a nicer brush head I wasn't expecting that much difference in performace over the flexcare which is already great. Needless to say I was blown away. This is 10 times better than the previous model solely in performance. And I'm referring to performance of the unit in terms of power. Way more powerful. In all honesty my teeth feel CLEANER than after going to the dentist. They literally feel like glass. Why only 4 stars? (Originally I gave it 3 bc I thought there was a battery issue but I figured it out) Firstly you aren't able to select the setting you want until it's already on and spraying your bathroom with toothpaste. This isn't a huge deal especially if you use the same setting every time (though that kinda defeats the purpose of the selection). You literally have to turn it on (while looking at it) to cycle through the settings and select the one you want. And since the pause only works after it's been in the same setting for like 10 seconds, the alternative is selecting the setting before you put toothpaste on, standing there and holding it for 10 seconds running just to be able to pause it, to then put toothpaste on it. I guess this is the tradeoff of having only one button. The other issue is the base had imperfections and scuffs. I opened 4 more brushes and most of the shiny chromed bases are scuffed. The glass is also scratched and has a sharp unpolished lip. You wouldn't find something this bad at a 99 cent store. In all honesty I don't think these things will bother or even be apparant to most people. Which is most likely why Philips allows it. IMO they need to step it up in the quality control department if they want to continue to attract discerning customers that will spend $200 on a toothbrush VS the ones that would rather spend $50-$100. I'm the $200 brusher and I expect a base without imperfections and scuffs for my $200 toothbrush. Period. I found out they are manufactured in both Thailand and China. the base was flawless in the thailand brush. The china brushes were the ones with the lackluster bases.
  61. This is a decent electric toothbrush. It does the job well, my only complaint is that the brush is really small compared to my regular electric brush.<br /><br />I'm fascinated by the charging technology. There's a small base that plugs in to the wall, you put a glass on top of that and put the toothbrush in the glass. The brush doesn't make direct contact with the charger. There's a travel case, and you plug a USB cable into the case to charge it. (You can plug it into the wall or into your laptop.) Again, the brush is not in direct contact with the charger. I know that this technology works, but I'm a software engineer, so this is magic to me.<br /><br />Overall, a good brush, nut the price is pretty steep.
  62. I was a bit worried that I wouldn't be able to practically review this product...after all, I'd never spent more than $8 for a toothbrush, so this product (despite all of its bells and whistles) had a bold line to reach: was it worth 30 times a normal toothbrush if that's what you were going to pay for it? I can happily say that after a few weeks of use, you can certainly justify the cost.<br /><br />Phillips seems to have thought of everything that you might request for a toothbrush of this quality. In terms of normal use, it is easy to use and clean. The five different programs are more than adequate for everything that you might want, from a deep cleaning to a quick polish. The inductive charging system within the rinsing glass is very effective, although the cord is a bit bulky and may be difficult to leave plugged in at all times. The toothbrush is equipped with a carrying case and USB charger for travel use, and the two brush heads provided are of good quality and hold up well to daily use and cleaning.<br /><br />In short, if you've never wanted to take the plunge for a high-quality toothbrush, you won't be disappointed in this. If you're used to Sonicare products, this is the top of the line. Highly recommended.
  63. I have been wanting to try an electric toothbrush for quite sometime, and my dental hygenist does recommend the Philips Sonicare, but I wasn't sure I wanted to spend that kind of money without really knowing how well they worked.<br />The opportunity to try one out for myself, well a great chance to see how this product works and if it really is worth the money.<br />Well, here is what I can tell you: as a person who has used a manual toothbrush for most of my life, I felt a little silly the first time I used this. I had to \\"learn\\" to wait till I got it in my mouth before I turned it on so I didn't spray toothpaste everywhere. After getting used to that, I found it quite easy to use and I love the high-quality look of it. I didn't know if I would like having it sit out on my bathroom counter, but it looks very elegant (as much as a toothbrush can) and the cord is long enough that you can move the base around and hide the cord behind things on the counter,<br />There are several things I really like about this prouduct and just a few I do not.<br /><br />What I like:<br /> The charger. They give you a small plastic stand or a realyl nice glass to use as a charger. Now, I tried the plastic one first, because I thought it would take up less room. I changed my mind when I tried the glass out because all you have to do is place the toothbrush in the glass and it charges! So no toppling over. great idea.<br /><br />The travel case/charger eith a usb cord. I travel a lot for business and it's great to know I can bring my electric toothbrush along because the case doubles as a charger!<br /><br />The \\"pause\\" every 30 seconds so you can tell when to move the brush to another part of your mouth. This is great because now I can see I have not been taking enough time to brush my teeth. (it is recommended you brush for 2 minutes)<br /><br />The different settings. Clean, white, gum care, polish. I have tried them all, but I mainly use the regular clean setting,and my teeth feel so clean! I do sometimes swtich to the white setting because I am a tea drinker and would love my teeth to be whiter. I also use the polish after clean, for an extra clean feeling.<br /><br />What I did not like:<br /><br />I would have liked 2 of the regular brush heads instead of one regular and one smaller. Not a huge deal, but I probably will not use the small one and for the price it would be great to have 2 heads. They do sell replacements, though, and they are not too high priced.<br /><br />Actually, it looks like that is the only thing I do not like. The Phillips Sonicare Diamond head toothbrush is an excellent choice. I would highly recommend it if you are looking for a high-quality electric toothbrush.setting because I am a tea drinker and would love my teeth to be whiter. I also use the polish after clean, for an extra clean feeling. What I did not like: I would have liked 2 of the regular brush heads instead of one regular and one smaller. Not a huge deal, but I probably will not use the small one and for the price it would be great to have 2 heads. They do sell replacements, though, and they are not too high priced. Actually, it looks like that is the only thing I do not like. The Phillips Sonicare Diamond head toothbrush is an excellent choice. I would highly recommend it if you are looking for a high-quality electric toothbrush.
  64. first of all, I love the design and how it works when it is not defective. The warranty is 2 years which some of you will need like me. From the picture, you can see the charging light is not on for the replacement brush. I urge you not to waste your money on a product with a poorly built interior.

  72. I have been using electric toothbrushes for more than 10 years and this thing is hands down the best one on the market. I purchased this toothbrush a few weeks ago and even upgrading from my older Sonicare, I've noticed a huge difference. I never thought I had sensitive teeth in the past - I just thought the feeling I had after brushing was normal. Using the sensitive setting on this toothbrush gives a better clean than I got in the past and doesn't leave my teeth feeling like they vibrating afterwards. Also, about once a week I would have some gum sensitivity where there would be redness and or bleeding which has gone away. The 30 second interval timer is great as I like to zone out while brushing and this makes sure I move from each section of my mouth when needed. With my old school Oral B toothbrushes I would sometimes go over the two minute timers as my teeth didn't feel super clean but I haven't come close to experiencing that with this brush. My wife also uses and love this toothbrush. As of now we have been two weeks without recharging this thing - we are trying to see how long it will really go. It comes with a travel charger which is super nice, but really, if the battery lasts this long when would you really need it? If for some reason you do need to charge it it comes with the handy charging glass to keep in your hotel room. This is really the top tier toothbrush, as silly as it sounds. They have a 30 day guarantee so there really is no reason not to try it if you're considering it. I really do look forward to brushing now and I've been using electric toothbrushes for over a decade - that's saying a lot. Highly Recommended.
  73. the Philips Sonicare Diamondclean Rechargeable Toothbrush is what it would pick. I have used an Oral-B battery powered toothbrush for years, but this Philips Sonicare blows it out of the water. Where to begin...<br /><br />First the design and feel of this toothbrush is incredible. It feels comfortable and very natural in my hand, the start button is easy to push, and the overall look of the toothbrush is sleek and minimalist. It comes with a snazzy travel case that can also be used to charge it (though it holds a charge for three weeks) either by plugging it into a wall socket, or, get this: plugging it into the USB port of a computer. For charging it up at home, the method is ingenious: it comes with a cup, that sits atop a charging base. All you have to do is put it into the cup after use, and it charges right there in the cup.<br /><br />The toothbrush assembles quickly and easily, getting the brush-head on and off is as simple as pulling it off and then lightly snapping back on when you need it.<br /><br />The toothbrush has several brushing speeds, including: clean, polish, whiten, and settings for gum care and sensitive teeth. If you are not accustomed to a toothbrush that moves this fast, the first time you use it might be a bit of a unique experience. People with a ticklish palate and gums might find it takes a little while to get used to it. But this toothbrush is absolutely worth it: after I brushed with the Diamondclean, I felt like I'd had my teeth cleaned at the dentist's.<br /><br />It has a feature I found pretty interesting: every 30 seconds, the brushing action seems to pause as a reminder to move on to another quadrant of your mouth. After 2 minutes, the toothbrush cuts off. But if you're not done brushing, just press the start button again, and it picks right back up where it left off. The brushing head is very small, so it gets into all the nooks and crannies quite easily.<br /><br />I am now completely spoiled for any other toothbrush.
  74. Still using it 2 years later.<br />Perfect tooth brush.
  75. ***Update***<br />In barely two months, my teeth look markedly whiter. Two people within the last week made of point of saying that they can tell I have had my teeth whitened (I haven't).<br />------------------------------------------------<br /><br />My new Philips Sonicare Diamond Clean Rechargeable Toothbrush is the best electric toothbrush I have ever used and I have owned more than a few.<br /><br />The number one thing I like is the power. This brush really gets in and does its job using just light pressure.<br /><br />This particular model has multiple settings: Clean; White; Polish; Gum Care and Sensitive. Except for Sensitive mode, the difference is the amount of time the brush stays on.<br /><br />Polish is the shortest and keeps the brush on for one minute. Clean adds another minute for a total of two and White adds thirty more seconds for a total of 2 minutes, 30 seconds. I use the &#34;Gum Care&#34; setting which is another 30 seconds for 3 solid minutes of running time. Sensitive mode runs for 2 minutes at less power to be more gentle on teeth and gums.<br /><br />There is an interval timer for each setting with short beeps and pauses to remind you to move on to the next quadrant of your mouth. Sometimes I space a bit while brushing, so I find the timer a big plus.<br /><br />There is an &#34;Easy-start feature&#34; that gradually increases the power over the first 14 brushings. It would seem to be especially beneficial for anyone not already using Sonicare brushes, or electric brushes in general. For those replacing or upgrading, the feature has a by-pass option to get the full benefits of the brush day one.<br />The Charging Travel Case is cool; the ability to charge the battery by connecting it to my laptop via USB is something I found very smart. The downside of the case is that it does not seem to have been thoroughly thought out. The most glaring omission is not being able to store the USB cord inside the case when not in use. I ended up wrapping the cord around the Case with a loose knot. It's not a huge deal, but the case does loose some of its cool factor with the cord dangling.<br /><br />The &#34;Hygienic Travel Cap&#34; is a clear plastic cap engineered to fit tightly around the bristle end. It protects the bristles while allowing air to circulate to dry the brush. Unfortunately, the cap cannot be used if using the Charging Travel Case. The brush will not fit in the travel case with the cap on. I use the Charging Travel Case all of the time because it makes the brush really mobile, so the caps became just two more items floating around inside the bathroom junk drawer. For later generations, I recommend that Philips rework the case so that the brushes with caps on will fit.<br /><br />All in all, I highly recommend the Philips Sonicare Diamond Clean Rechargeable Toothbrush to anyone serious about keeping their teeth and gums in tip-top shape.g the cord around the Case with a loose knot. It's not a huge deal, but the case does loose some of its cool factor with the cord dangling.<br /><br />The &#34;Hygienic Travel Cap&#34; is a clear plastic cap engineered to fit tightly around the bristle end. It protects the bristles while allowing air to circulate to dry the brush. Unfortunately, the cap cannot be used if using the Charging Travel Case. The brush will not fit in the travel case with the cap on. I use the Charging Travel Case all of the time because it makes the brush really mobile, so the caps became just two more items floating around inside the bathroom junk drawer. For later generations, I recommend that Philips rework the case so that the brushes with caps on will fit.<br /><br />All in all, I highly recommend the Philips Sonicare Diamond Clean Rechargeable Toothbrush to anyone serious about keeping their teeth and gums in tip-top shape.

  77. After $3k in gum and tooth work a few years ago, I was totally sold on power toothbrushes. I've gone through 3 of the AA-powered $20 version -- they're great for travel, but water ingress in the bottom always ends up eventually destroying them.<br /><br />Given that I brush my teeth 1-2 times/day, every day, spending $200 on a toothbrush is a bit painful, but seems like a totally justifiable expense. So, I bought the top of the line, which is this brush. The main features which sold me are the induction charging cup and the USB travel charger and case -- they looked great in the review, and in person, are just as good as I expected.<br /><br />The new and even more expensive diamondclean brush head does seem to be an improvement on both the E-type and the proclean brushheads previous; the main upgrade is a smaller, more dense head.<br /><br />I probably wouldn't have upgraded from one of the regular sonicare products to this, but as a new customer for the rechargeable products, it seems like the best brush on the market.

  79. I'm trying to find words for this toothbrush, but \\"amazing\\" and \\"more than I thought possible\\" seem like they won't do it. This is the best toothbrush I have ever had. I know that sounds weird - after all, it is just a toothbrush. But it cleans in a way that I have never seen a toothbrush do before. It also is incredibly well thought out. The brush heads have wear indicators on them so you know when to replace them. It charges in the glass, so the handle stays clean and you can stick the glass in the dishwasher. The battery lasts, well, not quite forever, but nearly. The travel case protects the toothbrush and charges straight from a USB port on your computer so, if you have a trip that lasts longer than 2-3 weeks (the battery life) you can just hook it up to the computer with the same cable you use to download pictures from your camera to charge it.<br /><br />Get one. I've had 4 or 5 sonic toothbrushes and nothing else compares.
  80. My dentist recommended the Philips Sonicare Diamondclean toothbrush. Skeptic that I am, I thought it was just another example of a doctor being influenced by a big corporation. However, I was so frustrated by the amount of tartar that had to be removed during my last checkup that I thought it might be worth a try. Let me say that I have used an Oral B electric toothbrush for the last three years and hoped it would prevent the tartar buildup. But it didn't. When I first used the Diamondclean, I knew this was no ordinary electric toothbrush. The brush itself moves at at extraordinarily high speed. It's like having a hummingbird in your mouth. As a result, I'm not sure if it's the brush action that does such a great job or the sheer speed. The result? After every brushing, my mouth feels like I've just had my biannual cleaning. I'm really eager for my next appointment in Spring 2012 to see if my anecdotal impressions are borne out by a professional cleaning.
  81. Unlike the previous \\"Flexcare\\" and \\"Elite\\" models, the \\"Diamondclean\\" model has been designed by clueless people who maybe produce art for modern museums, but certainly have never used the toothbrush for actually brushing their teeth. The \\"Diamondclean\\" model offers five different modes: \\"clean\\", \\"white\\", \\"polish\\", \\"gum care\\", and \\"sensitive\\". You select the mode you want by pressing a *single* button multiple times. So, if you want \\"sensitive\\", you need to put the brush head into your mouth, and press the button five times. You can't do that while looking at the display, because the handle will turn on on the first button press, and splatter the toothpaste all over the place in \\"clean\\" mode, while you're progressing slowly to the mode you actually want. What kind of art house goon comes up with such impractical designs? To recharge the handle, you stick it into an included water-glass-shaped container that's sitting on a small silver charging plate. While this resembles an old-fashioned toothbrush sticking in a water glass for rinsing your mouth (\\"How cute!\\"), it makes the electric toothbrush lean at a 30 degree angle, wasting space next to your sink. There's also an adapter that lets it stand vertically, but you need to make sure you always put the handle back exactly the same without rotating, because it won't charge if it's not 100% aligned. And make sure it's not located next to anything metallic, like a metal bathroom cabinet! Surrounding metal will *discharge* your Sonicare! In fact, I sent the first Diamondclean back to Amazon, thinking the battery was defective. When the second shipping arrived and showed the same problem, I put it away from the metal cabinet and it charged fine. This was never a problem with the Elite model, which was a great product for brushing your teeth instead of fancy-pants industrial design. It comes with two brushes, a normal-sized one and one that's about half that size. If you're a couple, you have to either agree who's using the odd-sized one or buy an extra one, which comes at about ten bucks extra. Yes, per brush head. If there was a prize for the most useless industrial design, the person who came up the Diamondhead mode selector would certainly deserve it. Also if there was an industry award for throwing a product on the market without any consumer testing, the Diamondhead would be a top candidate.
  82. When I first got this Sonicare toothbrush, I decided not to post a review immediately. Instead, I chose to take my time and see what the effects of using this product would be over a long period of time. After three months of using this toothbrush, I can say that it does have a whitening effect on my teeth and it does, indeed, promote gum health.<br /><br />This was the first sonic toothbrush I ever used, and, at first, I have to say that the sensation in my teeth was unpleasant. I have sensitive teeth, so it took a little while to get used to this toothbrush. What really helped was the function of the product that ensures that the first few brushing sessions are less intense than the regular ones.<br /><br />I can't say that I saw any whitening effect in just one week, as the promotional info promised. However, three months into using the product I can say that it definitely does whiten teeth. It isn't going to substitute whitening treatments you can get at a dentist's office but it does have a noticeable whitening effect. I also have noticed a significant improvement in my gum health.<br /><br />One of the things I appreciate the most about this product is that it's perfectly suited for traveling. The travel case is very sleek, light and it charges the toothbrush, too.<br /><br />Overall, I am very happy with this Sonicare toothbrush.

I have only had the toothbrush for a few days now, but have been enjoying it very much.<br /><br />It works exactly as expected and does provide a good brushing experience. Since I haven't had a sonic toothbrush, the first experience tickled the roof of my mouth, but I quickly got adjusted to it.<br /><br />The one gripe I have with it is that after the 2 minute brushing cycle the unit automatically turns off. I would prefer it not to because if there are areas of my mouth (namely tongue) that I haven't gotten to yet I have to turn it on again. Last but not least, the single button interface means that if you press the button once the brush turns on, the second press (if within 5 seconds) cycles through various brushing modes. I like to turn on the brush when rinsing it, but end up cycling through all the modes instead of turning it off. I guess it's something to get used to.

  88. I previously used a Sonicare Elite until it wore out a few months ago after about 8-years of use. After the Elite, I was using an Oral-B Professional electric toothbrush that I received for free from my orthodontist, until it died in a tragic outlet accident. I decided that was a sign to try the new Sonicare, and I'm very glad I did! The DiamondClean is amazing! It is way better than either the Oral-B or the Elite. The DiamondClean is compact, lightweight, quiet, the brush bristles are soft, and it leaves your teeth feeling extremely clean after use. I would highly recommend this toothbrush! While I like the concept, the actual `shot glass' is huge--more like the size of a whiskey glass!
  89. A second unit just broke down in about two years. Even when in warranty, getting a replacement in Athens, Greece is a hassle. There is only one shop where you can replace the unit. It is located in a suburb of Athens (Nea Ionia) and works from 9am to 3pm, workdays only. You need to go there in person to leave the broken unit and then go another day to collect it. Which means that you need to take days (or at least hours) off, if you are employed 9-5.
  90. Great toothbrush. I really love it and it cleans the teeth just perfect, leaving my mouth feeling fresher and cleaner longer. The only downside is the price.. But then it is worth it.
  91. Update 10-17-16: I have reduced my previous 4-star review (below) to 3 stars due to the unbelievably short lifespan of this toothbrush handle. I can't believe how many times I have had to have this replaced. Just initiated another warranty claim today. I purchased a new one myself after the first one died, because it was just barely out of warranty. I believe today's warranty replacement request is the 3rd one. The usual issue is that the power button becomes recessed and will not operate the handle. On one occasion, the issue was that the handle would no longer charge. You can (and definitely should) register this product online, because that gives you an additional 6 months of warranty coverage. You'll need it. _________________ I have been using a standard electric toothbrush for many years, and I have long wondered if the sonic toothbrushes were all that much better. Yes, they are. At least this one is. After brushing with this DiamondClean, my teeth feel as clean as they do after a polishing at the dentist's office minus the grit from the paste they use. I'm pleasantly astounded. You can barely see that the brush is moving, but it is. The vibration is intense, and you'll feel a tingle or tickle while using it. That's unnerving at first, but I got used to it pretty quickly. There is considerable splatter during brushing if you're not careful. I have used the clean and white modes so far, and both make my teeth feel smooth and clean. The white mode vibration seems a little stronger, but that's the only perceivable difference. This toothbrush has a very sleek design - it looks very nice in my bathroom. The charger is a glass that you rest the toothbrush in, but a smaller travel charger is also provided. Apparently there is no difference in charging power, so I assume the difference is mainly a matter of aesthetics. I could also see the toothbrush being knocked off of the travel charger base very easily if you used that on a regular basis. The DiamondClean also comes with a nice travel case. The purported long-lasting charge (three weeks) would seem to make the travel charger unnecessary, but I haven't checked out the battery life yet. Here's my one complaint - the reason I'm only giving this four stars. The DiamondClean has a timer mechanism that reminds you when to switch from one set of teeth to the next. The idea is to ensure that you're spending enough time brushing each section of your mouth. However, at the end of the timed cycle, the toothbrush shuts off! I am rarely finished at that point, so I have to take the toothbrush out of my mouth, put my glasses on to make sure I'm activating the correct brushing mode, and then start the cycle over. (Yes, you can shut it off manually.) I wish there were a way to deactivate that timer. I can't attest to the whitening results yet, since I've only been using the DiamondClean for a few days, but I can definitely tell you that this toothbrush makes my teeth feel cleaner than anything I've ever used before. And I'm thinking that will translate to fewer dental problems down the road.
  92. Awesome toothbrush. Well worth the money.
  93. Works well as a toothbrush, but the batteries are not replaceable and the unit cannot be repaired, according to Philips. Mine broken down 2 months after the end of the warranty and all customer support could do is offer a 15% discount on the next purchase.
  94. Maybe it's just me but I just bought this -my third Sonicare model - and I am already in love. There are several designs fixes which make me happy over my last Sonicare. First the charging base is sleek but mostly it's EASY TO CLEAN. I was tired of cleaning in the nooks and crannies of my old charger base. Just gross. Next the brush head is EASY TO CLEAN. No longer am I worried about the germs collecting in the brush head basin. I often cleaned it with listerine to keep it sanitary but it was still easy to find gross murky, germy water left behind after brushing. Removing the reservoir was really good for this upgrade. Lastly, being able to charge while the brush is still in the case just makes sense. I'm sure there will be tweaks to improve the case, the brush, the charger, etc... But I cannot begin to tell you how excited I am to have this version. If it cleans only as well as the last version I will be a very happy customer!<br /><br />After using: I am still in love. Not sure why some people area having problems turning off. I don't have to scroll through different options to turn the brush off early. I hit the button once and the brush turns off. To clean the brush, I turn it back on and rinse and turn it off. No excessive button pressing. I think maybe some reviewers did not deactivate the \\"easy start\\" feature that comes as a factory default. I deactivated it before my first time using it. Maybe that made a difference. I just love it.<br /><br />Okay here's yet another update: it stopped working. Battery was charged but it just wouldn't turn on. I called sonicare and read the numbers on my unit. They are sending me a replacement handle. Took care of it in 5-10 minutes. Worth every dime. If I had the money, I'd buy some stock in the company too! I'm just that happy!!!!
  95. I replaced my old Sonicare with this Diamond Clean. So far no complaints. Does an outstanding job.
  96. Quit working after a yea but they replaced the entire thing promptly. When I went for my last cleaning the hygienist asked if I had one of these because she said I was not cleaning the backs of my front teeth. Turns out pricy brushes leave a ridge due to design flaw. Cannot change stars but just wanted to update my review.
  97. I like this toothbrush overall. Nice design. The travel case/charger is nice. Here's where is falls short: Seems like the mode should be able to be set. IE set for Gum Care as the default setting. The manual lets you turn off the 'Easty-start' setting, but no way to set a default mode setting. I, too, got the 'Dental Professional Trial NOT FOR RESALE' packaging in a slightly dinged outer box. But, not bad enough for me to send it back. I dispute the questions of whether this is illegal to sell as some have said. Its not like its the 'Do Not Remove' label on a mattress. I say that tongue-in-cheek. It seems to be just some verbiage for marketing and sales reps. I did find that the cup was missing. I called the Phillips Customer Support number in the paper work inside (800 682-7664) and mentioned the model and that the cup didn't come with it and without any complaints or objections, are sending me a replacement cup \\"in 7-10 business days.\\" From what they said, it sounds like it happens, my guess would be some factory packaging problem - made in China after all. The USB case/charger is great, but i think they should have found a way to pack the USB cable in the case at least. But I won't worry about it too much, I usually bring extra usb cables with me when I travel. If I need to charge it, I'll just use one of those. Overall, since it is marked down, it is worth it. But, not at suggested retail. Why no voting buttons? We don't let customers vote on their own reviews, so the voting buttons appear only when you look at reviews submitted by others.   99. I've tried other \\"electric\\" toothbrushes and gave up on them all because they didn't perform as advertised. This toothbrush beats them all hands down. Nicely designed, variable speeds makes brushing easy rather than a chore. Cleans up easily, and I really like the rechargeable stand. Been using this product for three weeks now and haven't given up. I recommend this brush for anyone who wants serious dental hygiene and care. Don't be put off by the price -- it is definitely worth the investment for your oral care.
  100. I have mixed feelings about this item. I like Sonicare and have used it for years. My flex gave out after several years and I upgraded to the Diamond model.<br /><br />What I liked.<br />nicer finish. The handle has a very nice finish and feels less slippery than previous models.<br />Diamond head does a nice job but it will fit on most model handles so not a big deal here.<br />Charger is cool. I like the glass and even the plastic induction charger that comes with it. Haven't used the travel kit yet and probably won't but if I do it could be handy. It does look very cool.<br /><br />What I did not like.<br />Too expensive and not a good value compared to other models.<br />You can not see which setting it is on because it moves from setting to setting while the brush is vibrating. If you take it out of your mouth to see which setting it is on, it will splatter toothpaste and water several feet in the air spraying your counter and mirror. HORRIBLE DESIGN and in my opinion could make this model a pass for some.<br />You can not change the default setting for which timer you use. This could change my opinion of the above flaw which causes the brush to spray water everywhere, but Philips missed the opportunity to incorporate this feature.<br /><br />If you have money to burn and like Apple like styling, this is a very nice looking update to the Sonicare line and you will enjoy the feel of it. If Value for your dollar is important, this is definitely not the model for you. Especially with the clumsy mode changing single button feature.
  101. Two defective units already only after about a year. Phillips customer service so polite but they never replaced my unit.<br />Very expensive toothbrush should last more then a year. Still under &#34;warranty&#34; but Phillips never sent replacement unit.
  102. This is the first review I have ever written about a product I have purchased on Amazon. Phillips impressed me so much that I felt compelled to do so. I purchased this toothbrush a year ago at the recommendation of my dentist. Since then I have been extremely pleased with it as it is easy to operate and always makes my teeth feeling very clean. There was also a noticeable difference when I went to my dentist again for a check up and cleaning 6 months later.<br /><br />However, a couple days ago the toothbrush was out of juice despite having been on the charger all night. I tried the travel charger and different outlets and still, it would not charge. I was quite upset as this was the most expensive toothbrush I have ever bought.<br /><br />So, I set aside 20-30 minutes out of my day to call Phillips about the issue because from experience, that is a minimum when calling any customer service department. And, I was prepared with my proof of purchase and fully expected to wait on hold, then be interrogated about what was wrong, how I was using it, where I store it, etc. But, to my surprise, I was connected immediately to a live rep without having to navigate through 10 minutes of prompts and press this and press that. When the rep came on, she was very nice and very helpful. She asked me for the serial number and what was wrong. Five minutes later they were sending me a new one and an email confirmation was in my inbox before I even got off the phone with her!<br /><br />I'm not upset the thing stopped working. It happens. I was extremely impressed by how they handled it and that the process was completely painless.<br /><br />Kudos Phillips!!
  103. The brush head size is much better than any Oral B product my wife and I have tried. It easily gets into all the difficult to reach spots. The soft bristles are easy on the gums. And, boy do your teeth feel great after brushing, while the vibration is not too strong like it is on some of the older Sonicare models. Also, this unit has a significant improvement over the older style brush heads that collected water, toothpase and grime. These are easier to clean, easier to remove and attach and the whole brush and handle system is far more sanitary and easy to clean than older Sonicare models. Travel case is really nice too. Love this brush.<br /><br />Cons: It would be nice if the charging system allowed the cord to plug directly into the handle of the brush for travel so you would not have to carry the small round base along on trips. At least the size of the base is not too big.

  110. Wow! This is one expensive tooth brush! Going to the local college of dentistry for my dental work and my student dentist recommended I get one of these because after brushing my teeth for almost 60 years evidently I still wasn't getting how to do it! Well, it's not my fault if they change the size of the brushes and the way you're supposed to brush every twenty years or so, right! Hesitant and skeptical at first, I could not justify the &#34;investment.&#34; However, after reading all the specifications and asking around about other products and checking out what was available in local stores, I took the plunge and ordered one. I am totally surprised at how clean, white, and shiny my teeth are after about two weeks of using this brush. Granted, we did the routine maintenance cleaning at the school, but the results cannot be disputed. And, not only does this thing do a great job, but it times you in each quadrant, so your teeth and gums get a workout. I had a cheap battery operated brush before this, but it's no match for the constant battery power of this machine! I charged it when I received it, and haven't charged it again in over two weeks! The charger is that new type where you just drop it in the provided charging glass and it charges by electrical conductance or something. And, it comes with a USB charger cord for on the road sue, and a charger base that you set the brush in an it charges without no plug! One thing I did not do is order extra brushes at the time I ordered the product. Do this, you will need them! As a &#34;tool guy,&#34; this is a &#34;real&#34; tool, not some gimmicky toy, while being safe and clean and easy to use with minimal practice. Read the instructions, it has a &#34;slow speed setting&#34; from the factory that you can use to get used to the vibes, or remove to use the full power from the get go. Smile!
  111. I love this product. It cleans my teeth very effectively and much better than my old Braun toothbrush. Well worth the expense.
  112. I like the product so far. My teeth always feel super clean after brushing and the timers on the brush setting help me to remain diligent when brushing; even if I'm half asleep.   114. Years ago my Mom bought electric toothbrushes for my entire family on the theory that jaw-rattling fire hazards must be better for your teeth than plain old .99 cent drugstore brushes. The results were less than impressive, and that was my first and until now last experience with electric brushes. Until I got this product, and saw where the technology has gone in the last ten years. When I got the Philips Sonicare, I was particularly interested in the \\"whitening\\" setting, because I drink a lot of green tea and have stains that are tough remove, mostly because I never stop drinking tea. This brush really did whiten as promised, and polished, and removed plaque like nothing I've ever used. It's a strange experience to wake up in the morning with your teeth still feeling completely clean. My gums are noticeably less swollen in the morning and the tea stains are definitely improved, but the real surprise was my skin. I suffer from severe food allergies, and unless I eat nothing but apples and lettuce my skin has a strong tendency towards redness and irritation. Since using the brush my skin is much less red, and when I stop using the brush it goes back to flushed-looking. I think this is because the brush is cleaning my teeth so much better and allergens are being removed quicker. It was such an unexpected benefit I wanted to mention it. Drawbacks are few. The design of the charger is inelegant (it looks ready to tip over any second) but serviceable. I think the brush should come with three normal-sized brush heads, instead of one full-size and a bonus itty bitty brush head. Kinda strange. The product is clearly supposed to resembled an Apple Iproduct, for reasons known best to Sonicare. Does everything have to look like an Iphone? The travel case and computer charger are nifty, the sensitive setting useful (these brushes still rattle your jaw), and all else worked just as it is supposed to. Well worth the money and the health benefits, even the surprise ones. All in all: GRADE: A
  115. The Best tooth brush I have ever experienced. My teeth feel very clean and my mouth refreshed .

  136. I've been using the Philips Sonicare HX9332/05 Diamondclean Rechargeable Toothbrush for a little over a month now. I must say I'm impressed! I've been an old-fashioner manual tooth brusher all my life and this is the first time I've ventured into the realms of the power toothbrush. First off, the DiamondClean system is compact and easy to use. It doesn't take up a lot of counter top space. One of the coolest thing, to me at least, is the charging glass. The DiamondClean comes with a glass that actually charges up the toothbrush while it rests in the glass. How cool is that? Yes, it's the same glass you can use for rinsing your mouth when you are finished brushing. I also like the travel case and the fact that you can plug your charging base into your laptop. Technology rocks!<br /><br />The most important aspect of the DiamondClean system is how well it works in your mouth. I wanted to use it for at least a month before writing this review. After a month, I can say that I am really impressed with the results. I tend to brush my teeth too hard with my manual brush and so the power brush on the DiamondClean actually seemed like it wasn't churning as hard as I thought it should, but then, as soon as I was finished - wow! My teeth and gums felt amazingly clean and fresh! Over the course of a month there has been a marked and remarkable improvement in the health of my gums and mouth, and my teeth do seem to even look whiter and healthier. The Smartimer and Quadpacer features make sure that you have brushed sufficiently and in every area.<br /><br />This is a great system. Five stars, two thumbs up!
