  161. I received it on time and immediately removed it and began charging it. It takes 12 hours to fully charge. The charge is estimated to last through 3 weeks of use (twice a day). On Clean, it brushes for 2 minutes (30 seconds front and back, upper and lower). I use a 2-minute cycle for the upper teeth and another 2 for the lower (just my preference). It gets my teeth much cleaner than normal brushing; I noticed a slight whitening effect after a few days. I have not tried the other cycles yet. You get a charging unit composed of a base and a glass tumbler. You merely plug the base in, set the tumbler on it, put the toothbrush inside it and it charges. It also comes with a travel case which has its own cords to charge from the wall outlet or a usb port on your computer. I have not tried charging that way. The toothbrush is very attractive. It is very sleek and the handle is all white. The different cycles that you can use are invisible until you turn it on or charge it. Then the cycles are lit up and glow. After using the toothbrush, the cycle \\"lights\\" fade away and all you see is a white toothbrush. It is very easy to clean. There are 2 brush heads and a cover to slip over the bristles after use. I am very satisfied and love using it. I cannot speak to its longevity as I have only had it since the 3rd week of December. I do recommend this based on my own use. You can get replacement brush heads on Amazon as well. It is well made and even the glass tumbler is heavy glass and attractive.
  162. Have been using Sonicare toothbrushes for years and I love this newest edition. Takes up less counter space and does a terrific job on the teeth. Try it and your teeth may be thanking you!
  163. I love this toothbrush. It times my brushing so that I don't rush and the vibrating stimulates the gums so that they feel healthier. Can't go back to regular brushing.
  164. In just a fee weeks i saw impressive results, my teeth had never felt cleaner and they are getting even whiter, the gum option is perfect for a much necessary massage every other day.
  165. This is my first sonicare that I bought after my Oral B died after about ten years. Initially I was quite impressed with how well it cleaned, much better than my old Oral B. After several days the sonicare started buzzing when putting slight side pressure on the brush head. After two weeks it got to the point where just barely touching the side of the brush head, particularly when brushing rear molars, the unit would buzz loudly and there was no vibration at the bristles. Quite aggravating after spending nearly 200 dollars. So I called sonicare for a warranty replacement, which they honored. Received the replacement unit a couple weeks later. That was about six weeks ago and the problem is starting again with the replacement unit. There are several other Amazon reviews reporting similar problems. The only recourse I have at this point is to continue warranty claims until expiration and ultimately never purchase a phillips brush again.
  166. Excellent product. Excellent shipping, too.
  167. I don't usually don't write reviews but I almost didn't get this toothbrush because of one of the other reviews I read. It said that you cannot turn it off to take it out of your mouth without paste flying everywhere because there is only one button for power and mode.<br />If you turn it off mid-brushing to spit, like I do, then that would be a deal breaker. But the truth is, as long as you've had it in your mouth brushing for at least 10 seconds it will turn off as soon as you press the button.<br />Great toothbrush so glad I bought it.
  168. This toothbrush is great! My 6 year old Sonicare finally crapped out on me and chose this one as a replacement.
  169. This is a great toothbrush with new improved brushing features. Clean, polish, sensitive, etc. It is pricey, and does not come with a sanitizer. I kept my old sanitizer which works very well with this. I love it! It was nice to be able to get the perks with the store card for 6 months interest free financing at time of purchase.
  170. Switched from regular toothbrush to Philips Sonicare after doing some research among the other electric toothbrush vendors and models. It has great cleansing power (I feel my teeth are completely clean after each brush), a good 3 week battery life, and cool chargeable traveling bag for the brush. I can't think of any other option I need...
  171. This is simply the best toothbrush on the market. Not only does it clean and whiten your teeth the best of any other manual or electric toothbrush, it is probably the most high-tech device that a person can stick into their face, and it even changed how I brush my teeth by promoting. This is a must-buy for any tech-centric gadget head who cares about oral health and hygeine. I never brushed my teeth regularly before this brush. In fact, I can say with honesty that even three times a month would be giving myself too much credit. Disgusting, I know. But then one day a month or so ago, part of a tooth got chipped off because of a large cavity so I went to the dentist to get it fixed and afterwards, resolved to try a hardcore toothbrush to see if that would make a difference. I did some research and after trying out the Sonciare HealthyWhite, which is also a great toothbrush for people who don't want to spend so much, I decided to purchase the Sonicare DiamondClean.<br /><br />When the product arrived, I immediately opened it to find a very attractive toothbrush and many accessories. This is literally a high-tech swiss army knife for your teeth. The handle of the brush itself is made of a faux-ceramic material that feels great in the hand, and even though it doesn't have the ridges or rubber grip of other Sonicare brushes, it will never slip or slide out of your hand. The DiamondClean brush heads are also very nice and professional looking. The brush handle is ceramic white on the body and chrome on the bottom, where it touches the inductive charger. There is one power/mode button on the handle that cycles through the various modes (of which there are five), and each mode has an illuminated display that lights up a soft white color when that mode is selected and active. There is also a battery/charge indicator on the front near the bottom that lets you know when you're running low on battery, when the brush is in use, and when it's charging. One note: the bottom of thehandle, where it stands on the charger, doesn't have the hole that the little nub of the charger fits into to keep it stable. It is kind of concave and stands on the included chargers, which surround the bottom portion of the handle, preventing it from falling over.<br /><br />The DiamondClean includes two brush heads in the package, one standard size and one compact. I have yet to use the compact one but it looks like it would be just as effective as the standard size, but a bit smaller. Changing from using (rarely) a manual toothbrush to the HealthyWhite was a huge difference, and from the HW to the DiamondClean brush heads made a huge difference. You can feel it immediately. The bristles on the outer edges of the brushing surface of the DiamondClean head are white and blue (blue being the indicator bristles that tell you that you should replace the head when they fade to white) and are arranged in sort of a concave almond shape around the center bristles. The center bristles are the special part of this brush head. They are the green ones in the middle, which appear to be both thinner and more fine than the outside white/blue bristles and are also more densely packed. This is where the real cleaning action happens. These bristles are arranged in a semi-geometrical orientation that really scrubs and cleans your teeth. Also of note, these brush heads can fit on the HealthyWhite and most likely some other Sonicare brush handles, but not the Essence.<br /><br />The brush comes with several different charging options, and this is where the techies should pay attention. For regular use in your home bathroom, there is a charging plate that plugs into your wall with the standard 2-prong power socket, and you can put the included clear plastic charging stand on the plate which is a good looking charging option, and is what I use. The other home charging option is to use the included charging glass, which also fits on top of the charging plate (you can put either the charging stand or the glass onto the charging plate), and allows you to sit your toothbrush in a glass as many people do, and charge it at the same time. I prefer the charging stand because it is more compact and clean looking and keeps the tooth brush standing up straight, matching my other dental tools, instead of leaning against the large glass.<br /><br />The final charging option is also one of the coolest accessories that comes with the brush, and that is the charging travel case. This case is made of a white cloth/synthetic weave on the outside and some sort of green plastic on the inside. There is room for two extra brush heads that fit snugly into their designated areas and space for the toothbrush handle next to that. This case also uses the inductive charging method, so all you have to do is place the handle into the form-fitting slot for it and it will charge when you plug it in, and plugging it in is the fun part. This charging travel case is powered by USB and has a mini-USB port on the end so you can plug it in to charge from a USB port on your laptop or by using the included USB power adapter and cable. Very cool!<br /><br />One of the special features this brush offers is the gentle-on feature, which, for new Sonicare users, starts the brush on first use on a low-power mode, gently increasing the power over the next 14 uses to gradually and gently acclimate the user's mouth to the sensation of using a Sonicare. I guess this is here because some people feel that the toothbrush is too strong when they use it the first time and the sensation is somewhat ticklish, but I didn't require that. If you've previously used a Sonicare toothbrush or don't mind the new super-clean sensation, you can disable this feature like I did by placing the handle of the brush into whichever charging source you choose to use, and pressing and holding the power/mode button down for a few seconds until it beeps. This means that now, whenever you use the brush even if it is the first time, it will always operate at full 100% power. You can turn the gentle-on mode again by repeating the steps: placing the handle on the charger and holding the button for another few seconds until it beeps twice. Another feature is the quadpacer, which tells you how long to brush each quadrant of your teeth. It is recommended that you brush for a full two minutes, so the quadpacer splits that up into 30 seconds of brushing for each quadrant. When you turn it on, after 30 seconds the toothbrush will beep and pause for a second, which indicates that you should move on to the next part of your mouth. Most of the modes work this way, The way I do it is I brush the outside-upper teeth first, then the inside-upper, then outside lower followed by inside lower. However, since my teeth were very badly stained, I use three different modes/cycles every time I brush my teeth. I start out with the standard power Clean mode that goes for two minutes in 4 intervals, then move on to White mode, which is higher powered than Clean mode, which goes on for two minutes in 4 intervals plus another 30 seconds of an even higher powered brushing in 2 intervals for your \\"glamour\\" teeth, or front teeth, top and bottom, followed by the Polish mode, which is the strongest and highest-powered mode the toothbrush offers, giving you 30 seconds each for your top front teeth and lower front teeth. I'm sure some of it is redundant but I still like to use all three modes one after the other to feel cleaner. There are also two additional modes that the toothbrush offers. After Polish is Gum Care, which massages your gums and stimulates the blood flow there and helps to reverse and prevent gingivitis, and after Gum Care, the final mode is Sensitive, which speaks for itself. It is a lower-power mode that you should use if your teeth or gums are sensitive and you feel discomfort using the other more powerful modes. Now if Sensitive mode is any worse than the other modes in terms of cleaning power, it doesn't show or the difference is absolutely minimal. It still cleans and whitens just as well as the other modes, but does so without being uncomfortable.<br /><br />Now as I mentioned above, I had a serious problem when it came to brushing regularly, but in the month since I've had the DiamondClean, I brush three times a day, every single day, without fail. I don't know if other people who had brushing problems have experienced the same thing, but this has made a huge difference for me. Not only are my teeth visibly white (they used to be quite yellow), they feel incredibly clean and fresh after brushing with the Sonicare Diamondclean, which no manual toothbrush can ever replicate. Just for the record, I also use the Sonciare Airfloss since I got this, which is a great device to use before brushing your teeth.<br /><br />Update: I have been using this brush for just over a month and my teeth are more than 5 shades whiter. I have actually gotten compliments and am greeted with surprise every time I smile because my teeth were noticeably yellow before and you could see that a mile away. Now my pearly whites are really pearly white and people are astounded and don't believe that a toothbrush could make such a huge difference. I mean the difference is literally night and day. I'm hooked to my Sonicare DiamondClean now. If your teeth need to be whitened, this is the way to go. Just in case anybody was wondering, I use [[ASIN:B004VGSVHS Crest 3d White Vivid Anticavity Teeth Whitening Radiant Mint Toothpaste 5.8oz, Twin Pack 11.6 Oz Total]] with this brush and rinse out with [[ASIN:B009PIJV1W Crest 3d White Arctic Fresh Rinse 32 Fl Oz]] mouthwash after brushing.
  172. I was excited to get the DiamondClean as a gift, since my FlexCare model had died recently (prematurely--disappointed about that), but it didn't take long to fade. In changing the design from two-buttons to one, they went too far. You can't turn the toothbrush off when you want to!! It changes modes instead of turning off. When I'm done brushing my teeth, I turn the brush on again to rinse it out. If you press the button again, within 5-10 seconds, it switches modes instead of turning off, and you either have to toggle through all 5 modes, or wait another 5-10 seconds before pressing the button again. If you happen to want to turn the brush off in the first 5-10 seconds after you start brushing, you run into the same problem. It's incredibly annoying. Since it doesn't seem to offer any other significant features over the FlexCare, other than a nifty USB charging case, it doesn't seem worth the extra money for extra frustration. And one nit: you would have thought they would have solved the problem of the toothbrush rolling over after you load it up with toothpaste and set it on the counter, but they missed the boat on that, too. It does a fine job of cleaning your teeth, as prior Sonicare brushes have, but if the battery is going to die in 2-3 years, anyway, why invest so much in a lousy design?
  173. I've had several sonicares over the years and I was very happy with them. The only exception being that the water and \\"stuff\\" would get caught in the part where the brush was attached. This is the best part of this toothbrush , there is no place for the water to get caught! Otherwise all the bells and whistles are just that. If I ran through all the cycles it would take me an hour to brush my teeth. I do like the holder, but I can' t justify the price.
  174. Had it for a few years now... Love it.
  175. I upgraded from a sonicate I'd had for about 10 years, which finally the battery was dead and wouldn't hold enough charge to get through a full brushing. This one - wow!! The vibration is far more intense, has multiple 'levels' of cleaning purposes and it is sleek and lightweight. Additionally, I travel tons, so the travel charging case is perfect for me. The home charger is sleek and easy to clean, unlike my last one. So far, I love it!
  176. I always had an oral B toothbrush but I find I like this even more. They glass charger that you can place this in is awesome and it takes so little space that it can be left on the sink. So far I am impressed with the toothbrush but the proof will be when I go for my dental check up and see if it made a difference in my tarter buildup.
  177. Not the cheapest toothbrush on the market....but works great....and all the replacement brushes for any types of these brushes are expensive...but if it does what you need like this one does.....its worth it... The brush hold a charge for a long time...maybe recharge every 2 weeks. Carrying case also has build in travel charger....its all first class!
  178. I must admit this is my first foray into the world of electric toothbrushes. For years I have debated whether or not to get an electric toothbrush, but I was pleasantly surprised with this one. Firs the design is excellent. The look and feel of the toothbrush is exemplary. It has a modern look, and clean simple feel. The design allows you to lay the toothbrush into a glass cup which will charge your toothbrush while you are not using it. The cool factor is definitely at work here, a portable charging station that you can also use to rinse out your mouth when you are finished. The toothbrush has several settings so you can adjust the vibration to your own personal preference. Personally it took me a day or two to adjust to the vibration of the toothbrush, this may primarily be because I am not accustomed to an electric toothbrush, but after a few days I am definitely hooked. The vibration makes your mouth feel clean and fresh, and it keeps that fresh feeling throughout the day. It also gives you that feeling without a lot of work on your part. You simply have to hold the toothbrush in your mouth and the vibration does all the work getting into areas that are tough to get clean with a regular toothbrush. The brush portion easily pops off for changing, or for travel use, or for disinfecting. The adjustable settings allow you to choose how strong you want the vibration. I started off on the sensitive setting, and slowly am working my way to the regular setting. Overall I really enjoy the toothbrush, and I am expecting my next dental appointment to support this feeling.
  179. I have been using a Braun electric toothbrush for many years, with no complaints. I decided to purchase a Philips Sonicare toothbrush after discussions with my dentist. I was not having any dental problems. To the contrary, I feel incredibly lucky to be 59 years young and never even had a cavity! We just felt this may be an even better dental hygiene option for me.<br /><br />I did a lot of research on the various manufacturers and models. Ultimately, I decided I wanted to try the Philips line of Sonicare toothbrush. This conclusion based on familiarity with Philips, product features, and user comments. After comparing several Sonicare models, I narrowed the field down to one or two. I kept coming back to their newest model, this DiamondClean Sonicare, but the price seemed prohibitive. Frankly, I had no intention of spending this much for a 'toothbrush'. I mean, plenty of folks get by with electric and manual toothbrushes costing much, much less. I did feel a sense of resentment towards Philips for excessive price and/or profit. I looked for coupons, deals, etc. Any way to lessen the impact on my wallet. When the dust settled, I was ordering the DiamondClean through Amazon. Amazon consistently gives me the best prices, with no shipping costs, in a secure format.<br /><br />I have been using this brush now for one week. Initial reaction? Finely engineered precision instrument. Has a very nice feel to it, in the hand and in use. Very pleasing aesthetic look to it, like comparing a Ferrari to, well, any other vehicle. It gives off a very determined but gentle hum that varies with the cleaning program I select. I am finding I seem to prefer the Clean and White mode. The best part is once I complete the brushing, my mouth feels like it has just been overhauled! The term squeaky clean comes to mind. It truly does leave that 'just had a professional dental cleaning' feel in my mouth. I can feel a pleasant sensation in my gums, too, which is very good for blood flow and overall gum health. (And no, I am not a Dentist).<br /><br />I won't go into all the product details and features, as I feel those have been fully covered in the product listings and previous user reviews. I do not get a sense of any changes I would make to the mechanics or features of the unit. I intend to give my impression on the overall effectiveness, which is the only subject that really matters.<br /><br />Does this toothbrush successfully complete it's intended duties? After such a brief time using my Philips Sonicare DiamondClean toothbrush, I can already fully commit to this one statement - 'THE best toothbrush I have EVER used!'.
  180. Probably the best toothbrush there is when it comes to cleaning your teeth. However, this product missed out on five stars for two reasons:<br /><br />1. The first brush I ordered stopped working completely after about two years. Unfortunately, I was one month past the warranty, and Philips wouldn't budge on a replacement. You'd expect a $200 brush to be more reliable.<br /><br />2. The power button and timer could be a bit more intuitive (as other reviews have already mentioned and covered in detail).
  181. I have had two Sonicare diamond clean tooth brushes and I love them. Problem is the On/Off switches go bad in about 1 1/2 years from purchase. I have now spent over $200 in purchasing two brushes and now my third one now has a bad switch. For $400 I can buy a lot of toothbrushes. For something so expensive, Phillips needs to have a better warranty. There is an obvious problem with their switches on these brushes. Other than that, it's a great brush and does a fabulous job.
  182. The main thing I realized after recieving this toothbrush is-- there are people out there leading such exciting lives that they need to recharge their toothbrushes with their laptops! What else is going on out there I need to know about?<br /><br />Seriously, this thing pretty much scared me at first. I had to start on the 'training wheels' setting otherwise known as sensitive. No kidding, I must be, because my first reaction was to throw it across the room. When the directions say- may cause some tickling, believe it. Eventually I did get used to it and learned to keep my tongue out of the way.<br /><br />Yes, my teeth feel great. My gums feel healthy. I'm afraid that I have naturally yellow teeth so I can't say much about the whitening feature but it certainly does make your mouth feel clean and refreshed.<br /><br />I'm still working my way through all the settings to see if I can tell one from the other. My mouth, it's still learning.
  183. This was my first electric toothbrush and I am nothing but impressed. I'd always been very skeptical about shoving a battery-operated, vibrating toothbrush into my mouth and having it produce results better than what I was getting with a regular toothbrush, but I'm sold now. Every time I use this thing I feel like I just walked out of my dentist's office and without all of the poking, prodding and scraping!! It tickled my mouth a little bit at first, but after about a week I was used to it and I could use it comfortably. I really dig the charging station. It's literally charges itself while it just sits in a glass next to your sink. No big, ugly stands or anything like a lot of the older electric toothbrushes that I've seen. This really is the total package. The only thing that even begins to bug me is that the heads cost about $15 a piece, but according to the manual, they should last six months. Time will tell on that one...
  184. I don't know. It seems like it might indeed be a good toothbrush. I love the way it looks, and the travel case is surprisingly nice, with the USB hookup being a great idea for travel. But mine was sent without a glass, with a worn and dog-eared instruction manual, and all the other parts poorly re-packaged in a bashed-up box marked \\"Dental Professional Trial NOT FOR RESALE.\\" What is going on? Is Amazon or Phillips trying to recondition samples sent to dental clinics? Pretty weird experience for a $175 toothbrush.<br /><br />Also, I have an update regarding the comment by the \\"design flaw\\" poster. There actually is a way to select modes without your toothpaste spraying everywhere. You advance to the mode you want, wait a few moments for the mode to register, turn the toothbrush off, put your toothpaste on, and then when you turn the toothbrush back on, it will remain in the pre-selected mode. (I cannot confirm whether, as the poster says in the comments to his/her review, that 10 seconds is then deducted from the brush cycle. I wasn't going to keep the toothbrush, so I didn't make it as far as actually brushing and testing the cycle durations.)<br /><br />Anyway, I'm going to give it three stars for now, then try to replace it. If it turns out to be the toothbrush of my dreams, I'll add stars.<br /><br />UPDATE:<br /><br />I replaced the brush. I was able to get a new one for $130 from my dentist (after rebate, and including tax). I've been using this for four days now. I have to say, each time I brush my teeth they feel like I just got back from the dentist. In fact, about three weeks ago I had my teeth cleaned professionally, and I still had some light stains on my upper teeth. After less than a week of using this brush, the stains are gone. Also, the motion of the brush head feels less violent than the rotary-style toothbrush I had before. It feels like this motion will be easier on my receding gums, although it's too soon to say for sure. In terms of style, the brush is more streamlined and minimalist than my previous toothbrush. Less dorky. The charging glass has a pleasing, stout solidity to it, like a whiskey glass, and it's an ingenious solution to the daily grind of recharging electronics. The travel case is nice too. With my old electric toothbrush, the travel case was so chintzy I immediately threw it away, but this case is nice enough that it looks like something you would buy separately for another twenty or thirty bucks. It has the fit and finish of, say, an eyeglass case. Real design work all around. Anyway, now that I have a proper consumer unit with all the parts, I can cast my lot with the other ecstatic reviewers for this product. This is definitely the best toothbrush I've ever owned. Even if I'd had to pay the full retail price of $210, it would have been worth it.malist than my previous toothbrush. Less dorky. The charging glass has a pleasing, stout solidity to it, like a whiskey glass, and it's an ingenious solution to the daily grind of recharging electronics. The travel case is nice too. With my old electric toothbrush, the travel case was so chintzy I immediately threw it away, but this case is nice enough that it looks like something you would buy separately for another twenty or thirty bucks. It has the fit and finish of, say, an eyeglass case. Real design work all around. Anyway, now that I have a proper consumer unit with all the parts, I can cast my lot with the other ecstatic reviewers for this product. This is definitely the best toothbrush I've ever owned. Even if I'd had to pay the full retail price of $210, it would have been worth it.
  185. I've been using electrical toothbrushes by Philips' competitors for more than 20 years now. After three weeks of using Philips' Sonicare Diamondclean, my teeth feel very clean, are more polished and need less care when flossing. The very small brushhead manages to get around my 4 wisdom theeth very easily and cleans very well in between teeth. And I love the Gum Care setting that gently massages the gums. I find that the brush is easy to handle and like the feel of the material in my hands. The battery seems to last much longer than those used in my previous brushes. The travel set is practical albeit it takes up quite a bit of room in the luggage. In summary, this is the best electrical toothbrush that I have been using in the last 20 years and I would think that it is the best currently on the market. It is worth the investment!   188. My first power toothbrush was a Braun Oral-B and I used it diligently until its battery finally died. Before I replaced it, I asked my dental hygienist who enthusiastically recommended the Phillips Sonicare units. At first, I was skeptical that a handheld so-called \\"sonic\\" unit could compete with a dentist's professional gear. The first time I used the Phillips, I was pleasantly surprised to find that it is almost equal in cleaning power to my dentist's. I get practically the same skull-rattling sensation from this unit that I get when I'm in the chair. My teeth have the same squeaky clean feel they do when I've had them professionally cleaned. I had been using the FlexCare model for the past several years and I decided that I should keep it in my desk at work so I replaced it at home with the new DiamondClean model. While they both have essentially the same engine in them (31,000 strokes per minute), the newly designed brushes seem to do a slightly better job. The redesigned power handle is quite effective too, yielding a sleek-looking object which appears to be less prone to becoming a \\"crud-magnet\\" around its base. The ergonomics are slightly different than the previous versions as this model appears to be somewhat squared off in the hand as opposed to the earlier rounded power units. I especially like the hard fitted carrying case (as compared to the fabric bag affair used on the earlier versions). The ability to recharage the shaver thru a USB port is a great plus as I'm often travelling and find myself short of electrical outlets. If you don't need the USB adapter, a standard 110 (220) plug connects to a power base which allows for induction charging of the unit. It comes with a standard bathroom glass and a flat glass hockey-puck piece, either of which have fitted bases to sit on top of the charging unit. Since the unit is advertised to hold a charge for 42 sessions, I would not be inclined to waste a bathroom electrical outlet in order to keepthe unit on charge constantly. Instead, I'll just pop it onto the charge overnight every week or so. In short, while pricey, I'm thrilled with the unit. And my dental hygienist is always glad to see me because she's starting to clean a set of almost perfectly clean teeth already! One side note: I've been using Phillips (Norelco) shavers and oral products for years and this is the first time I've found one that was not built in the Netherlands. While the country of origin is nowhere marked on the unit itself, small print on the box shows the ubiquitous \\"Made in .....\\" legend.

  196. I LOVE this toothbrush! Was hesitant on shelling out the money but glad I did. The vibration of the toothbrush gave my mouth a strange feeling at first that I wasn't used to, almost like a tickling but after a handful of times I got used to it. You know that feeling of slick clean teeth after leaving the dentists office? That's how my teeth feel every time I brush. The &#34;polish&#34; mode really leaves your teeth feeling slick so less food is able to build up. After 1wk of using 2x a day I noticed a dramatic difference in the tarter buildup of my teeth that regular brushing and flossing wouldn't take care of. The best thing about it is that I got my husband to use it as well and he loves it! It has helped with the overall appearance and I drink coffee ALOT and it has helped with whitening of my teeth. If you or your spouse are thinking about getting one, save some money and buy 1 and share!! It comes with two different sized toothbrush attachment heads. He uses one and I use the other. After I brush my teeth, I pop my brush head off and he attaches his on. It's like two for the price of one!! Ha. We will be ordering replacement heads in a couple of months, DEFinitely recommend!!
  197. I am used to a manual toothbrush and never tried any kind of electric ons in my life until my dentist recommend it to me. Well, from the first try my teeth feels much cleaner. Every time I go to the bathroom I have to check it out of curiosity. As for the price, yes it's a little bit high but worth it.<br /><br />It's just simply Amazing!

  199. Phillips Sonicare is the best thing you do for you teeth. Once you start using it you will wonder how you ever lived without it. Your teeth and gums will be healthier than ever before.

I am so happy that I bought this product and my teeth are sparkling clean and so much more whiter and brighter than they were before.   205. I have owned the flexcare (model below this) for a couple years. the difference between these two models is pretty minor but if you are buying your first quality electric (not the cheapo junk) then this is the best price you will find anywhere.<br /><br />I bought it because I have to travel for work and my wife still wanted one at home, so naturally I got the new one since it can be charged on 110v-220v through a wall or usb in the case or out of the case. It is very versatile and I love it.<br /><br />The design is very appealing but only one major flaw. There is only one button but 5 brush settings, so you have to hit it several times if, like me, you finish brushing, spit, rinse the brush under water and then pulse it to dry it out (knock the water off).<br />This means you have to hit the button 6 times to go on and off one time. Not a deal breaker but an oversight.<br /><br />The hard case is awesome for traveling though.<br />And the charge lasts about 2 weeks. Charge it until it stops itself as the instructions don't mention this.

This is something that was never present on my braun. Consequently, I gotta wash the handle with dish-washing soap once a week to keep it looking pristine.

  212. So, I've been using these toothbrushes for over 3 years now. When they first were introduced I bought one for myself, one for my wife, and one for my parents to share. So in all, I have experience with 2 in my household and second hand experience from my parents. My Father-In-Law also bought one as well and had a similar experience as ours.<br /><br />With that said, this toothbrush is incredible! It cleans better than any electric toothbrush available. I love the different settings and programs it offers. It is also extremely stylish and looks like it is from the future. I have gone to the dentist and been told that there really isn't anything for them to do as I didn't have much to clean at all. The convenience it offers when charging is also incredible as all you do is plop it into the base or put it into the cup and it charges without plugging anything into it. The travel case is also incredible and works perfectly, you just plug in the usb cable and it charges just like how a cell phone would. Overall this toothbrush is everything I was looking for in a toothbrush! With that said, I have to go into detail with the issue we have all had with the Sonicare Diamondclean handles.<br /><br />The battery holds a great charge and is not an issue. The function when it works is excellent! The accessories are great! But there is some fatal flaw in the design of this toothbrush that makes it extremely fragile. Something inside comes &#34;unglued&#34; and the vibration delivered to the brush head is reduced by 90%, but you can feel the mechanism inside the handle vibrating and making strange noises. This will occur if you drop it, EVEN ONCE. I had this happen on my first brush, it slipped out of my hands (As it is a very sleek design) and fell into the sink and it was broken. I contacted Sonicare and was told that dropping it voids the warranty and there was nothing they would do about it as it is considered abuse. The fact that it was dropped from about 1 ft into my sink, ONCE, was not of concern to them. After speaking with several supervisors they sent me a replacement as a one-time customer goodwill. From this point on I was incredibly paranoid using it, gripping the handle until my fingers turned white for fear of dropping it and destroying another one. I also briefed my wife on it as well as my parents, telling them that they better not drop it as it would void the warranty and even a little drop would break it.<br /><br />Things went well for a while, until about 14 months after the replacement, the same issue that occurred after dropping it, was happening again, but I had NEVER dropped it and have actually handled it with such care due to the trauma of my original experience with Sonicare Customer Service. The mechanism had again somehow disengaged partially, reducing the vibration by 90% and making the Sonicare more of a normal toothbrush with a vibrating handle. I contacted Sonicare, and after adamantly denying that I dropped it, they finally authorized a replacement, thank goodness for the 2 year warranty. Mine lasted about 10 more months and it again, had the same issue and had never been dropped. I contacted Sonicare and was told that I was a couple of months past the 2 year warranty and that I was out of luck.<br /><br />Now for my wife's Sonicare Diamondclean, as she experienced the same issue. She never dropped it, and was paranoid after my experience. After about 11 months she had to have hers replaced due the same thing I experienced. Her second one broke after only 8 months so she got a second replacement. It lasted about 9 months and now she is out of warranty and her THIRD Sonicare Diamondclean handle is now also broken, several months out of warranty.<br /><br />My parents also had a similar experience. The first Sonicare Diamondclean handle broke after about 8 months, received replacement. Second handle broke after 10 months, received another replacement. The third one broke after 9months and is now out of warranty.<br /><br />My Father-in-Law also purchased one of these after seeing how awesome it was during the first few months, and I told him he better not drop it. He ended up having the same issue come up and when he tried to redeem the warranty for a replacement, because he did not have the receipt they refused to replace it. Keep in mind, this is when the toothbrush was first released, so the thing hadn't even been out for a year yet. Even so, they refused to give him a replacement without the receipt/proof of purchase and it took me escalating it to darn near the CEO to get his replaced. I calmly explained to them that my Father-In-Law was NOT A TIME TRAVELER and he had not somehow traveled into the future, bought their Sonicare DiamondClean, and then traveled back in time 18 months before release of the DiamondClean. That their product had not even been out for 1 year, let alone 2 years. After this reasoning they replaced it and said that it was a one time exception. Interestingly, it has been working fine since then, going on close to 20 months now, but I suspect it will fail within the next few months, and he is already out of warranty.<br /><br />So there you have it, 4 Sonicare DiamondClean toothbrush sets, 3 of us went through multiple replacements, and all but 1 of them after 2 years are now broken. NONE of those have been dropped, and I can personally vouch for mine and my wife's being drop free. As for my parents, they assure me it was never dropped and that is enough for me. I also know for a fact that my wife and I do not brush our teeth hard and we literally just let the brush head &#34;glide&#34; over the surface of our teeth applying just enough pressure for it to make contact.<br /><br />Overall, the toothbrush is ridiculously awesome, and when it works it is the best thing ever! The fact that I have direct experience with 2 Sonicare Diamondcleana, and another 2 through second hand experience, and all of them break, is unsettling. Also the fact my Father-in-Law got lucky and his replacement is still working after 20 months also shows me it could be a sporadic quality control issue. Either that or my Father-In-Law doesn't brush his tooth as often as us. So either we are all the unluckiest family out there, or there is some design flaw that causes the Sonicare DiamondClean's vibration mechanism to come loose inside the handle.<br /><br />So now I have a bunch of replacement brush heads sitting in my drawer but no toothbrushes that work with them. We have resorted to using a normal manual toothbrush while we figure out what to buy to replace the broken DiamondClean handles, especially since our finances are not in the best place due to medical bills, and lets be honest, the Sonicare Toothbrushes are not cheap. My gosh how horrible it is to not have an electric toothbrush, as it feels like my teeth is not getting even 1/10 as clean as it was getting with the Sonicare. It really makes you miss an electric toothbrush.<br /><br />On a side note, the one warning I have for people who use electric toothbrushes is to be careful brushing a tooth with a crown on it, as I have been told by my dentist that the vibration will break down the cement holding the crown in place causing it to come loose. How did we come upon that subject? because my crown fell out. ;) So careful if you have one.<br /><br />I do hope this review has helped you guys out and helps you make a more informed decision. If you buy this Sonicare Diamondclean, SAVE THE RECEIPT and remember that you will probably have to get at least 1, maybe 2 replacements. If your Sonicare Diamondclean is acting up, even a little and it sounds like the handle is beginning to rattle, get it replaced immediately. I would highly recommend attempting to get it replaced before the 2 years is up, as that way you can at least get almost 3 years of use from the original purchase.<br /><br />Overall, I am giving it 2 stars as thetoothbrush is incredible, the accessories are great, and it works fantastically! I am taking away 3 stars because of the lack of reliability, although Sonicare WILL replace the broken handles IF you have your receipt and it is within the 2 year window. As I said, just realize you are paying for the privilege of using the Sonicare DiamondClean for at least 2 years, anything past that is a bonus. It may not be the original one you bought, but Sonicare will ensure you get a replacement as long as you are within the warranty period. Also, their customer service is not the most friendly and they will try to trick you into admitting fault so they can immediately deny a replacement and void your warranty. They also require a receipt regardless if you registered your product, as I said, they basically accused my Father-in-Law of being a Time Traveler, trying to deny the warranty when the toothbrush had been out for less than a year.<br /><br />So now you know the risks and perils involved with entering into the transaction of obtaining a Sonicare DiamondClean. Farewell and stay vigilant, as it is a great toothbrush, but you are going to have to fight for your right to brush with it...break, is unsettling. Also the fact my Father-in-Law got lucky and his replacement is still working after 20 months also shows me it could be a sporadic quality control issue. Either that or my Father-In-Law doesn't brush his tooth as often as us. So either we are all the unluckiest family out there, or there is some design flaw that causes the Sonicare DiamondClean's vibration mechanism to come loose inside the handle.<br /><br />So now I have a bunch of replacement brush heads sitting in my drawer but no toothbrushes that work with them. We have resorted to using a normal manual toothbrush while we figure out what to buy to replace the broken DiamondClean handles, especially since our finances are not in the best place due to medical bills, and lets be honest, the Sonicare Toothbrushes are not cheap. My gosh how horrible it is to not have an electric toothbrush, as it feels like my teeth is not getting even 1/10 as clean as it was getting with the Sonicare. It really makes you miss an electric toothbrush.<br /><br />On a side note, the one warning I have for people who use electric toothbrushes is to be careful brushing a tooth with a crown on it, as I have been told by my dentist that the vibration will break down the cement holding the crown in place causing it to come loose. How did we come upon that subject? because my crown fell out. ;) So careful if you have one.<br /><br />I do hope this review has helped you guys out and helps you make a more informed decision. If you buy this Sonicare Diamondclean, SAVE THE RECEIPT and remember that you will probably have to get at least 1, maybe 2 replacements. If your Sonicare Diamondclean is acting up, even a little and it sounds like the handle is beginning to rattle, get it replaced immediately. I would highly recommend attempting to get it replaced before the 2 years is up, as that way you can at least get almost 3 years of use from the original purchase.<br /><br />Overall, I am giving it 2 stars as thetoothbrush is incredible, the accessories are great, and it works fantastically! I am taking away 3 stars because of the lack of reliability, although Sonicare WILL replace the broken handles IF you have your receipt and it is within the 2 year window. As I said, just realize you are paying for the privilege of using the Sonicare DiamondClean for at least 2 years, anything past that is a bonus. It may not be the original one you bought, but Sonicare will ensure you get a replacement as long as you are within the warranty period. Also, their customer service is not the most friendly and they will try to trick you into admitting fault so they can immediately deny a replacement and void your warranty. They also require a receipt regardless if you registered your product, as I said, they basically accused my Father-in-Law of being a Time Traveler, trying to deny the warranty when the toothbrush had been out for less than a year.<br /><br />So now you know the risks and perils involved with entering into the transaction of obtaining a Sonicare DiamondClean. Farewell and stay vigilant, as it is a great toothbrush, but you are going to have to fight for your right to brush with it...
  213. My Phillips Sonicare toothbrush worked great for three weeks & then I couldn't use it because I realized the base was not charging & hadn't been charging from the beginng. I now have to charge it in it's travel case. The toothbrush itself I really like & when it's charged, it's great!! But it's very frustrating to purchase something new & it doesn't work.
  214. I've used Sonicare toothbrushes since the original model with the screw-on brush head. While better than a manual brush. I feel like they could be so much better. Sonicare brushes, and this brush is no exception, isn't as good at removing stains as touted, and the implication that it can clean in between teeth because it sends &#34;sonic waves of cleaning&#34; doesn't hold true. You're not getting rid of the floss anytime soon.<br /><br />A few things to know:<br />- It takes more than 12 hours to fully charge the brush when it's depleted. This just seems crazy to me--it should charge overnight and be fully charged for the next use. This problem has been in every Sonicare toothbrush I've used.<br />- It tends lose strength as the battery gets below 50-75%. So it's just not doing as good a job unless it's freshly been charged even though it touts a long time in between charges.<br />- This particular model puts the modes and the power on the same button. If you click the button within 6 seconds of turning the brush on, it will switch between cleaning modes. Since I regularly turn the brush on and run it under water after brushing to clean the brush, if I don't wait the right number of seconds, I have to push the button 5 more times to cycle through the modes to turn the brush off. Older models had separate buttons for power and mode, and I find that design preferable.<br />- The heads that come with this brush don't have interchangeable color rings so it's hard to keep track... is this my brush head or my wife's?<br />- You can use the heads from the Pro Results line as well as far as I can tell. I'm not sure whether there's any substantive difference between the two head types.

  234. I bought this to replace an older E series that I had for a good 8 years. I had an Oral B first, then I bought my wife a Sonicare E series that she didn't like as much as my Oral B, so we switched. I liked the E series way better than the Oral B. The Sonicare just felt like it was doing more by vibrating and the way the movement is different from Oral B, and the result was that my mouth felt cleaner. I was debating between this Diamond Clean or possibly the next stop down or maybe even an Oral B again (Oral B 5000 or 7000, or Sonicare Flexcare). The price of this thing is ridiculous, and the only way for me to justify buying it is because of the sleek look, the glass charger, and the travel-charging case. That's enough for me, I'm easy. After 2 months of use, I'm still happy with my purchase. The Diamond Clean definitely feels more powerful than the E series, but not too overwhelming (by the by I NEVER use any of the other modes although I may try one day). It's a little bit louder than the E series too, but still not as loud as the Oral B 5000 that I bought my wife. One thing that some reviewers had a problem with was only having 1 button versus 2 and having to shuffle through all of the modes before you can turn it off. This is not true at all. Once you turn the brush on and let it run for 5-10 seconds (which is about the amount of time it takes me to clean off after using it), the singular button WILL in fact turn off the brush rather than having to cycle through the other modes. I kept my E series fairly clean by unscrewing and rinsing out after every use, and I still do the same thing here - rip the brush head off and just give it a quick rinse. I'm somewhat of a neat freak with my toothbrush and the Diamond Clean definitely doesn't have as many nooks and crannies for crust to build up in which is a big plus. The only things that I don't like about this toothbrush is that the travel case doesn't work with the covers for the brush heads. Also, I got the black one so if I want to get black heads I'll end up buying them online or at a store I don't like to shop at. But all of that is peanuts to me. It's excessive, too expensive, and the brush heads work on cheaper models - but the other models just don't look this cool.
  235. My daughter recommended this product. She is a dental hygienist. I really think this product does a great job on my teeth.
  236. My wife and I just purchased two DiamondClean toothbrushes. The white model for her, and the black model for me. We discovered that the white model comes with a charging stand that allows you to charge and store your toothbrush in an upright position. The black model only comes with the charging glass. I prefer the charging stand because its more compact and takes up less counter space. I contacted Philips and their support person directed me to their parts site to purchase the charging stand separately for an additional $20 after tax and shipping. He could not tell me why Philips doesn't provide a stand for the black model, he just confirmed that they don't. After all the money spent on this excessively high priced toothbrush, I'm disappointed that Philips wouldn't throw one in for free, so I knocked one star rating off for that.<br /><br />This toothbrush is much more powerful than your average battery powered unit. Your teeth and gums will really feel it. In fact, the instructions say that the unit doesn't reach full power until after 14 days, so that your mouth can get used to it.
  237. I've had a few electric toothbrushes and this is by far the best.<br />Feels strange to begin with as the brush vibrates very fast.<br />Brush heads are a little expensive.
  238. ********************************************<br />See my updates following the original review - the short of it, now two years after purchase I'm still very happy with the DiamondClean toothbrush! Also, some reviewers/users complain about not being able to select the mode without the toothbrush 'spraying all over.' This is NOT an issue if you read the manual and it's very simple to select the mode you want.<br />********************************************<br /><br />The latest update 4/2014 -- am currently using and testing both the [[ASIN:B0086VIA3O Diamond Clean Standard Replacement]] and the InterCare Standard Replacement Brushes. The [[ASIN:B00HMMUD2O InterCare Standard Replacement Brush Heads ]] are very similar to the DiamondClean in type, but they offer deeper cleaning in interdental spaces/gaps than do the standard DiamondClean Brush. Right now I am switching back and forth between these two brushes to see if one works better than the other for me. Although I just started doing my 'trial', I believe that for me, the Intercare brushes may work better.<br /><br />**** ORIGINAL REVIEW ****<br /><br />I upgraded to this unit after my previous SoniCare brush failed to hold a charge after 10 years of use. I was very happy with how using a SoniCare brush improved my gum's health, so for me it was a 'no brainer' and I knew I would replace the old SoniCare with a new one from them.<br /><br />When making my buying decision, I was trying to decide between the DiamondClean and the [[ASIN:B002CVTVVY Philips Sonicare HX6972/10 FlexCare Plus Rechargeable Electric Toothbrush]]. I was interested more in function and practical features than I was in design, or the USB charging capabilities. One of the features of the FlexCare Plus brush that I was very interested in was the UV sanitizing feature. Before making my purchase, I read as many reviews as I could, I visited a local store that carried both the FlexCare Plus and the DiamondCare, and I also asked my periodontist for his recommendation. From my store visit, I was leaning towards the FlexCare Plus model because of the UV cleaning option and the fact that there was a separate On/Off button. My periodontist said that he didn't believe the UV feature would make much difference, and that it would be just as good to periodically soak the brush head in Listerine or similar product. In other words, he said he didn't think it was 'worth paying extra for' the UV sanitizing feature. Instead, he suggested I go with the model I preferred based on price and any other features I wanted.<br /><br />I finally decided on the DiamondClean model based on its having a better performing brush. I have to admit that I was concerned with two things about this model: no On/Off switch, and a smooth surface which I wondered if it would be slippery when wet. Now, after over a month of use, I can report that I am very, very pleased with my decision. First, the cleaning ability of this brush far surpasses the older unit it replaced. Second, the surface is not slippery when wet and it actually feels very comfortable in the hand. Lastly, the issue I was concerned about the most -- not having an On/Off switch and having to cycle through all five settings whenever one uses it -- is a non-issue. As you will see in some of the other online reviews, some users complain that the DiamondCare's lack of an On/Off switch causes as situation such as what this reviewer wrote: \\"You select the mode you want by pressing a *single* button multiple times. So, if you want \\"sensitive\\", you need to put the brush head into your mouth, and press the button five times. You can't do that while looking at the display, because the handle will turn on on the first button press, and splatter the toothpaste all over the place in \\"clean\\" mode, while you're progressing slowly to the mode you actually want. \\"<br /><br />In actual use the DiamondCare is not saddled with the problem if one follows the procedure in the owner'smanual. The way it works is like this: after one choses the mode one wants to use -- by pushing the button to cycle among the various modes (i.e., Sensitive, Whitening, Cleaning, Gum Care) -- the DiamondCare operates in that mode for the completion of the cycle. The next time one uses the brush, simply put your toothpaste on the brush, press the On/Off/function combo button, and the DiamondCare starts up in the same mode you selected last time. If one needs to interrupt your brushing, simply push the function button and the brush remains in 'pause' for 30 seconds. When you push the button again it starts up where it left off in terms of mode and timer.<br /><br />In short, I simply can't believe how clean my mouth feels after each use. My gums are looking great and I'm looking forward to many years of satisfaction from my DiamondCare brush.<br /><br />**** UPDATE -- 4 months after purchase ****<br />After over 4 months of use I am pleased to say that I am still very happy with my SoniCare brush. A full charge lasts for about 3 weeks. I don't keep the unit constantly charging, but instead give it an overnight charge after the status light turns amber for a couple of days.<br /><br />**** UPDATE -- 1 YEAR LATER ****<br /><br />Still very happy with the Sonicare DiamondClean. It is easy to use, clean, and you don't have to worry about getting it moderately wet. Maintains a charge for at least three weeks.<br /><br />*** UPDATE -- 2 YEARS after purchase ****<br /><br />Toothbrush is still working well. I have never used the USB charging feature, but I do like the nice case for travel. Because the case itself can charge the toothbrush with a USB cable, one need not be concerned about how much their toothbrush is charged before a trip. I charge my toothbrush using the included charger base that goes under the also included charging glass, which is where my DiamondClean toothbrush resides between uses. This is nice because it helps protect your brush from beingknocked off the counter or shelf in your bathroom.
  239. This is a very good toothbrush.The two chargers are very handy. The box with the USB charger is convenient upon travelling.<br />The drawback is the cost of the brushes.
  240. Congrats Philips on addressing so many improvements in this great new toothbrush. i had a Philips FlexCare Plus before this and used it for several years until it finally died. i loved it, and this one is even better. All the little improvement touches. Storing it in a glass with an inductive charging system is brilliant...easy access, and frankly i don't really know if the big cleaning device for the FlexCare Plus really worked or just made me feel good. The form factor is so much improved. Lighter, easier to hold. Adding a charging function to the case brings this up to date in a great way. Great job Philips! The best electric toothbrush yet!

Different brush design, teeth feel cleaner, Also, gum cleaning program does a very good job, in addition to the regular cleaning program. New charger very elegant, new travel case also very elegant. Highly recommended.
  242. After owning a Sonicare for years, I decided to upgrade to the Diamond Care based on the great reviews and stunning design. As a piece of art, it doesn't disappoint. As a toothbrush, it doesn't work (literally). Aside from the counter-intuitive design, it just stopped working after 5 months of use (out of warranty, out of luck), but even when it did work it turned out to be a big, frustrating step down from the older model we had been using.<br />The multiple brushing modes are great, but the one-button interface is counter-intuitive and even after months of use I found it hard to predict when it would switch modes or just restart in the same one. If you do find yourself in the wrong mode (which happens often if you're sharing the brush within the family) you can't cycle through the modes with the brush off -- a messy prospect if you've already pasted-up. And, speaking of sharing the brush within your family, unlike the lesser Sonicare models, they don't make color-coded Diamond Care heads, so you're never quite sure if you're using your own.<br />Of course, the biggest disappointment was that the whole damn thing stopped working altogether after just a few months. Our older Sonicare had been working flawlessly for 6 years when I decided to step up to the Diamond Care model. In hindsight, it was a big step down and a lot of money wasted. Still looks great, though...
  243. The design of this toothbrush is second to none and is reminiscent of the minimal, yet beautiful, design of Apple products.<br /><br />Naturally, this toothbrush works extremely well and cleanses teeth easily and expertly. I have found it to be a superior product to brushes offered by Oral B.<br /><br />I travel a lot, so my favourite aspect of this toothbrush is the included travel case which allows the device to be inductively charged by USB, thus negating the need for additional chargers. Battery life is also impeccable, and lasts for well over a week of twice a day 2 - 5 minute brushing sessions.<br /><br />The only downside is that it is a little bit fragile. If dropped on its head, it may break easily (this was my second purchase after the initial toothbrush met its demise from a 50cm fall onto a tile floor).

  255. This is a really ingenious toothbrush. The case doubles as a charger. It can be plugged into a computer via USB or charged via an AC power adapter. The charger is 220V compatible so it is suitable for international travel. The glass is a charger as well ! The toothbrush lights to tell you which mode it's in - clean, white, polish, etc. Despite running on battery, it is very powerful. If this toothbrush was any fancier, it would fly off to remind you it's time to brush. The only downside is the high price. I have to note that I got this one free through the Amazon VINE program. I am not sure that I would have paid the list price on this for a new one. But if you really have to have the best on the market, this is it.
  256. Eleven months after I purchased this item, the vibrational force decreased significantly. I called Philips product support and was told that this loss of power is not uncommon and that as the product was within its one-year warranty, would be replaced within about 10 days. Three weeks later, still not having received the product, I attempted chats with Philips customer-support staff. I chatted with Donna, and Agnelo, both of whom seemed poorly trained. Seemingly no matter what I said, they responded by telling me that someone would contact me within 24 to 48 hours. Then, I called customer support. I was told by supervisor Justina that while Philips has units in stock, the units are reserved for sale and cannot be used as replacement units for defective product under warranty. I asked Justina to contact the physician customer-support group to see whether they could solve my problem and she agreed to call me back the same day (I am a physician). She never called me. When I called her back, she had left for the day. I spoke with a second supervisor, Lisa, who was outright rude to me on the phone. When I explained my problemthat it was taking too long for me to get a replacement toothbrushI explained to Lisa that I am a physician and that if it might result in better service, she could transfer me to the physician customer-support group. She said to me, &#34;I'm happy you're a physician.&#34; In response, I said that the only reason I was mentioning I was a physician is that Philips is a healthcare company that has separate groups for physicians and consumers. I told her that it was snide and inappropriate of her to say that she was &#34;happy&#34; I'm a physician. She claimed that she meant it sincerely. I asked her why she was &#34;happy&#34; with my career choice, and she said it just made her happy. This is atrocious behavior from a company like Philips. Someone at Philips should bring this feedback to the attention of the people I've named herein (assuming the names are real and not aliases), and should overhaul the management and training of the customer-support department. I give three stars to the product for average strength compared with other alternatives at half the price, minus two stars for poor product quality (it died within 11 months) and abysmal customer service. Update 12/22/15: I'm now on my third replacement unit. All three units have failed in what appears to be the same way: the power switch stops working. On this current unit, the power switch failed within three months. Philips continues to have the most poorly trained support group. I'm constantly told that someone will call me within two to four business days, but no one ever returns my calls. I would go with another brand.
  257. I previously owned a number of ultrasonic toothbrushes. This is by far the best. My teeth are dentist clean everyday. I love it. The best part is the gadget factor. Second is the USB travel charger. Brilliant!!! I travel internationally for busniess and carrying one more charger is a total PITA. I love that I can just plug into my computer. The third thing and possibly the best, is the jewelry cleaning aspect. I don't know what made me the think of it - maybe the name. But, I used the smaller head that comes with set to clean my engagement ring and eternity band. Oh my!!! The best cleaning. I have a steam cleaner and an ultrasonic jewelry cleaner. The Diamondclean did the best job. I have no idea if it is safe to clean your jewelry with this toothbrush, but it works. Proceed with caution.
  258. first let me start by saying that i used to love sonicares. i've owned every generation, and until the flexcare generation, each one has served me loyally for years until the batteries were just too old or the buttons would literally wear off.<br /><br />unfortunately, starting with the flexcare generation, while you gain a slimmer handle, a MUCH better removable tip that is much easier to clean or prevent gunk, and more powerful motors, what you lost is reliability. in the two years i had my flexcare, i had to replace it SIX times under warranty. usually it's because the shaft inside would snap, so while the handle would buzz, the tip would no longer vibrate. i also had the battery fail to charge, as well as a weak motor.<br /><br />it was enormously frustrating, but at least customer service would replace the unit each time after 20 minutes with them on chat.<br /><br />with the diamondclean, the handle and tips got even better...when it works... but unfortunately it is breaking just as often, with the same issues as with the flexcare: broken shafts, weak motors, and dead batteries. i purchased the diamondclean on 3/25/12, and am currently on my SIXTH replacement handle (7/22/13). and unfortunately now philips requires you to provide original receipt after the second replacement handle, otherwise they won't send them any more. so even if you registered your purchase with them when you first bought the diamondclean, they suddenly refuse to acknowledge it, adding frustration to an already annoying issue.<br /><br />so after a ton of years of being an incredibly loyal sonicare user, i'm just fed up. even though i have a new replacement handle in the mail to me as i write this, i ordered an oral b toothbrush as well, because i know it's just a matter of time until the sonicare breaks again, and i'm tired of having to deal with them.<br /><br />each time the customer service rep will make it seem like it's your fault that the handle is broken, by asking things like whether you've dropped it or used it to joust with a tyranosaurus. that way they can deny your claim. while i've never done either of those (t-rexes are more scared of manual toothbrushes), i suspect that what is actually causing the issue (other than overly brittle metal shafts, obviously) is having a relatively small jaw. if the head jams up by your jaw/gums/cheek as it's trying to vibrate 30K times per second, either your face, or the shaft, have to give.<br /><br />i guess if you think about it that way, i'm glad that the sonicare keeps breaking... =/

  266. As a Dental Hygienist, I tell my patients daily to get an electric toothbrush and no not necessarily this one. The reasons I recommend an electric toothbrush are, it helps prevent further gum tissue recession, it gets your mouth cleaner, it does the work for you and its just easier. I have heard many of my patients tell me that they like the Oral-B spinbrush the best as comopared to Sonicare. I personally have never used the Oral-B spinbrush. While I do like the diamond clean, I think my next electric toothbrush purchase will be a Oral-B spinbrush. The reasons are because the Oral-B spinbrush covers more surface area of the teeth as compared to Sonicare, its spinning action seems much more gentle than the excessive vibrations of the Sonicare TB. To me the diamond clean is a bit too much, I have to use the sensitive setting and still it can be a little powerful for me. It is super easy to clean though and to recharge, it takes hardly anytime to recharge it maybe an hour or two and its ready to go for another 2 weeks with repeated use.

  277. I received this toothbrush for Christmas, and I'm very impressed with it. I've never owned a sonic toothbrush before, but love my Clarisonic face cleaner so much that I thought I'd try one out! One thing I really appreciated about this model was the \\"Soft Start\\" feature. This makes the toothbrush start softly the first couple of times you use it and ramp up in intensity over the first 14 uses. You can disable this option if you're already used to the feeling of a sonic toothbrush, but since I've only used manual toothbrushes, I really appreciated being able to ease my way in. Also, I LOVE the cup charger. The cup comes off of its metallic charging base, so I just set the cup & toothbrush by my sink and leave the charger in a more inconspicuous area. The toothbrush will indicate when it's time to charge it, so I'll simply move the cup back over to the charger then (this happens about once a week so far). Originally, I thought the USB charger was a silly idea, but USB wall outlets are becoming much more comercially viable, and I even have a few USB outlets on most of my surge protectors, so I could actually see myself using this feature eventually. Altogether, I'm extremely impressed at how much cleaner my teeth are! It's almost completely stopped the plaque build-up I get behind my front bottom teeth, and I'm noticing my teeth are much whiter, too. I find the pulse of the timer when it's time to switch zones is extremely useful at making sure I'm brushing evenly, also. Overall, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this product. Get it! *edit (oops. Just realized I typed \\"tootbrush\\" a couple times)

  286. i recently 'upgraded' to this diamond clean system from the sonicare 'flexcare' system. the overall clean feeling is roughly the same, although the new diamond clean system has a much cleaner design. i do have two issues. first, to toggle between the function, you must press the power button until you reach the desired setting. unfortunately, you'll have to know just how many 'clicks' it takes to get there as there is no why to see which function is illuminated while the brush is in your mouth. of course, you can select toggle between the functions while it's not in your mouth, but then you'll have toothpaste all over your bathroom. the second issue is with the travel case. there is no space for the brush head cover. i don't know about you, but when i travel, i like to keep my toothbrush covered (you never know what housekeeping is spraying in the bathroom). you could always keep it in the closed travel case, but i like to let my brush dry.

  296. Although this is the most expensive personal dental hygiene item that I have ever purchased, I felt the difference after the first use. The same feeling that I usually get after visiting the dental hygenist when I go for my dental cleaning and exam. The built in timer really helps to give all of your teeth the right amount of bruching time. Very satisfied with the puchase on Amazon.com and with the seller of this item.
  297. When it first arrived 5 months ago, everything works fine and it looks cool.<br />Now, I recommend anyone to look for something else.<br /><br />Reasons:<br />- pressing the button to stop, may get you into the different modes instead.   298. I'm currently deployed overseas and had this product was recommended to me by one of our military dentists. I grew up without dental care and thankfully the military has been able to provide me with some much needed maintenance over the years, but I've still struggled with an occasional cavity here and there no matter how often I brushed or flossed. I was a little hesitant to purchase this product once I saw the price and I was concerned about it being able to be shipped to my current location BUT it arrived here in 10 days and I think I'm in love! This toothbrush was without a doubt worth every penny, I never thought I'd ever be this excited about brushing my teeth or find myself writing a product review for a toothbrush! My point is, this product works. My teeth have never felt cleaner and after a week I can already see a difference. Although this product isn't perfect -- *you have to switch through every setting to actually turn it off/no UV cleaning kit*-- I would still highly recommend this to friends,family, and other Amazon members.

I dont know that any of the other modes are even worth having. Id rather have just one mode. The travel case and USB charger make traveling with this super convenient and easy. This pretty little toothbrush does the most amazing job cleaning AND whitening teeth! My smile was noticeably brighter/whiter after only 1-2 weeks of daily use and it feels like I got a professional cleaning after each use. Highly, highly recommend!

This brush does a great job and leaves my mouth feeling truly clean.<br />The only downside I've found with this new design is that the handle seems to be too slick. I've had it slip out of my hands while brushing my teeth on two separate occasions so far.<br />If they could fix that, this toothbrush would be perfect.<br />All in all, I love using a Sonicare toothbrush and I cannot see myself going back to using a regular manual toothbrush.

  307. I wanted to tell you that my poor old Sonicare electric toothbrush has lasted at least THIRTY-FIVE years...it was sold to me by my dentist when they first came onto the market! I have used it daily for all these years (I'm 83 years old!) and it started to become very noisy lately. I just found the problem, and thought I'd share it...the outer body has cracked from the small rectangular hole in the threads at the top of the main body, so of course the vibration noise has increased. Now I will have to replace it, but I think you might be pleased to know it has lasted so long!
  308. I bought this to replace a dying Braun/Oral-B electric toothbrush, the kind with a round head. Possibly the Advanced Power.<br /><br />It does get my teeth very clean, and I like the charging tumbler and travel case. The tumbler glass is very thick, it's very easy to charge, and the interval alerts are helpful. But I ended up giving it to my sister and reordering one like my old one.<br />If you have a small mouth, you may find brushes with a smaller head than this easier.<br />I have a small narrow mouth and found it hard to reach upper tongue side without clacking the brush stem into my front teeth. I've chipped my front teeth more than once (not on plastic), and worried the vibrating clack would chip them.<br />I have always been a sloppy brusher before I got my Braun (small mouth, overactive salivary glands -- aren't you glad to know this?), and using the Sonicare was a return to my sloppy days. I also found it hard to keep the spray inside my mouth -- this was never a problem with the Braun.<br />The sloppiness may have been why it always seemed like I'd run out of toothpaste froth with this one before I was done. I tried squeezing toothpaste into the brush (not just onto) but it didn't help. Never a problem with the Braun/Oral-B.<br />This has a few modes that are varying lengths of time. I tried two of them, the regular one and whitening. It shuts off at the end of the mode. I was used to how the Braun continues after the 2-min alert, then I'd brush my tongue then shut it off. I ended up using the whitening setting on this to get another 30 secs of power for tongue work, though I'd shut it off after 5 secs.<br />I'm so glad my sister had mentioned she was going to replace her dying Sonicare. Now she has a new one (pink!) that she knows she loves, and I have one like my old BraunOral-B on its way.<br />I liked the packaging on this. Almost entirely recyclable, not overly packaged, and IIRC, didn't require scissors or Band-aids.<br />Excellent cleaning, but not the brush for me.

The vibrations are lot softer now - clean mode is like sensitive mode and with the sensitive mode almost nothing happens. Plus, it's making a constant noise, and I have to charge it every few days instead of every other week initially.<br /><br />I wouldn't have put this review for just one isolated incident, but unfortunately my husband's toothbrush deteriorated in the same way after about the same time. This makes me believe that the toothbrush is designed to last a little more than a year (warranty time), which is highly unreasonable for such a high cost. I still like to use a Sonicare toothbrush for brushing, but I will stick to the cheaper versions to buy them every year or so.
