  330. Tuesday, 7/16/2013 - I went to the dentist for a cleaning and was told that I have to floss more because my gums bleed severely when they're doing the cleaning. I'd like to tell them &#34;That's because you're stabbing me with the picks, idiot!&#34; but I just smile and nod. They indicate that if I don't change the overall health of my gums, they'll want to do more frequent visits with some sort of gum care routine. As you know, dentist visits are expensive and I have NO plans in going there any more frequently than the standard every six months. To give you an idea of my oral care habits, I brush at least 3 times a day with a Pulsar battery-powered tooth brush, rinse with CloSYS daily, Listerine Zero on occasion and floss when I feel the need/have the time.<br /><br />Sunday, 7/21/2013 - I do a little research to see what I can do to improve my oral health. Yes, I will try flossing more but I think, &#34;Hmm, I wonder if a better toothbrush that massages my gums better would help...&#34; So I start looking at the top rated/most featured electric toothbrushes. Far and away, this one had STELLAR ratings. Wireless charging was a smart/cool idea that honestly attracted me the most. So I added it to my cart and waited.<br /><br />Tuesday, 7/23/2013 - I receive the DiamondClean and unbox it. It comes out of the box with a charge (helpful so you can get started right away) and immediately notice the quality of the pieces. Everything is smooth and designed well, also feels sturdy in the hand (not plastic-y). I pop on the full-sized head and use the &#34;CLEAN&#34; option of the 5 choices on the brush. 2 minutes later, my teeth feel as smooth as glass. Mind you, I had a dentist appoint exactly a WEEK ago so there shouldn't be any real build-up. But this blasted away whatever was there and my teeth are slippery-smooth. Definitely feels cleaner, that's for sure. I purchased 3 replacement DiamondClean heads as well so I'm covered for the year since you're supposed to replace the heads approximately every 3 months.<br /><br />PROS:<br />-Designed beautifully<br />-AMAZING clean! This is my first SonicCare so maybe others can do a similar job but my readings say this model is up towards the top.<br />-Wireless charging is handy<br />-Travel case is sturdy<br /><br />CONS:<br />-Short USB cable included and what seems like an oversized AC-to-USB converter. Though it's mostly used for travel so no real problem.<br />-Brush head seems small but that's probably just because I'm coming from a full size brush.<br /><br />OVERALL:<br />It's a premium product and that comes at a price. I personally think the price is worth it and HIGHLY recommend you consider this.osed to replace the heads approximately every 3 months.<br /><br />PROS:<br />-Designed beautifully<br />-AMAZING clean! This is my first SonicCare so maybe others can do a similar job but my readings say this model is up towards the top.<br />-Wireless charging is handy<br />-Travel case is sturdy<br /><br />CONS:<br />-Short USB cable included and what seems like an oversized AC-to-USB converter. Charging with the USb option is also handy sometimes.<br />- It recharges to full battery pretty quickly, I just leave it on for a day to be on the safe side<br />- I can feel the difference on how it cleans my teeth compared to high-end manual brushes and low-end electronic brushes (I have not had the OralB experience)<br />- It is pricey, but in the long run you only need to replace the brush head (and it comes with two). It's an investment.<br /><br />Cons<br />- There is no way to tell how the battery life is doing. When it's low on battery you only know because it just stops!!! and obviously it's not ideal to go charge it for a little while when you're in a rush just to have some charge to be able to use it!!<br />- There are many hi-tech ways to recharge it, including this one way of putting it in this glass cup they provide, but it is a bit confusing to master. Better yet, they stay feeling clean for hours after using. The diamond brush head is small and so gets to the back teeth and backs of teeth easily. My gums look healthier too.<br /><br />I didn't find that it took long to adjust to the vibration at all but there is a sensitive setting to help you get used to it. (My husband complained that it rattled his teeth at first, I didn't have that sensation, only a slight tickling of the gums for the first couple of days).<br /><br />The included travel case with built in charger works well and even lets you plug it into a USB port on a laptop to charge if you choose. (It can also plug into a standard 110 outlet). It will hold two brush heads for travel, but you could include heads for the whole family in ziploc bags if needed.
  370. Best ever. Feels like I have had my teeth cleaned every time I use it. Expensive, but well worth the money. Dental hygienist said to change heads every 2-3 months. I will never be without a Sonicare toothbrush. I purchased a cheap imitation once and it was not even close to the quality or value.
  371. I have been using this toothbrush for one and a half years and I loved it. It cleans my teeth better than any other manual/electric toothbrush I have ever used.   379. I have used the ORAL-B units for at least 15 years and was pretty satisfied with them (each lasted about 5 years), though I did find that sometimes there was still some food at my gum line when finished. I have very tight teeth, to the point that I have had dental floss break and get lodged between the teeth (very uncomfortable and one time I needed my desist to remove it). My current Oral-B is getting to the point that the battery is giving up so it was time for a new one so I did an extensive search and comparison and decided on the Sonicare DiamondClean for this purchase. The price kind of made me shutter, but the reviews made me look past that and go for what the brush can do for my teeth. With a 90-day return policy I feel that they trust their product, and if it isn't what I hope for I am not stuck with an expensive unit.<br /><br />I was blessed with very straight, white teeth, but with the whiteness came soft enamel and despite taking great care of my teeth i have had many cavities and now crowns..... I brush, I floss, I get cleanings to keep my teeth in as good a shape as possible. I am concerned about my gums as I get older and from what I read the Sonicare is superior for preventing gum disease. So I will give it a whirl and update my review within 90 days. I am hoping for my teeth's sake it will be a 5-star review.<br /><br />UPDATE: I have been using this toothbrush for almost a month and I am astonished at the difference in my teeth! The first week or so my gums were a bit sensitive, but that went away rather quickly. I had a bit of tarter on my lower teeth (I am due for a cleaning) and it is nearly gone! I have been using the whitening setting, which may be the key. My teeth also feel cleaner than they ever have, and I would not have believed that possible.<br /><br />From someone who was a bit skeptical making the change to the Sonicare I can say that I highly recommend it as the better product on the market. Surely worth the investmentwhen you consider how much dental work costs!

Unhappy to the point of receding. I kept using it, not quite able to believe the toothbrush was at fault. The Flexcare does have different settings but they aren't very different. And they all are too harsh for me. My son, who is 23, however loves his.<br /><br />I was at the store a few days ago and say a display that included both brushes.<br />As I handled them I realized that there is a very distinct difference in how aggressive they vibrate. I much prefer the gentler Diamond brush and bought another one.<br />I do wish they would make it clear that the different brushes feel different and act differently. My hope now is that my gums will get happier now that I have my new Diamond brush.<br />I highly recommend it!

  449. As one of a fairly significant number of folks who are susceptible to gagging when brushing their teeth, I had pretty high hopes that this toothbrush might be an ideal solution for me. First, it offers a very compact brushing head which truly is the perfect size for someone like me with a small mouth and a susceptibility to gagging when brushing my teeth. I was also attracted to the fact that it is more effective in removing plague, which should mean that it has to be in my mouth for a shorter period of time. When I actually received the product, I was really delighted by what was promoted as a feature to &#34;ease in&#34; to the vibration by starting at a lower level and then slowly increasing over the course of 14 days. So first, the compact brush head is AWESOME! It is perfect - exactly the size for those of us with a sensitivity to gagging. I found it worked wonderfully on the outer side of my teeth. Unfortunately, when it came to brushing the back side of my teeth, I found that the intensity of the vibration provoked the gagging reflex in my mouth. I tried to use the so-called &#34;ease-in&#34; function multiple times, but it did not work as described in the instructions so I just gave up and reached for my old electric brush to do the back side of my teeth. I did notice that the awesome compact heads will fit other Philips toothbrushes so that may be a solution. But I would encourage the Philips product developers to find a way to accomplish the same effect with less &#34;tickling&#34; vibration. In the meantime, please, please, please keep making those awesome small compact heads!
  450. Ok, maybe it does look a little bit like an Apple design.   461. I generally like this toothbrush. It has lots of features and a clever charging station design. My only complaint--and it's minor--is that it's not intuitive to switch between functions (cleaning, polishing, sensitive, etc.). If you have toothpaste on your brush, and you want to toggle to your preferred setting, the toothpaste will fly off as you find your preferred setting--and when the brush is in your mouth, you can't easily see what setting you're on. So you have to choose the setting well before you put the paste on your brush. Might not be a problem for some, but there should be a more intuitive way to choose your default setting instead of hitting a combination of buttons to set it.

  468. Let's just get this out of the way right up front: this latest incarnation of the Philips Sonicare toothbrush is quite pricey. And, yes, you are probably paying a fair percentage of that price towards the unit's stylistic design. But this latest model comes with a number of nice accessories that work with the brush to make you understand the higher price for the unit, and therefore, possibly make it a good choice if you are looking for a new toothbrush.<br /><br />The toothbrush itself is gorgeous. It stands apart from all Philip's previous designs (and yes, I've used virtually every one of them over the years) due to its \\"high-tech\\" visual appearance. Gone, for example, are the yucky gaps on the front control panel that, over time, collect toothpaste, water buildup, and so on, and become impossible to clean and unpleasant to look at. This new model has more of a uni-body shell that contains a gap only around the power button itself. The texture of the white finish (you can also purchase the toothbrush in all black, by the way) feels somewhat like unglazed ceramic: it not only looks wonderful, but it feels great in the hand.<br /><br />Operation is quite similar to all the previous Philips models, with available \\"cleaning,\\" \\"gum health,\\" \\"whitening,\\" etc. modes. A nice touch is the default initial setting that, over the course of the first 14 operations, slowly ramps up the power to acclimate those who have never used this type of brush in developing a comfort with the high frequency vibration feeling (this ramp-up in vibration power can be disabled, as well; check the manual for the two-step process to do so). A stronger, sequenced vibration while brushing alerts you to switch to the next quarter of your mouth so that you will get equal coverage for all teeth during each brushing session. The battery is listed as a three week duration, assuming normal use. My previous Sonicare brushes generally lasted this same length, and this model has proved.<br /><br />The device comes with a number of very snazzy accessories. First, a wide-mouthed, heavy glass cup (yes, it is actually made of glass, not plastic) sits on top of the charging base. You simply place your toothbrush into the glass for charging. When not charging, the glass cup can sit on the counter and continue to serve as a decorative toothbrush holder. (The charger, by the way, is universal voltage, so it can be used in Europe, as well as North America.) This is one of the most obvious fancy item on the accessories list, but it does not stop there.<br /><br />There is also an acrylic stand which can also be placed on top of the charger, in case you prefer not to use the glass cup. And the supplied case is much more exotic than we've seen before with other electric toothbrushes. On the end of the case is a USB port, and inside, a induction charging panel. Yes, you guessed it: during travel, you can place the toothbrush into the case, close the case, and then plug it into an USB port, and the toothbrush will charge while sitting in the case! Nice touch. And, a supplied USB adapter that plugs into the AC socket (the adapter is also universal voltage, so it works both in North America and Europe, and is much smaller and lighter than the main charger) can also be used to charge the toothbrush while it is in the case (and the USB adapter is supplied, along with a USB cable, in addition to a normal a/c charger. Finally, two different types of heads are provided to get you started (each head lasts approximately six months).<br /><br />So, this is a very gorgeous and somewhat unusual toothbrush, and it has won at least two separate design awards. Once you look it over in person, you'll see why. I've used both the Braun and Philips types for years, but I have to say this Philips model is the best one I've used yet. Get it when there is a coupon or sale available, and that will help with the price. Five stars.<br /><br />Pluses:<br />+ Beautiful design<br />+ Gapless brush head design (except for power button) greatly reduces chances for build-up over time<br />+ USB and a/c charging (convertors and cables are provided for each)<br />+ a/c charging is universal voltage (110-240V), so you can use it in Europe<br />+ USB charging can be accomplished either by using supplied plug-in USB a/c convertor or by plugging USB cable into a computer's USB port<br />+ Travel case has built-in USB port so charging can occur while brush is sitting inside travel case<br />+ Ceramic-like finish to brush handle<br />+ Power button has a deeply curved design that is easy to use (no fumbling with finding and properly pressing a button to get the brush to turn off)<br />+ Three-week use period before charging is needed<br />+ Lovely glass cup holder adds a touch of class (and functionality) to a mundane device<br />+ Secondary acrylic stand if the cup is being washed (it is top dishwater safe), or is not your \\"cup of tea\\"<br />+ Available in white and black<br />+ Light appears when charging necessary<br />+ Options backlighting done via LED, making display very bright, but also using less electricity<br />+ Gorgeous travel case that doubles as an in-case charger when connected to the USB cable<br />+ Handles a wide range of Philips brush heads, including the diamond clean, sensitive, deep clean, and other models<br />+ Long two-year warranty, and if you register the toothbrush online, the warranty is extended to two and one-half years (!)<br /><br />Minuses<br />- Pricey (buy it when it goes on sale, or find a Philips coupon)<br />- Handle is ALMOST totally gapless: a gap appears around the power button (but all the other troublesome gaps from previous models are now gone)<br />- Some body squeaking at certain angles and pressures (caused by the high frequency vibration that these devices use, but this could be improved)<br />- Battery level light appears only when you need to recharge, so you can't tell how soon that time will be coming up (i.e., no three-light power level indicator)<br />- Travel case, while lovely, doesn't appear that it will stand up well to cleaning, due to its heavily textured outer case (but will only know this over time)<br /><br />Note:<br />If you register the device online, Philips will supply you with an extra six months of warranty, adding up to two and a half years. Not bad!build-up over time + USB and a/c charging (convertors and cables are provided for each) + a/c charging is universal voltage (110-240V), so you can use it in Europe + USB charging can be accomplished either by using supplied plug-in USB a/c convertor or by plugging USB cable into a computer's USB port + Travel case has built-in USB port so charging can occur while brush is sitting inside travel case + Ceramic-like finish to brush handle + Power button has a deeply curved design that is easy to use (no fumbling with finding and properly pressing a button to get the brush to turn off) + Three-week use period before charging is needed + Lovely glass cup holder adds a touch of class (and functionality) to a mundane device + Secondary acrylic stand if the cup is being washed (it is top dishwater safe), or is not your \\"cup of tea\\" + Available in white and black + Light appears when charging necessary + Options backlighting done via LED, making display very bright, but also using less electricity + Gorgeous travel case that doubles as an in-case charger when connected to the USB cable + Handles a wide range of Philips brush heads, including the diamond clean, sensitive, deep clean, and other models + Long two-year warranty, and if you register the toothbrush online, the warranty is extended to two and one-half years (!) Minuses - Pricey (buy it when it goes on sale, or find a Philips coupon) - Handle is ALMOST totally gapless: a gap appears around the power button (but all the other troublesome gaps from previous models are now gone) - Some body squeaking at certain angles and pressures (caused by the high frequency vibration that these devices use, but this could be improved) - Battery level light appears only when you need to recharge, so you can't tell how soon that time will be coming up (i.e., no three-light power level indicator) - Travel case, while lovely, doesn't appear that it will stand up well to cleaning, due to its heavily textured outer case (but will only know this over time) Note: If you register the device online, Philips will supply you with an extra six months of warranty, adding up to two and a half years. Not bad!
  469. The cleanest my teeth have ever been. The materials and construction of the toothbrush are of high quality. The unique ultra-sonic pulses are superior to the conventional toothbrush and the rotadent, another mechanical toothbrush I have used.<br /><br />The toothbrush does cost a lot but it's worth it. You can't get this much quality for a lower price. Everything from the charging station, to the toothbrush, to the bristle head are sturdy, powerful, and well constructed.<br /><br />It surprised me that the automatic timer is set for merely 2 minutes. I used to brush for 5 minutes with the rotadent. But let me tell you, 2 minutes is enough and your teeth will feel completely clean. It does an amazing job of removing plaque and stains. After a few weeks of use, both myself and my girlfriend noticed that our teeth were whiter.<br /><br />All I can say is I'm so happy that I purchased this toothbrush. It does the best job and feels great to use.
  470. Saw a difference in less than a week!!
  471. Have had this for about a month now and I love it! The small head makes it easy to clean teeth in the back of your mouth.   473. First of all I never write reviews until now. I really wanted to warn anyone that have to deal with Philips warranty.<br /><br />Please understand the product is great unless it breaks. I love the product until after 8 months the handle will not charge anymore and hence the toothbrush will not turn on. I have to admit, it is somewhat upsetting that a toothbrush for roughly 200.00 bucks would last only 8 months but either way the handle was in warranty.<br /><br />When I called the warranty personnel, she was really fast and gave me a reference number for my replacement handle and instruct me to call back within 2-3 business days to receive my tracking number. She also mentioned the delivery time would be 7-10 business days from today (the day I am talking to her).<br /><br />Again, I love the product until it breaks which makes perfect sense to anyone that loves their product. Therefore within 2 business days, I chatted with the customer service regarding my order and they mentioned that there is no tracking number or anything and decided to mention to me that the item is not in stock, also please check in 2 business days. Ok, no problem.<br /><br />2 business days later from the chat date, the next agent mentioned the item is in stock and no tracking number yet. They also mentioned that it will take 7-10 business days from when I first called. Finally, they mentioned to check back again in 2 business day. Ok, no problem.<br /><br />Anyways, the cycle continues until today. Today is the 10 business day and I decided to see what is going on. Of course! I receive the same answer as before but this time I wanted to talk to a supervisor. the supervisor gave me no tracking number which was suppose to be given to me 7-8 business days back and mentioned to follow back on Monday when the updated shipping detail will be available. I mentioned that I know it is not his responsibility but would like a shipping contact to see where the shipping is. Of course, no response.<br /><br />Please be aware of Philips warranty; it stinks! I wish I could say that you will get a truthful answer if you ever talk to them but I would be lying to you.<br /><br />5 stars for the product when it works<br />1 star for the longevity of the product (should be longer because you spend 200.00 -&#62; also surprised the agent first time I called that this expensive item was deflective)<br />negative max stars for warranty -&#62; when you spend a decent amount on the item, you would assume there is an honest answer of when you would receive your replacement item under warrant. But expect longer than the promised 7 - 10 business days.

The settings are mostly to set an internal timer for it to turn off.)<br />-Slender, elegant design.<br />-Cool recharging station (it recharges by inductive charging)<br /><br />Cons:<br />Expensive.<br /><br />Other Comments:<br />Most brush heads you buy come with a ring that fits between the brush head and the toothbrush.   542. I was skeptical. Really, the idea of spending this kind of cash on a toothbrush seemed absolutely ludicrous to me up until a few weeks ago.<br /><br />I don't like going to the dentist. Aside from Bill Murray, I'm not sure many of us do. But, I dragged myself to that devil-spawns office last week and was informed I had some fillings that were needed. I was also encouraged to fork out the dough for this toothbrush, which he tried to sell me there. I opted not to, but decided to buy it later after reading the reviews.<br /><br />There is no way I can properly put into words how much better this thing is than a &#34;regular&#34; toothbrush. To put it simply, my mouth has never in my life felt this clean, and I will never, ever go back to normal tooth brushes again.<br /><br />This will not be a purchase you regret.

  546. This is the best (and by far the most expensive) toothbrush I've ever owned.<br /><br />Pros:<br /><br />- Powerful<br />- Many cleaning modes<br />- Awesome rinse glass / charger<br />- Great carrying case which doubles as a travel charger<br />- Long battery life<br /><br />I love the glass charging solution. It's great to be able to just drop the brush in the glass and know it'll be charging perfectly.<br /><br />The battery lasts so long that I've taken two-week trips abroad and not once found the need to plug the carrying case in to charge the toothbrush.<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />- The elegant one-button design really isn't the best user interface<br />- Expensive<br />- Wish the charge cable would fit in the case as the case feels overly large<br /><br />The issue with the one-button design is that you have to select the cleaning mode while it's turned on, and if you've ever turned on a sonic toothbrush while it's primed and outside your mouth, you'll know that's a bad idea. So to pick a mode you have to have the brush in your mouth and try to focus your vision on the display which is just inches from your eyes, while pressing the button to select the next mode.<br /><br />The travel case is very convenient, but it does feel larger than it needs to be, I'm sure they could find a way to fit the cargo cable within the case, even if it was a shorter cable.<br /><br />In all the pros outweigh the cons by a large margin. This is a fantastic toothbrush and if you've never used a sonic toothbrush you're in for a real treat.
  547. This is my second Sonicare my first didn't make 6 months before it died, I am happy to say this one is now over a year old and still takes and holds a charge like new, I think they improved the technology so now they don't over charge where the earlier models may have. These are not cheap but the results speak for themselves. My dentist as well as other dentist I know all highly recommend these and the reason I got another was my dentist told me he saw a major change with me using it for just 3 weeks in tooth and gum health.
  548. Sure, paying nearly $200 for a toothbrush seems a little ridiculous, and maybe it is. But in all honesty, I have lived this toothbrush. The extras make a difference. For example, the wireless charging. Just set the brush in the cup when you're done brushing and it charges. It's that easy. You don't have to line it up any special way to make it work. The travel case has come in handy several times as well. It protects the toothbrush and is an easy way to charge it on the go, of you even need to. The battery seems to last a really long time, so I don't usually even take the charging cable with me when I travel. It hasn't died on me yet. The different settings are also a nice touch. I also like that it times your brushing and lets you know when to switch to the next section of your mouth. I have enjoyed this toothbrush, and my dentist seems to think it was a good choice.

  559. Wow, this product is great.<br />First let me tell you I never used an electric toothbrush before... so I decided to give it a try when I saw this product available. I always heard wonders about Philips electric toothbrushes, and I know they have been around for years... but I never imagined myself using one.<br /><br />Now I'm sold.<br /><br />This toothbrush has the most wonderful feeling in the mouth and the teeth get REALLY clean. In my case I did not feel any bleeding or sensitivity.<br /><br />This Diamondclean comes with two heads and a great travel set. It is easy to assemble, easy to use... and you can even charge the toothbrush via the USB port on your computer (brilliant!). The pressets are easy to understand and the whole product has a quality that is hard to beat. And on top of it the system looks robust enough - meaning it does not look like it's gonna break three months from now. I simply cannot see a flaw on this product. Congratulations Philips: you converted a skeptic.<br /><br />RECOMMENDED!!
  560. I have to admit that my teeth have never been as clean since I began using this brush a few weeks ago. I have always brushed and flossed twice a day, but I have still gotten cavities in all the common places--between teeth and in the harder-to-reach areas of my mouth. In addition, I get tartar buildup behind my front teeth, both on the top and bottom. It is just a fact that brushing these areas with a regular toothbrush is not very easy. However, this amazing toothbrush makes it possible to brush your entire mouth with the same effective motion. It is effortless, and it only takes 2 minutes. The built-in timer that tells you when to brush another area of your mouth is GREAT. You divide the brushing into 4 parts: front of bottom teeth, back of bottom teeth, front of top teeth, and back of top teeth. When the timer indicates via a faint beep and a brief interruption of the brush, then you move to the next quadrant of your mouth. To summarize my thoughts, here are the positive and negative points about the brush:<br /><br />POSITIVE<br /><br />1. Amazing Clean: My mouth just feels cleaner after two minutes of using this brush. I think the feeling comes from the gentle vibration of the toothbrush, which stimulates your gums as you are brushing. In addition, I know my mouth is cleaner because I could not possibly brush this vigorously in tough-to-reach places with a regular brush.<br /><br />2. Long Battery Life: Even with 2 brushing cycles per day, I only charge the brush about once every two weeks. I plug it in to charge when I go to bed, and I unplug it when I get up the next day.<br /><br />3. USB Charging/Storage Case: This is a pretty amazing creation. You simply put the brush and heads into the case, attach the supplied cord to the case, and plug it into the wall or a computer (yes, a computer). The toothbrush magically charges in the case, even though nothing is plugged into the toothbrush.<br /><br />4. Easy to Handle: The brush has a nice feel in your hand. It is easy to hold, even when it is vibrating. I have never dropped mine.<br /><br />5. Simple to Use: I never actually read the instruction manual. The brush comes with a \\"Quick Start\\" card that is the super-short version of the instructions. I have never needed to look at the lengthy instructions.<br /><br />NEGATIVE OR QUESTIONABLE<br /><br />1. Availability & Cost of Replacement Brushes: I believe it is recommended that you change the brush every 3 months. I have not used mine that long, but I have looked at the cost of replacement brushes--currently 3 for $38 on Amazon. This is certainly no bargain. I have seen Philips replacement brushes at Sam's Club, but not for the Diamondclean model. Maybe they will get them in the future. In the meantime, this toothbrush could cost you over $50/year if you replace the brush every 3 months. That is about $50 more than a regular toothbrush.<br /><br />2. Many Different Modes: The first mode is \\"Clean\\". It is the only one that I have ever used. I have my doubts as to whether a different method of brushing could actually make my teeth whiter or more polished. Therefore, I have never even tried those modes. They seem a little gimmicky.<br /><br />3. USB Glass Charger: The concept of putting your toothbrush in a glass to charge it is neat, but I haven't seen the real advantage to this over the USB Charging/Storage Case. For me, this is a once-every-two-week activity, and I don't plan to keep the toothbrush on the counter sitting in a glass.<br /><br />4. Funny/Concerning Instructions: Given the price, I hope to use this toothbrush for many years. However, in the instructions, Philips shows you what to do with the toothbrush before you throw it away (throw it away?!?). You simply cover it with a soft cloth (pictured in instructions), whack it with a hammer, remove the rechargeable battery, and then throw the smashed toothbrush in the trash. GREAT! I hope I won't be doing this anytime soon. My lastmicrowave lasted only about 6 years. I better get no less than that from this toothbrush, which cost me more than a new microwave.than a new microwave.
  561. After the first time you use it, which is creepy if you don't already use an electric toothbrush, it quickly becomes the best thing since sliced bread!<br /><br />It has multiple modes (although I only use the basic one) but does a great job. If you are a heavy brusher this will help you go easy on your gums. My dentist even complemented the results. The only down side is that replacement heads are VERY spendy.<br /><br />Comes with travel kit and a few charging options which work a little bit like magic.
  562. I really wanted to give this toothbrush 5 stars, but I just couldn't. It's not a bad device by any means but it's partly a step backwards from the Flexcare+ model and is it really worth the price?<br /><br />Let me start off by saying this is the 4th Sonicare Toothbrush I've owned. I had the Essence, than the Flexcare, than the Flexcare+ and now the DiamondClean.<br /><br />If you have the Flexcare or the Flexcare+ do you really need to upgrade to this model? Probably not, Sonicare's own website states you get a 44% better clean using the new DiamondClean heads, so the handle obviously makes no difference.<br /><br />Don't get me wrong the new handle is very cool, slick design, even slicker charging options, but did Sonicare have to remove features to do this? For instance:<br /><br />The battery icon is now 1 solid icon rather than 3 different slices, now you can't tell when the battery is getting low.<br /><br />The button to change modes was removed, now there is one button for power and mode changing, this means unless you want to splatter toothpaste all over your mirror you need to change the mode in your mouth while trying to squint at the brush to see what mode it's on.<br /><br />Why was the UV cleaner removed? Ok, I really didn't use this often but it was cool to know I had it.<br /><br />This toothbrush is very expensive, and your basically paying for the cool charging technology, and the absurdly overpriced new brush heads. Currently a pack of 3 runs almost $35. In contrast a pack of 7 ProResults can be had at a big name Warehouse store for around $40.<br /><br />Also while putting your toothbrush in the cup for charging is cool, is that really practical? If anything it's going to start making the bottom of the handle sort of gross, how many germs collect in that cup overnight unless you clean it every day.<br /><br />So in conclusion, cool charging technology does not take the place of convenience features.
  563. Wow! My teeth have never been cleaner. And they were whiter after the first brushing. It's a little pricey, but when you figure how much whitening at your dentist's office would cost.... this is a good deal.

Each of them performed great and lasted about 7-8 years before the battery finally started to fail. I've been using Diamond Clean for about 6 weeks now and I'm extremely happy with it. I'm not exactly sure why it seems to perform so much better than my prior Sonicare but I'm guessing its primarily due to new brush head design.   568. This is probably my 4th or 5th Sonicare in over a decade. I'm been using them since they came out before Philips bought the original company. I don't think I've ever had one go bad. They've all been rock solid. I've only bought new units when Philips had made some substantial changes. The one I'm replacing has been going strong for about 3 years now and I just happened to see that they have this no Diamondclean model. First off. The newer style heads are a blessing. All the models I've had before had though drop in a cavity and twist lock design. Toothpaste and water always managed to get in over time and it was an annoyance to clear. These newer style look light they won't have any of that problem. This is also my first Sonicare with more than two modes. I don't know that they really have a different brushing style but the ability to have a mode with a different time is nice so that I can brush longer without the brush going off and having to turn it on again. That was always just a minor inconvenience. What does seem to be annoying is that you can't \\"lock\\" the toothbrush into a specific mode. You can turn off an off the \\"ramp-up\\" mode, cycle through the different modes, but you can't leave it in a specific mode. You have to CYCLE through a long list to get to what you want each and every time you start the brush. I read through the manual, read the Philips FAQ, and even spoke with a CSR at Philips and nope. That just seems silly since I would figure most people are going to use one or maybe two modes so to have it start at a different position in the list would seem a no brainer but Philips didn't do it. What is interesting is that the CSR said other (older) models do. But not the newest, most expensive, and most featured Diamondclean. Weard. The charging glass is very nice and WELL built. They also state you can use it for rinsing your mouth. That's nice. For charging it seem really cool that you can just drop the toothbrush in glass without having to make sure it's positioned the right way, REALLY cool. Problem is if you're using it to rinse with I don't think you want to also store the bottom of the toothbrush in it afterwords. Doesn't seem right. They also include a charging cradle though instead if you want to use the glass as a glass. That's a nice dual featured option. Only problems though are that it does have to align a certain way and it's not always clean how the toothbrush fits in it (direction wise) so you just need to rotate it a certain way and remember that's how you left it. It also would have been nice if the charging cradle was glass so you could drop in the dishwasher like the charging glass but it's high quality plastic. It's not a big deal but would have been nice. The travel case with USB charger / AC adapter is a smart idea and I don't know why someone didn't think of it sooner. For those long trips it's one less thing you have to take with you. The case itself it also excellent quality, well built, and stylish. There is no UV cleaner on this model. Personally I never had the model with one. I always question if it really makes a difference. Sure UV can kill the little grubbies but over time they can also mutate and become stronger. Not to mention the UV doesn't seem like it would have an effect in crevices where the light doesn't reach. I just don't know that it \\"really\\" makes a difference. The cost of toothbrush is expensive. Yes. But my first Sonicare over a decade ago was MORE expensive and in todays dollars would be even more so. Are they making a large profit off these. Possibility. But they also seem to spend a lot of R&D to constantly refine and upgrade, not just repackage/redesign or add gimmicks. Given that you get the toothbrush, two heads, two chargers (home/travel), travel case/charger, glass, etc and they are all very high quality, excellent build quality/construction/design I think you get what you're paying for. They are also some of the most popular and recommended professionaltype home toothbrushes. The replacement heads on the other hand due seem more expensive compared to their other models which contain more parts/plastic. I'm sure that will change. But this is also a change in business too. There are lots of businesses out there that sell the hardware at a loss because it's so expensive to make, but make there money back on consumables.

  570. This is one of my best purchases of the year (the other being the Nutribullet). My friend suggested I treat myself to this Sonicare DiamondClean. He also told me it would change my life. And it has. I hate, repeat HATE, brushing my teeth. I don't find it pleasurable in any way. I would rather suffer at the hands of my dentist every 6 months than to brush my teeth on a regular basis. This thing has a bunch of different modes (i.e. 'Polish' when I had a little too much red wine and 'GumCare' when my mouth is feeling a little hairy). The 30-second interval timer is really handy b/c it makes sure you reach every part of your mouth and not just the front teeth.   577. I've never owned -- or even used -- an electric toothbrush before. I bought this product, pricey though it is, based on the reviews here on Amazon.<br /><br />I'm happy with it, and still happy a year later, as I update this review.<br /><br />Although I can't compare this brush to other electric toothbrushes for how effectively it cleans, I like it.<br /><br />My mouth certainly feels clean after the 2 or 3 minutes. (I've had no problems at all with over-vigorous brushing, unlike some of the other reviewers.) It's certainly a good looking toothbrush, too, and since it sits out in the bathroom (at least in my minuscule bathroom, it has to), that's important to me as well. The charger options are terrific -- the glass, the little unit instead of the glass both work and are equally convenient. (I haven't used the USB option, and I didn't see the point of it -- who would charge a toothbrush through a laptop??!!??--, but someone pointed out that it's convenient for international travel, which makes sense.) So all in all, great stuff.<br /><br />My only deduction, a star, is for the design flaw that many others have complained about: the single button that switches modes *and* turns it on and off -- but, very unfortunately, only in sequence of modes. In other words, if you're brushing in \\"clean,\\" and want to end early, you have to cycle through the other modes before it turns off. Not a deal breaker, but wow, is that annoying. One other annoyance: it sometimes gets noisy and rattles (though maybe mine's broken already!).<br /><br />Oh, and it's expensive. But worth it to me, at least, and you get what you pay for.
  578. It's everything I've wanted in a toothbrush. The case is amazing...it allows charging while in the case using usb to a wall outlet or computer.   579. I had the Sonicare Flexcare awhile back, but the battery started to lose its charge after one or two brushings, so I started shopping. I had read that most people didn't notice a difference between sonic and non-sonic variety, so I opted for an Oral B electric (rotating-head) brush. ...mistake. The brush-head was tiny, it was loud, the battery didn't last more than 3-4 days, and I never really felt that ultra-clean like I did with the Flexcare. Goodbye, Oral B! Hello, DiamondClean! This is amazing. The look is sleek and classy, tho, the handle is a little .. not slippery, but an odd smooth that takes a little getting used to. It charges fairly quick and the charges have lasted about a week (two brushings per day). It's quiet, too; just a low hum that can't really be heard outside of 10 feet. I've read complaints about the multiple modes and having to awkwardly scroll thru them while the brush-head is in your mouth; honestly, I haven't even needed another mode other than the standard. Why? Because the power is glorious! I missed it SO much with the oral b. This leaves my mouth feeling amazing! My one complaint (about all Sonicares) is the auto-shutoff after two-minutes. They say \\"30 seconds per zone\\" (top-outside, top-in, bottom-out, bottom-in), but sometimes I fall behind schedule and the brush shuts off when I'm only half done. Simple enough-- turn the brush on again for a fresh two minutes. I hesitate to mention anything positive about the oral b, but that one stuttered the brush at the two-min mark, then just kept on going. I wish Phillips would incorporate that feature. It's a very, very minor complaint, and frankly, my only one. This toothbrush is well-worth every penny!

  587. This is by far the most expensive toothbrush I've ever bought, but I think it was worth the money. My old one (A $60 dollar DazzlePro) burned out after about a year or so. Actually it didn't burn out; it just started turning itself on at random times, and never when I needed it to.<br /><br />First, this thing is probably what you'd get if Apple designed electric tooth brushes. It's sleek looking, the lights kinda &#34;fade in and out&#34;, the product packaging is a work of art, and every detail was meticulously crafted by engineers who obviously lose sleep over this sort of thing. My favorite feature is the inductive charging! That little glass cup you see in the picture; yes, that's a charger. You just drop the toothbrush in there and the lights turn off, and the &#34;Charging&#34; light starts pulsating. It even comes with a fancy travel case with the same inductive charging ability, only this one uses a USB cable. Yes, it's that geeky.<br /><br />The only slight issue I have is the tooth brush head itself is a bit too small, and sometimes I put a blob of toothpaste on it and it immediately falls off. However, I think this makes it easier to reach those back wisdom teeth so perhaps it's worth the occasional mishap. I'd recommend this tooth brush to anyone!
  588. Cleans great and has a great aesthetic design. The protective travel case that includes charging via USB is genius. The only downside is that it's not possible to choose the toothbrush's mode before turning on the sonic vibration. But honestly, I only use the standard 2-minute cleaning mode, so this isn't a big deal for me.
  589. I really like this toothbrush! I read all the reviews before i bought it and i agree with the majority of them. This really makes your teeth feel dentist-clean - everyday! Only down side was It was a little pricey!!! That kept me from buying it for quite awhile but the reviews finally won me over (and my old Sonic was dying....). Hopefully it will last a few years.
  590. Toothbrush handle looked slightly dirty, but it wiped off with a damp cloth. I received it quickly. I love the way it makes my teeth feel. Although it was pricy, it was well worth it!
  591. Wireless charging is so cool. I just wish the USB connector for charging it in the travel case was micro instead of mini, so I could share it with all my other devices.
  592. Really makes your mouth feel clean!
  593. I previously had a 5 star review, but miraculously just a few months after warranty expires, so does the brush handle. I loved the product and took great care of it, but a little after the 2 year warranty expired the brush started to stutter and switch between low and high vibrations as if one of the gears rusted away. It got progressively worse and now barely works and drives me crazy.<br /><br />Despite customer service acknowledging that it is sounds like a common manufacturing issue, they hid behind the 2 year warranty period and were not willing to budge after several attempts. Their solution was a 15% discount and they suggested a 6mo warranty extension for additional $, which is just a slap in the face given mine broke down after 2 years and 7 months. I explained I have been a lifelong Philips customer, and my family still has 4 old Sonicare models that have lasted me 8+ years without issues, and that a sub 3yr shelf life for their &#34;top of the line&#34; almost $200 toothbrush doesn't seem right. Their response was &#34;Yes, that's actually the normal time frame for a Sonicare (diamondclean) to last because it has a motor attached to a batter inside the handle connected to other electrical components.&#34; Effectively they admitted that its normal for these expensive toothbrushes to begin to break down just after the warranty period, and just hope their customers keep replacing them. If you ask me almost $100 a year for a toothbrush is a complete scam. They lost a lifelong Philips user due to taking manufacturing shortcuts that they never made with past models.nnecessary (my roommate has one)<br /><br />Baseline: its not necessary, but neither are any of the flexcare models or any oral-b over the 1000. The diamondclean is a high end luxury no frills kind of model that feels great in your hand and is built to last. The long term batterly life and sleek design make it terrific for travelers.
  594. I bought this because I have developed a bad habit over many years of brushing too hard, and because of that I'm getting some slight gum recession, so I decided on this to help break the habit. I've always thought that electric toothbrushes were a bit of a gimmick so I've never bought one until now, but I am impressed! The first time I used it, my teeth felt much more clean than they ever have from normal brushing. It is expensive, but it appears to be well made and the way it charges is too cool. You just set it in the inductive charger, and that's it. The only thing that bugs me, is that it doesn't seem that it runs long enough before the timer shuts it off. For example: the &#34;Clean&#34; mode is 2 minutes long. You're supposed to divide your mouth up into 4 sections, and after 30 seconds it alerts you that it's time to move on to another section. I'm finding that I don't have enough time to finish up each section before moving on, so I wish there were a way to disable that feature. Other than that minor gripe, this is worth every penny!

  614. UPDATE 5/2014: After two years of use, the power button on the handle had become so unresponsive to operate, that it required a very forceful two-thumb push to turn on my toothbrush. I contacted Philips via their website, using their online assistant, and a replacement handle was shipped to me the same day. I simply had to return mine in the same box as the replacement, and Philips paid the return shipping. How easy was that?! My two year warranty had actually expired one month prior (isn't that always the way it goes?) but it turns out that because I registered my toothbrush--which I didn't even remember doing--the warranty got extended by an additional six months. Great customer service, Philips!<br /><br />ORIGINAL REVIEW: Funny, i don't remember reading that Jonny Ive was moonlighting over at Philips. But this is their second new dental product in a row--the first being the AirFloss--that might lead you to think that Sonicare design was now being done by Apple. And I mean that in the most complimentary way. This is, without question, the most modern and elegantly designed electric toothbrush on the market today, and I can only compare holding it to the feeling you get when you hold an Apple product. But is it worth the premium price being charged for it?<br /><br />THE ANSWER IS YES, IF...<br /><br />1) You have money to splurge a bit and value great design very highly. The ceramic feel of the power handle (though not actually ceramic), the hidden areas that illuminate to indicate mode and battery status, the brilliance of a travel case that both closes magnetically and charges the power handle via USB cable from your computer or the included USB power adapter--the whole package has just been thought through with incredible attention to detail. There's even an alternative to the one feature I didn't like, which was the charging glass--it looked too big and clunky in photos, which is exactly how it looks when you actually see it. Plus, do we really need to mimic the old, unsanitary practice of standing wet toothbrushes up in a glass to store them? Fortunately, there's a much smaller and more elegant charging stand included that can be used instead of the glass. You never see that in photos of this toothbrush, and I was very pleased.<br /><br />2) You don't care if the premium price buys you no functional or performance advantage of any type over cheaper models in the Sonicare line. You know you're paying for the design, and you're fine with it. (Yes, I agree that the DiamondClean brush heads ARE a notable improvement, but they can be used on other, less expensive Sonicare models. See below.)<br /><br />THE ANSWER IS NO, IF...<br /><br />1) You expect a premium price to buy you better functionality and performance over less expensive models. The DiamondClean toothbrush doesn't, trust me. Ignore most of the five star review hype that you read about this brush (\\"Cleanest Teeth EVER!\\") and focus on these facts:<br /><br />a) The power handle, which is the heart of any electric toothbrush, is just the FlexCare+ handle with a different skin on it. Specs are identical and--if you go to a store and hold them side by side--you'll see that size, shape and weight are the same. Only the elegant, ceramic-like skin on the DiamondClean model, with it's hidden lights, is different.<br /><br />b) While the DiamondClean brushes DO clean somewhat better than older Sonicare brush heads, you can use DiamondClean brushes on some of the older, cheaper Sonicare models like FlexCare. Since the power handles are essentially no different, the cleaning you get will be the same.<br /><br />2) It drives you crazy to pay more and actually get less for your money. As others have pointed out, the DiamondClean doesn't have the UV sanitizer of the less expensive FlexCare models. And I just saw a Costco special that included two Sonicare power handles, two chargers, two travel cases, plus four brush heads that included two DiamondClean ones... all for $120.<br /><br />3) Design just isn't that important to you.<br /><br />The value of great design is very much a personal decision. While I decided that the DiamondClean was worth it for me, it might not be for you, depending on your priorities. But either way, I thank you for taking the time to read my review. and I hope you found it \\"helpful\\" in making your purchasing decision!<br /><br />UPDATES: The longer you use a product, the better you get to know it. The section below contains more on the pros and cons I've experienced since I wrote the above review after extended use of the DiamondClean:<br /><br />PROS: 1) The ceramic-like power handle, which I thought might get slippery during usage when wet, actually maintains a nice grip to it.<br /><br />CONS: 1) No vent holes in the travel case, made worse by its form-fitting plastic interior. So if you pack the brush head while damp--which often happens when traveling--it stays damp, in a dark, tightly enclosed space--the perfect conditions for promoting bacteria and mold growth. 2) When a second family member recently joined me in using the DiamondClean, I suddenly realized that there's no storage for multiple brush heads. (Except in the travel case.) Plus, there's no system for color-coding the heads for different family members. Bottom line: you have to store multiple brush heads in a medicine cabinet or elsewhere and somehow color code them yourself.r /><br />3) Design just isn't that important to you.<br /><br />The value of great design is very much a personal decision. While I decided that the DiamondClean was worth it for me, it might not be for you, depending on your priorities. But either way, I thank you for taking the time to read my review. and I hope you found it \\"helpful\\" in making your purchasing decision!<br /><br />UPDATES: The longer you use a product, the better you get to know it. The section below contains more on the pros and cons I've experienced since I wrote the above review after extended use of the DiamondClean:<br /><br />PROS: 1) The ceramic-like power handle, which I thought might get slippery during usage when wet, actually maintains a nice grip to it.<br /><br />CONS: 1) No vent holes in the travel case, made worse by its form-fitting plastic interior. So if you pack the brush head while damp--which often happens when traveling--it stays damp, in a dark, tightly enclosed space--the perfect conditions for promoting bacteria and mold growth. 2) When a second family member recently joined me in using the DiamondClean, I suddenly realized that there's no storage for multiple brush heads. (Except in the travel case.) Plus, there's no system for color-coding the heads for different family members. Bottom line: you have to store multiple brush heads in a medicine cabinet or elsewhere and somehow color code them yourself.

  629. I purchased the Diamond Clean toothbrush through Amazon prime. Having purchased for more than 100 items through Amazon Prime, I would say that this is the only one that is not up to the standards of Amazon.<br /><br />First of all, the product is for Dental Professional Trial so it's not intended for resale. It might be good to check whether the product that you purchase will be under warranty. Second, it doesn't have the charger glass as shown in the pictures.   630. This toothbrush is a disaster:<br /><br />1. You can't set the mode on the toothbrush. It's a complete design failure. The toothbrush has five modes. The \\"on\\" button immediately starts the toothbrush and then you press it repeatedly to cycle through the modes. You have to look at the handle of the toothbrush to see what mode you're in. Fine, but you need to put the toothpaste on the toothbrush and put it in your mouth before you start using it. If it's in your mouth and ready to use, you CANNOT look at the handle to see what mode you are in. So, it isn't possible to set it correctly to the brushing mode that you want when you are ready to start brushing. It's the worst product design I've ever seen. The only solution is to count the number of times you press the button while the toothbrush is in your mouth and hope that you guessed right. Incredibly stupid design.<br /><br />2. The toothbrush head does not attach securely. The toothbrush head vibrates itself off of the handle--it's moving at 33,000 vibrations per second and does not lock into place. The manual shows that toothbrush head attaching with a loud \\"click\\" but the manual is generic and not relevant to this model. The toothbrush head does not \\"click\\" into place. It just smushes on and then wiggles off while you use the toothbrush. I tried with both of the toothbrush heads that come with the toothbrush and neither of them attaches securely. Another complete design failure.<br /><br />3. The manual gives incorrect information about the brushing modes. There is supposed to be a beep to indicate moving the brush from one section of your mouth to another. There is no beep: the brush just pauses briefly which is very confusing--it seems as if you've accidentally turned off the brush for a second. Without the beep you can't tell if you turned it off by accident or that's the signal to move the brush to another part of your mouth.<br /><br />4. The toothbrush is supposed to signal three times to move to another part of your mouth: it signals 6 times! This makes no sense. The manual clearly states that the brushing cycles are divided into four parts (one for each quarter of your mouth). If it is signalling me to move the brush six times, it is obviously not guiding me through brushing four sections of my mouth.<br /><br />I am very very disappointed. This is one of the most badly designed things I've ever purchased.t of your mouth: it signals 6 times! This makes no sense. The manual clearly states that the brushing cycles are divided into four parts (one for each quarter of your mouth). If it is signalling me to move the brush six times, it is obviously not guiding me through brushing four sections of my mouth.<br /><br />I am very very disappointed. This is one of the most badly designed things I've ever purchased.

  632. I've used Sonicare for 7 years now and DiamondClean is the latest in the family of rechargeable electric toothbrush. So far, it feels great, especially the brush head. My main issue with Sonicare toothbrushes are their batteries. Eventually the batteries will not charge anymore and the toothbrush will randomly start and won't be turned off. There is nothing that you can do except to buy a new one. This usually happens after 1.5-2 years of usage. My other complaint is that the color/paint (replacement indicator) on the brush head vanishes way faster than the advertised time of 3 months.<br /><br />In terms of the new design for the DiamondClean, I don't like the cup charger, because it collects water after using the toothbrush. I've always had problems with the bottom of the toothbrush yellowing from water dripping from the top after usage.

  648. It is amazing!! Everytime I brush my teeth, they feel dentist clean!!
  649. I bought this toothbrush as an upgrade to my FlexCare and couldn't be happier. While many have complained about the one button design, I would respectfully recommend reading the manual. The brush was designed with simplicity in mind. Eliminating the second button is a feature, not a downgrade. Here's how it works:<br /><br />1) Press power/mode button and scroll through menu to find desired mode.<br /><br />2). Press power/mode again to power off. You have 30 seconds to place toothpaste on brush before mode is canceled.<br /><br />3). Place brush in mouth, then power back on . . .brush will run for full time of mode setting, then power off automatically.<br /><br />The case was designed to charge the brush, so a form fitting interior was necessary in order for the handle to make proper charging contact. Admittedly, it would be nice to have the ability to place the cap over the brush head, however, doing so in the form would prevent ample air circulation, causing bacteria growth. My work around is to place the cap in the second brush compartment and put the cap back on when I arrive at my destination.<br /><br />As for the lack of storage for the charging cord, is that really necessary? Neither my iPad or iPhone have on board storage capability and I travel just fine with both. I keep the cords for all three in a pocket in my carry on flight bag. The charger cord is always there, in it's pocket when needed. On board charger capability would have required a larger case, giving reviewers one more complaint.<br /><br />Yes, a UV Sanitizer would be perfect, and perhaps they'll bring back the standalone sanitizer that was once available. I kept my Flexcare + sanitizer and use the charger side to charge my AirFloss. However, i managed to live most of my life without a sanitizer but if the lack of one would be a deal breaker . . .there's still the option of choosing the FlexCare +.<br /><br />When put into perspective, this unit's design was fully tested and there's a logical reason for every feature. I sincerely couldn't be happier with my purchase.here's a logical reason for every feature. I sincerely couldn't be happier with my purchase.

  655. I travel a lot for a living and it occurred to me that much of the time I was using a regular toothbrush, while my trusty electric stayed at home, not being used.<br /><br />So I saw this bad boy in the store and asked for it for Christmas. Turns out Santa was very generous this year and under the tree arrived this incredibly expensive and fully featured electric toothbrush.<br /><br />The charging mechanism is super cool. It looks like a glass tumbler, yet through the magic of electromagnetic induction it charges the toothbrush just by putting it in the glass tumbler. When traveling there is a little hard sided case that has the ability to charge the toothbrush also. Just plug a USB cord into the case.<br /><br />Unfortunately it is this travel case that ultimately cost this product a gold star. While the brush itself may be an excellent design, the travel case requires that the brush head be removed from the base, and worse the head protector must be removed from the head before you put it in the box. In fact there is no actual space for the head cover at all. So you end up putting that in a separate plastic bag.<br /><br />In one move this negates so much of the practicality of the travel case, which was one of the primary reasons for my purchase.<br /><br />On the upside the manufacturer claims that the brush can go three weeks without charging, so I don't actually need to charge the brush on my trips. But it is a pity that the that travel case is so useless.<br /><br />As a brush, it's fantastic. Other than the snafu with the travel case, it does a fantastic job. Multiple modes, and a really clean feeling. It's an expensive brush, but what price do you put on the health of your teeth?
  656. After a year and half, it's kind of broken. The vibration comes and goes.
  657. If you've ever owned or used one of these then you already know the basics of how this kind of toothbrush works and the Diamondclean is no different. I'm a fan of Sonicare and purchased this one to replace one that I accidentally damaged. The only negative I can say about this model is that the smooth plastic body is a bit tough to hang on to. My previous Sonicare had rubber around most of the body and that made for a secure grip. The Diamondclean has a very smooth body and it seems to slip and slide around in my hand. This is a great toothbrush but it works the same as the lower models. You can't go wrong with Sonicare.
  658. Let me start off by saying that I have been using sonicares for the past 9 years, and my teeth have never been in better shape. However when deciding which sonicare to buy, you have to keep several things in mind:<br /><br />1. Essence: good basic brush, not as many strokes per minute.<br /><br />2. Flexcare/ + : Good advanced brush, with lift most stains with pro results brush, give an awesome clean feeling.<br /><br />3: Diamondclean: ok, slightly more advanced, charging glass only looks cool but is hard to keep clean with water stains etc.<br /><br />Pros of diamondclean: much, much less susceptible to mold and other grime that forms between the handle and brush head of EVERY OTHER MODEL! yes there is no way to fix it, the gap will get toothpaste in it, and bacteria will grow on that sugar. It will be a biofilm that will get daily nutrition.<br /><br />Pros of Sonicare: i can never go back to regular brushes. my teeth will never feel as clean with manual brushes. When i forget my sonicare during travel, i have lot regretful travels. yes not an exaggeration, but a fact.<br /><br />Cons of Sonicare: except for diamondclean, other brushes are susceptible to stuff growing at the joint where head meets handle. The \\"other\\" modes are barely ever used.<br /><br />Cons of diamondclean: The travel case is very unintuitive when it comes to storing wet brushes. How do you vent it to ensure bristles dry?<br /><br />I strive to write short, to the point reviews. if you have questions, please comment, i will be happy to answer.
  659. We've had two of these DiamondClean toothbrushes and previously, two of the previous FlexCare models. They perform very well and are good/better than the previous Oral-B models. But I am not at all pleased with Sonicare reliability. Within 2.5 years of owning two of these DiamondClean toothbrushes, I've had 3 just stop turning on. The first two failed this way after about a year and within 1-2 weeks of each other. Philips customer service was great and after confirming it wasn't just a charging issue, replaced both due to the 2-year warranty. But one of those replacements just failed and because it's out of warranty, I'm stuck buying another one. I like the Sonicares and think they're the best available, but I'm not thrilled about spending $200 every 2-3 years for an electric toothbrush. I hope that they've figured out the kinks over time and my new one will be more reliable. BTW, I use an older FlexCare for travel (better battery life) and it failed about the same way, but at least not until many years after the warranty expired. I still keep going back to Sonicare...

  669. I was looking forward to trying an electric toothbrush for the first time. Everything sounded great about this one. The five modes sounded like a great idea. It is however it's implementation is flawed. How do you actually set the mode you want and get toothpaste on the darn thing? You can apply paste, then stick it in your mouth and turn it on. That works fine but what if you want the fourth mode? By the time you press the button three more times to get to that mode, the paste is gone! I suppose you can put it in your mouth then press the button several times but then what's the point in having the nice display. When you push the power button it immediately starts in the first mode. Try putting paste on it and selecting a different mode. It will liquefy the paste and fling it off the brush. There either needs to be a delay or a 2nd button. The delay would stall the onset of power for 2 or 3 seconds to give you enough time to stick the brush in your mouth before turning it on. The 2nd button would select the mode and the first button would turn it on. Either way would solve the problem. Do the designers actually use their own creations? It's a pretty nice brush otherwise.
  670. This toothbrush is shockingly well designed. I say this as someone who worships at the altar of Apple (and Porsche). If customer delight is what you seek, and you need a new electric toothbrush.....you will not be disappointed. Period. Starting with the surprisingly heavy package that includes a heavy glass tumbler for the unit to sit in, through which it recharges through induction (there are several other charging options included). The unit itself is stunning. Just a pure white and very light unit, until you turn it on and status information glows through. The fitted travel case is a trip in itself: mini USB connector to charge through your computer (or USB charger) and a magnetic closure. But since the toothbrush uses a Lithium Ion battery (good for three weeks) it is just for safety. I thought Apple had a near monopoly on clever, aesthetic, practical and whimsical electronics design. But some rogue design group at Philips is emulating 1 Infinite Loop in the electric toothbrush department! PS: my dental hygienist says Sonicare toothbrushes are a bit better than Oral-B. Certainly more delicate and logically as or more efficacious due to the very soft bristles and the very high frequency it oscillates at. But they got me 100% with the design! PPS: I bought one for myself yesterday, for my wife today.
  671. The handle is smooth and fits so nicely into your hands that you simply want to hold it. The display lights up with clean, white lights. It is incredibly easy to use, and leaves your mouth feeling clean and refreshed. With three great-looking, streamlined ways of storing your DiamondClean (case, glass, or stand), what's not to love? The case is sturdy with magnetic closure. The charging glass is simple enough to fit into any bathroom setting. Brushing your teeth is a two-time daily must, but now, you'll both love and enjoy it! I don't have any real problems with having to change the mode while brushing. It's a simple matter of counting. I normally stay between \\"Clean\\" and \\"White\\", anyways. Not to mention, it's easy to see considering how long the handle is? My only complaint is that I wish the carrying case allowed you to store the brush heads with the plastic cover. Other than that--very pleased with this unit.

  691. Sonicare 9332 DiamondClean is a life changer.<br /><br />My dentist recommended I go electrical since I was brushing too hard and was causing my gums to recede, while at the same time not effectively cleaning my teeth. She claimed frequency of the brush strokes mattered, not power. So I did some aggressive research and went with the top of the line Sonicare. I tried OralB before and quit because the brush head rotates and rips your gums more - OralB is an entirely different technology. The brush on the Sonicare, on the otherhand, cleans without actually rotating, and thus doesn't rip your gums.<br /><br />After using this, you will never feel clean going back to manual brushing. And yes, all the studies are right, you do spend more time cleaning with an electrical, which is counter intuitive, because you are systematically trying to cover every surface of every tooth. So be prepared for a 5 min brush. Due to the time commitment, I prefer to use it at night only, and I brush manual in the morning and after dinner since manual is faster.<br /><br />Everyone who can spend the money should have one of these. In my opinion, and I am not a dentist, but I believe you actually come out saving money because if you use this product, floss, and use mouth wash, at least 2 times a day, you can certainly reduce the number of times you go for &#34;regular cleaning&#34;. So rather than pay 100-200 bucks to your dental hygenist every 4-6 months you can now go every 8-12 months. And I am sure when you do go after 8-12 months, your teeth will show up 2x cleaner than manual brushing and showing up every 4-6 months.<br /><br />Btw - very easy to clean and charge. Reliable technology.

  706. Years ago, my periodontist recommended the Sonicare. Products eventually finish their useful life, and I am now using the Sonicare DiamondClean brush. That basically pays for the Sonicare in one year.<br /><br />This particular product arrived just in time for Christmas as my older unit was on its last legs. I was pleased that the old brush heads that I knew Santa would put in my stocking would fit the new handle. The handle is elegant and avoids the criticisms I had for my earlier model. The single button is all you need. I especially like the basic charging stand. The glass that is provided is cool, but I'll be using the simple base charger. To me, it takes up less space and fits into a corner better. The travel case is very nice, but it doesn't include storage space for the charger. When I travel, I want to take the charger even if I think I will not need it. That said, the travel case is a charger that is USB compatible.
