  728. Dropping it into the glass for charging is all this unit is about. Other than that, they did a horrible job on software. Software for a toothbrush? You bet - terrible software programming. It was performed by some engineer who probably never brushes his teeth anyway.<br /><br />It runs half-speed for 2 weeks, which you can turn off (and go to full speed). But then half speed comes back. Then you can't shut off the brush by pushing the button - it just changes modes. The only way to shut it off is to slop toothpaste all over the bathroom and put it back in it's glass. Then it'll turn off.<br /><br />No way to update software. No way to make materials stronger - again the Chinese have an insatiable hunger for anything plastic. This unit should have been ceramic or even metal. But cheap plastic from top to bottom? Wait till you drop it on the tile floor.<br /><br />And the brush pops out from time to time, and since you can't shut it off once it's running you'll have to wait 2 minutes till it shuts itself off, or do the in-the-glass thing.<br /><br />It also pauses every 30 seconds weather you like it or not - no software choices to turn yet another annoying feature off. My old one used to have a setting for that, but not the new modern one.<br /><br />Carrying case is stupid - brush just sits in there all day and grows bacteria.<br /><br />It's definitely a 1, but I'll give it like 1/2 additional star for the glass/charging thing. At least it is REAL glass and not plastic - so credit where credit is due.<br /><br />Just get one of the original models - they work great. Had my first one for more than 3 years before it finally gave up. This one won't last much past July 4th IMHO
  729. I just upgraded from an OralB SonicCare, and this definitely gets deeper and leaves my teeth cleaner, especially the &#34;Polish&#34; cycle. After every use it feels like I just came from a cleaning at the dentist. I use &#34;polish&#34; mode once or twice a week to get a little deeper, but otherwise stick with &#34;clean&#34;. I did have some gum sensitivity at the beginning, but that went away. The charging case was fun to use on a recent vacation - it worked just fine and looked good doing it. It is approaching 3 months, and the indicator bristles on the brush head are definitely signaling that it is time to purchase some overpriced brush heads. Supposedly my dental health is worth it.
  730. Dropped it ONCE and it broke. Yes, it brushes teeth very well. But you need to think about whether you feel comfortable spending $150 for a new one every year or two because that is the reality of ownership. Not to mention the price of replacing brushes is rather painful. My first Sonicare toothbrush, bought years ago, was designed to last, with rubber on the housing to absorb the shock of a fall. It did, in fact, fall to the tiled floor on a number of occasions without causing damage. Companies like Philips make me sick when they subsequently &#34;improve&#34; the design, reengineering their products to fail regularly. Consumers lose: more money for them. Hopefully consumers will learn their lesson some day soon and close their pocketbooks to these companies. Only then will they (the companies) learn.
  731. it's okay.. I don't think its waterproof?? I've used it for a year and it completely broke down. First the lights started to fade away so I would have to guess which settings it was on, and recently it would turn on/off randomly by itself. It finally broke and wouldn't turn on at all except the bottom light in the settings on the toothbrush.
  732. Best tooth brush I've ever used! My teeth feel like I just came from a cleaning at the dentist. Very happy with this.
  733. I bought this toothbrush for my husband. I had tried to get him to try a battery operated toothbrush before, but he would not.<br />NHow he loves the Phillips Sonicare Diamond Clean Rechargeable Electric toothbrush.
  734. I absolutely love this electric toothbrush! I have had many electric brushes, but this one is absolutely the best. I have sensitive teeth and this works wonderfully without making my teeth feel more sensitive. I also love that this brush does such a wonderful job of removing plaque, I rarely have to use my plaque scraper now. Great product, so worth the money!
  735. Everytime I brush my teeth, they feel like they do when I've gone to the dentist for a teeth-cleaning. I've had several generations of electric toothbrushes. This one is by far the best.
  736. My old Sonicare died, and for 3 weeks (before I got this one), I went back to a manual toothbrush. I happened to have a regular dental cleaning scheduled (by coincidence) near the end of the 3 weeks, and it took my hygienist at least twice as long as she usually takes for the appointment. I felt like my teeth weren't getting as clean with the manual toothbrush, but she confirmed it. This is my 3rd Sonicare toothbrush in about 8 years, and I think they are definitely the best electric brushes on the market. I was torn between getting this model (DiamondClean) and the one a tier down in price (I forget what it's called), as the the DiamondClean, great as it is, seems excessive. However, I went ahead with the Diamond, hoping that it will last as long as previous models have. It's much lighter than the model I had before, which is nice for traveling, and feels very sleek in your hand. All the settings sometimes make it hard to turn off with one touch (the on/off button also cycles you through all the settings), but if you wait until the 2 min. mark, it automatically turns itself off. I'm not sure why Philips has dropped the accompanying UV cleaner, as I know a lot of people liked having that. The glass charger seems kind of silly; it's just as easy to put the brush on a plastic stand, and I'm worried about knocking the glass (which will definitely break) over on the granite counter in bathroom. However, it does come with a second charger (not glass), which should work if that happens. When the price for this item comes down about $50, I think it'll be the best Sonicare option on the market. It does make your teeth feel very clean. (I had to take off 1 star for being overpriced, but it's a great product.)
  737. I bought this because my dentist recommended that I switch to an electric toothbrush to reduce gum line recession. It takes a bit of getting used to, but the product works really well. I have that &#34;just cleaned&#34; feeling on my teeth all year around now, not just after leaving the dentist's office. And when I went in for my cleaning last week, a new hygienist (who had never worked on my teeth) poked around for about 10 seconds and asked, &#34;Do you use an electric toothbrush?&#34; I said that I did and she commented that it was obvious because my teeth were so clean. She had to do very little picking and scraping as was very complimentary on the condition of my teeth.<br /><br />It's a little pricey, but well worth it.
  738. Amazing! i love it. Feel clean and refreshed all day long, like a professional cleaning (xcept u r not going to gag becuz you r in charge). Smooth n powerful, i find myself brushing longer than with any other brush incl standard Sonicare. Love that it inclues 'gum care' (light massage) something which i need, but have not spent enough time on. Bravo Diamond Clean.
  739. DiamondClean toothbrush is way better than the old e-series! Bought this to upgrade my e-series. This toothbrush makes your teeth feel even cleaner than brushing with the e-series. Gets between the teeth well. Was a little discouraged by reading the negative feedback before purchasing but am glad I ordered this toothbrush. I have been using sonicare for 10 years or so and this model surpassed my expectations. However, I never tried the models between DiamondClean and e-series. This toothbrush came with a glass charging disk and the charging glass...I just use the glass charging disk to charge the toothbrush and the charging glass for mouthwash. One thing that disappointed me was that I bought a white toothbrush when I really wanted the black. I was discouraged in buying the black because comments said the black toothbrush heads were more expensive and hard to get. However, they are sold at a lot of places at the same price even at Costco. sigh!
  740. Best tooth brush I ever bought! Feels like I just stepped out of a dentist every morning. Everyone should try it!
  741. I used my first Sonicare toothbrush for nearly a decade before it finally stopped working. I loved that toothbrush. I noticed--and so did my dentist--a dramatic improvement in the cleanliness of my teeth. So, of course I purchased the top-of-the-line model to replace it.<br /><br />14 months later, I'm trying to decide if I should shell out more cash for this brush, or buy another model or brand. I have to agree with the other negative reviews on this site. Despite the fact that my teeth still get Sonicare clean, there are some major design flaws with this brush. I was hoping by the time I had to replace it, they would've been addressed, but my brush broke this morning and this model has not yet been redesigned.<br /><br />Yes, it's beautiful. But as other reviewers have pointed out, it's more than a little annoying that you can't turn on the brush, or cycle through cleaning modes, without having it in your mouth already. It starts vibrating as soon as you push the button, and if it's not in your mouth, you're going to shower your face and bathroom with a fine mist of toothpaste. I got adept at putting the brush in my mouth, angling it so that I could see the lights in the mirror, and pressing the button until I reached the cleaning mode I wanted. Should I really have to do that with a top-of-the-line toothbrush? The brush can't be turned off until it has been running for 10 seconds, so it's not even possible to select the mode, turn it off, apply toothpaste and turn it on again.<br /><br />The brush remembers the last cleaning mode used, which is also frustrating. If I knew that I had to press the button three times as soon as I turned it on to get to, say, \\"whitening mode,\\" then that would make a little more sense. As it is, if I used whitening mode the last time, I have to press the button several times to get it back into cleaning mode.<br /><br />I'm surprised someone approved this ridiculous design. Would it destroy the aesthetics of this brush so much if there were two simple buttons, one for \\"power\\" and one for \\"cleaning mode?\\" I appreciate the beautiful design, but I would rather have an ugly toothbrush and beautiful teeth. I don't buy a toothbrush as a piece of art to display in my bathroom. In the case of this brush, design has taken priority over functionality.<br /><br />This morning, as I was going through my usual routine of squinting in the mirror with the brush in my mouth, ready to hit the button several times to get into \\"clean\\" mode, the brush slipped out of my hand and fell about three feet into the sink. Now it no longer works. I'm not a careless person -- but sometimes a toothbrush falls, especially when I've got to do minor gymnastics every morning just to use it. It didn't fall far, and it didn't fall hard, but now the brush head no longer vibrates.<br /><br />I'm going to research other brands. I'm really disappointed in Phillips for not having designed this very expensive tool with more care for their customers. If it's re-designed so that function takes priority, and with better materials, then I'll buy a new one. If I decide that Sonicare is still the best brush for cleaning, I'll buy a different model. This supposedly top-of-the-line brush is anything but. After over a decade of using Sonicare, I'm seriously considering purchasing the highly-rated Oral-B Professional toothbrush at nearly half the price.<br /><br />Update: March 27, 2014<br />After doing my research, I had to (somewhat reluctantly) admit to myself that Sonicare still seems like the best way to take care of my teeth. So, I purchased the Flexcare model, which still uses the Diamond Clean brush heads, isn't as sleek, but has TWO buttons -- a power button, and a mode-selection button. It also comes in a multi-pack, which at a \\"big box\\" store was cheaper than buying a single brush. The two brushes I now own were still less than half the price of the DiamondClean, and my teeth get just as clean. Hopefully it'll last at least twice as long.g.
  742. I upgraded from my classic Sonicare solely because its aging battery no longer accepted a charge--about 10 years after purchasing it. All of that to say, this is a considerable upgrade. My teeth feel cleaner, I appreciate the charging glass for its practicality. Having recently traveled with the new brush, I can also say the USB charging case is incredibly practical. Amazon was the best price that I could find. If you need a new Sonicare, this is a great choice!
  743. First, let me talk about the design itself since this is pretty much what you will be paying for - The toothbrush does indeed look beautiful. The glass cup stand (combines as a charger) that comes with looks pretty slick. When people come into my restroom and I mention that the cup acts as a charger they are all amused and amazed... The travel case that it comes with is heavy duty and has an USB plug-in so you can charge it on the go without having an AC outlet. Sadly the aesthetics is the only the good thing about this device...<br /><br />The on button for this toothbrush is poorly constructed. If you like brushing your teeth in the SHOWER forget about it! This Sonicare has an open ring around the power button where if you get water in it will damage so you have to make sure you don't get anything inside it. This is pretty much impossible to do since when you are brushing your teeth water and toothpaste is inevitably going to go down unless you keep your mouth shut closed completely while you are brushing your teeth. Other models have a rubberized button that overlays the button so this leakage doesn't happen.<br /><br />I have had to replace this brush twice, and unfortunately the second time my warranty period was up and Sonicare offered me a 20% discount. At $200+ retail you should be getting a product that is better constructed and functions well. I have then moved onto a competitors brand which doesn't look as nice but feels and brushes a lot better.
  744. It's great, it works, and it cleans! It cleans really well! What more do you want from a toothbrush? Five different cleaning modes? Oh, well, this has got it!<br /><br />You want to take it around? The travel kit is pretty awesome, too. Battery lasts ~3 weeks from one charge. Whoa! You can even charge it straight from the travel case! Wait, whaaat?<br /><br />The glass cup is cool, but I don't use it. There's a smaller, more compact stand, and it definitely looks better in the bathroom.<br /><br />Although, there is one thing that I had trouble with. It was when I put the toothpaste on the brush head! Whenever I would turn it on, it would go cray and start vibrating like a maniac. The toothpaste would then either fall off or fling off everywhere little by little. I got it now, though. Mastered it. BAM!
  745. Best toothbrush on the market.
  746. This the first review I have ever written! This toothbrush is fantastic! It lives up to the advertisement!
  747. My recommendation is that you do not purchase this product. The product offers a two year warranty. If the product fails after the warranty expires, the manufacturer of this product will do nothing to assist with repairs, or replacement. I find myself the unlucky owner of a $190 toothbrush that looks good, but can no longer be properly charged because the battery has quit working. The product has a nice look with the glass to be used for charging the product - but essentially the product design is flawed. The battery issue is a known issue with this particular product - but Philips will not acknowledge the problem after the two year warranty expires.
  748. This was an very good tooth brush...then it simply stopped working. Apparently there is a well documented issue wherein the shaft which vibrates the tooth brush head breaks.   749. Awesome Toothbrush, my mouth feels so much cleaner
  750. My wife and I each bought one of these and I loved mine for the first few months. It was the best toothbrush I have ever used in my life. It literally felt like going to the dentist after each brush. Unfortunately, after six months my wife's toothbrush stopped working and mine feels like it is fading. Her's will turn on and vibrate a little, but it doesn't clean teeth. We were very careful with them and used them normally. We are contacting Philips to see if they will send us new brushes, so we'll see. If they send us new ones we'll keep using them, but for a $200 we expected more. EDIT I just contacted Philips and they are sending two replacement handles after a fairly painless 10 minute online chat with a representative. I am changing my rating to 3 stars from 1 star due to their customer service. I would still hesitate to by this again though.
  751. Love it! Have it for almost 3 years now. It stoppped working twice, but the warranty is awesome, so it got replaced
  752. Feels like just home from the dentist after every brushing. It is GREAT!! Have had other sonicare toothbrushes but this is the best!
  753. Quite, great design, thought through travel case, easy charging, glass cradle, various charging options, light. The best toothbrush I've had. Well done!
  754. First off, let me say that I have never owned an electric toothbrush before this. I have always used regular/manual toothbrushes and figured that they work just as well. I thought that electric toothbrushes are only good because you get to be lazy - I was wrong. I bought this toothbrush about a month ago after a trip to the dentist and have absolutely fallen in love with it - although it does tickle the first few times because I wasn't used to the vibration sensation. But it leaves your teeth feeling amazingly clean (post-dentist clean even). My girlfriend had been telling me that its only because I just went to the dentist - so I bought some extra tips and let her use it. She now plans to buy herself one since she was so impressed by how clean her teeth feel. I will say that I keep a regular toothbrush around for those random days where I am too lazy, late, or inebriated to spend a full two minutes brushing my teeth. Then I settle for a normal and quick (but less perfect) toothbrushing. I noticed in one review that people were disappointed that it did not come with a UV disinfecting light as some other models do. My only response: really? I have never in my life UV disinfected a manual toothbrush, so why would I have to disinfect this - it dries just as quickly as a normal toothbrush... One odd thing about the travel case - it comes with a USB charger (as well as the USB adapter to plug into a normal outlet). But I have to ask: why is it a USB charger at all? I doubt that many people will be plugging this into their laptops while on the plane to recharge their toothbrush. I don't mind it, but I'm just slightly confused. The only minor annoyance is that you cannot change the 'setting' on the brush without turning it on - so you are forced to click through the different settings while it is vibrating. You either have to turn it on and have water/toothpaste to splash everywhere, or put it in your mouth and cycle through while trying to look in a mirror(not easy). But all in all - I would recommend this toothbrush to anyone and everyone I know who is in the market for a great (albeit expensive) toothbrush.
  755. nice sleek design, and improved over previous version because it doesn't allow water to enter and get trapped into the assembly.
  756. The brush head (actual brushing end) is much smaller then my older sonicare. I feel like the cleaning area is much smaller.. The carrying case is cool but you can fit the charger in it so you end up carrying around a lot of extra bulk stuff. I wish I would have gotten the lesser model.
  757. I agree with some of the reviews I read before I purchased this, but not with some others.<br /><br />This brush does not rip your gums apart. A Sonicare requires that you grip it loosely and don't press it against your gum line. Let the brush do the work. I've used Sonicare for years now, so this seems like a no-brainer to me. This one is no harsher than any I've used. And I've had bad gums.<br /><br />It's true that the selection of five different settings can be a little hard to use. You have to start it out in one setting and while brushing hit the button again until you get to the setting you want. You can see in the mirror if it's at the setting you want. I love the 'white' setting because it gives you an extra 30 seconds. The clean setting is the normal 2 minutes. I want to also try the gum care setting. You can visibly feeling the change when you select a new setting. It would be nice if you could select the setting you want before you turn it on. Minor problem, however.<br /><br />One reviewer didn't like drinking out of the glass because of 'sharp edges.' He felt they were from the ones made in China. Mine was made in China, and there's nothing wrong with the glass. It's great having a glass in the bathroom for that last minute drink of water before bed.<br /><br />I do love the travel case that plugs in. I used to have a travel Sonicare that needed batteries. I hauled around hybrid batteries and a charger. Now I don't need that. I used this for a week and it did not need charging. But I can imagine on a two-week trip, it will.<br /><br />I love the little heads! Love! They fit in my mouth so much better than the old Sonicare did. Easier to keep clean, too. The bigger heads used to gunk up fairly rapidly, making me take special steps to keep them clean.<br /><br />This was definitely the perfect purchase for me.
  758. I love this toothbrush. It seems I spend less time cleaning, but my teeth get 10 times more brushing coverage. I love that clean smooth feeling after brushing. I get that same great feeling as I do when I get a cleaning at the dentist. I am so impressed that I can brush twice a day for 2 months just on one charge. And all the settings it has is awesome. I have to admit, I only use 2 of the settings, clean and whitening, and haven't used the others, but who cares, these 2 settings are great. I love that each setting as it's own timer, so I always get the same amount of cleaning time, no more, no less. I really do enjoy brushing my teeth now. It's not a chore like it use to be. It did take a couple of days when I first used this to get use to it. It kind of tickled my gums, but I got use to it after a few days. Who knew I had ticklish gums. I have been using this for 5 months now and am still using the original brush head, I haven't had to change it yet. If you are not hard on it, and just use it gently while you brush, you can get a lot of mileage out of it. Because the brush heads are expensive. SO wait for them to go on sale before buying any replacements.
  759. After tens of thousands spent on fillings, re-fillings, around 15 root canals and crowns, several re-canals and re-caps, and a couple of extractions, my new dentist strongly suggested I switch from manual brushing to a Sonicare and gave me a $10 store coupon. He explained that I may think that I'm brushing my teeth for the requisite two minutes but I'm really doing it for significantly less time. He explained that this product has a two-minute timer and he added that, \\"How well you clean your teeth is more important than how often you brush them.\\"<br /><br />My initial thoughts: \\"What's in it for him from the manufacturer,\\" not because I didn't trust him otherwise, but because I bought an electric toothbrush 20 years ago; I won't mention the brand--but I will say that it had a hose to squirt water between my teeth and made a mess from water squirting and leaking all over the place. I stopped using it after a couple days and it became a crud-encrusted elephant taking over limited space on the bathroom counter-top.<br /><br />Well, I'm thrilled with my purchase. The most distinctive feature is that the brush makes a sound every thirty seconds to remind you to switch to another quadrant of your mouth. Looking back I was probably brushing for only 20 seconds.<br /><br />The manufacturer claims my gums will feel better after only a couple of weeks. I'll see if this is true when I go back in 3 weeks for a cleaning. So far, my teeth feel so slick and glassy, and my breath minty fresh, that two minutes is worth it. With root canals costing $1,400, crowns north of $2,000, and implants close to $4,000 ... this $185 might turn out to be a wonderful investment!
  760. Amazing product. Teeth and mouth feel incredibly clean after using this brush. Very cool magnetic charging base so, no charger to plug into the toothbrush to get messy/water damaged.

  762. I would have written this review 2 weeks after I received the toothbrush, it probably would be a 4 stars.   775. Typical high-quality Philips product. The angled tip was a little puzzling to me as to whether to have the tip pointing towards the gums or towards the tips of the teeth. The manual was ambiguous on this issue. I sent their tech support people an inquiry, and they said the tip should be pointed towards the gums with the flat side against the teeth.
  776. It's hard to drop the money on such an expensive toothbrush. Reading the reviews cinched it for us. Our teeth feel cleaner and they are really whiter! It is VERY powerful, so it did take some getting used to. The only fallback is the difficulty of the setting changes once it is turned on. It did lose it's charge in a week as opposed to 3 weeks as stated in the directions. This could be that 3 people in the house are using it. Nice sleek design.   777. This is my second Sonicare in 2 years and the second one that broke.<br /><br />My first Sonicare had a battery that died 13 months after I purchased it. It was out of warranty and the battery is not replaceable. So, I was out $150. But I really liked the way the Sonicare cleaned my teeth, so I bought a the DiamondClean because it had a Lithium Ion battery and Lithium Ion batteries don't have the &#34;memory&#34; problems of NiCad batteries (the first Sonicare had NiCad batteries).<br /><br />This unit lasted 11 months.<br /><br />The first issue is that the USB recharging case doesn't actually recharge the toothbrush. It simply doesn't work. On the other hand, the battery does last a week without a charge, so the inability to recharge on the road wasn't a huge issue.<br /><br />Then the motor got weaker. And weaker... to the point were it stopped working.<br /><br />So, I contacted Sonicare customer support and gave them all the model and serial number information I had. They refused to honor the warranty. They claimed they couldn't find the model and serial number (and I think there's a 0% possibility that Amazon sells gray market items).<br /><br />So, I'm out my second $150 to Sonicare.<br /><br />I bought a OralB toothbrush and it's working well, although a little louder than the Sonicare.
  778. I really liked this toothbrush but after two years it stopped charging. This toothbrush is not cheap and I would expect it to last longer than it did. I miss it but don't think its worth replacing at that price every two years. I also bought the electric flosser and that stopped charging after a year and a half. I would be very hesitant to buy Philips products again.
  779. Having owned a soniccare for over 10 years now I was super excited to &#34;upgrade&#34; to this one. Don't do it, they suck to put it nicely. Bought mine in 2012 and have had to have warranty replace it over 7 times!!! On the phone they tell me to not get handle wet, ugh it's a toothbrush? And then eventually they will say sorry your replacement only lasted 3 months but you no longer qualify for a warranty covered brush.   780. Lots of money but my wife loves it. I don't care what those TV Dentists say about the electric brushes, my Wife's a living example for them . Especially this one. She had an older model and when it broke I got this for her, and LO & BEHOLD, her dentist and his Dental Hygenist both commented on the difference in her teeth!! She had issues when younger but ever since Sonicare she has needed no surgery, just goes in & gets x-rays and cleanings. Been 20 years now.
  781. A friend told me how amazing his was and the level of clean. I have to say he was absolutely correct. I love it so much I later bought one for my girlfriend, and my my mother.
  782. I purchased this toothbrush a little over two weeks ago and so far I love it. I have never felt a clean feeling such as this one, besides a regular dental cleaning. What first caught my attention is the toothbrush design, modern and very nice to look at. The cleaning options light up when you hit the on button, or when you take it off the charger. I don't understand why some people find the design not very thought out being you now use one button and all. It's very simple, you put toothpaste on brush, put brush in mouth n hit the button. The option you used last will be the one that starts up. That's if you let the cycle run its full course. There should be no reason why you would turn the brush off before its time is up. Very pointless, its timed for a reason. If you wish to do another option you just click the button to the setting you desire. There was also complaints that it you take brush out of your mouth toothpaste platters everywhere. If you need to pause the brush say to rinse or what not, you just hit the button and it stops it until you resume again (I think 30 seconds max) Very easy. The travel case and the fact thst you can charge with USB is also a huge plus. Everything now a days is USB charger friendly and now this is a lovely edition to the modern world of electronics. I do say that $220 full price for this toothbrush is a bit ridiculous, but amazon price is a little more reasonable. All in all this toothbrush is pretty great and I say give it a try!
  783. I have used Phillips sonicare brooshes for a number of years but this particular one is the best. I have seen the difference within a week. Its been already 3 months and I strongly recommend it.
  784. After trying many different electric brushes from many brands I decided to buy this Sonicare.<br />The price is not very accesible but once you try it youll see quality.<br />When you open the box the first impression is how sleek and modern it is . The different accesories are also nice.<br />It comes with a kids or small head and a regular head, a glass for charging , metal plate charger ,travel case ,usb cable for charging and a stand for the brush.<br />The options for cleaning are just amazing, and the way the head of the brush is design is perfect. It reaches the back of the mollars, between the teeth and is super gentle with the gums.<br />The timer helps you focus in the way you brush.<br />Yo have to split your mouth in 4 ways and the brush it. Every 30 seconds it will vibrate to let you know that you have to move to the next part of your mouth.<br />In the different settings you can have more time or different brushing vibrations.<br />If you travel the case is simple , elegant and perfect.<br />Battery fully charged will last you for at least 3 weeks brushing 3 times a day.<br />Overall is a great product.   788. This was an upgrade for us from FlexCare. We bought our FlexCare back in Apr 2011 and decided to splurge and made an upgrade purchase for DiamondClean in Jun 2013. FlexCare still works like a charm. In fact, we still use it when one of us goes on business trip. So none of us is without the Sonicare. DiamondCare work as well as the FlexCare. But I gotta tell you, if you're about the look, then go ahead, make the splurge. Buy the DiamondCare, you won't regret it. The rubber exterior on our FlexCare has gradually peeling after 3 years of use. The DiamondClean on the other hand is made of plastic but good quality of plastic (feels like ceramic but it's not). It is clean and sleek. No rubber parts on the handle so no peeling. Easy to rinse off after brushing. If you are switching from FlexCare to DiamondClean, you will have to get used to the button because there is only 1 button in DiamondClean to control. The reason I've subtracted 1 star is today (Oct 10, 2014) the battery in my DiamondCare has just dropped dead. Thank goodness it is still under 24 months warranty. Philips has great customer service! I was told they will replace the unit immediately. All I have to is mail the defected one back in the pre-paid mailing label. I read from another review that if you registered online with Philips, they will extend an additional 6 months. I will be sure to register the replacement online just in case.

  801. So some background. I don't remember ever owning a manual toothbrush. My parents started going with electric back when brookstone and sharper image mainly carried them. My last brush was an oral b 8000 series (older model) and lasted me for about 5 years. Got to a point where the battery wouldn't keep a charge. So I started looking.<br /><br />I read the reports that say sonicares are better, I read the reports saying oral b brushes are better, and the reports that say any electric brush is better than manual. So I debated between getting another oral b or a sonicare. I looked at features and even add-ons. It is a bit ridiculous but ultimately the reason for purchase of this over the 5000 series oral b was the &#34;no touch&#34; charger and the hard-plastic travel case with usb charging capabilities. The oral b would have been cheaper, however the cases never seem to look good to me (never tried them to be honest), and the timer/pressure/teeth cleaning sensor would be a waste of money where I wouldn't even use it. I'd probably toss it as I have a clock on my nightstand, phone, watch, oven, microwave; I don't need a time or clock and have been using electric toothbrushes long enough to know when I am pushing to hard.<br /><br />So to the pros, cons, and important stuff. I wanted to give this a few weeks before I wrote the review so I had everything in order.<br /><br />Important stuff: This brush cleans teeth well. I used a manual brush for a couple of days (disassembled the oral b early without thinking) and my teeth felt &#34;fuzzy&#34;. The sonicare feels good. The brush handle is light in weight, grips well, and of course if you are new to electric brushes or have a tendency to push to hard, kind of hard for the brush head to move if it is jammed up against your teeth (head still vibrates but bristles don't) where as with my oral b I could near brush away my gums if it came to it.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-The base does not have to attach directly if you use the glass. Just put the brush in the glass and it starts charging. There is a little dip in the bottom of the glass so if you don't pay attention you might not get the brush in all the way, but the only time I had a problem was when I put some floss sticks and my tongue scrapper in it too.<br /><br />-The charging case works. Though Phillips boasts a 3 week charge I feel better safe than sorry. Some people have complained about putting wet heads in the case. A quick shake of the head should make it dry enough and if not you can use a tissue to squeeze the head for excess. After I used the case for a few days I did take a damp cloth and did a once over the case and left it open to dry, but that's it. I never understood the need for the UV cleaners so I don't see the issue not having one or even the bacteria growth in between brushing.<br /><br />-If you don't like the glass a little cover for the charger comes with it. The brush does stand up right in this base. I didn't notice much brushing &#34;crud&#34; accumulate, but just keep that in mind.<br /><br />-Handle is relatively light in weight. I went to a store to compare both the 5000 and this one and the 5000 seemed to weigh far to much for me to like.<br /><br />Cons<br />-It comes with two heads, one is the compact diamond brush and the other is the full size. I'm trying to wear down the compact brush so I can toss it because it just doesn't work for me. The head size is just too small.<br /><br />-There is no where to hide additional cable length. Luckily my brush is on the other side of the sink from the outlet, but if you had it near the outlet you would have this bundle of wire in the way. Unlike all other charging stations I've seen that have a cable wrap for management.<br /><br />-The inside of the case is molded plastic of some sort. So at the crease where it bends I feel that after a while (could be a very long time or short) that tears and eventually breakage of that crease could occur. A worry more than a con.<br /><br />-There is no place to put the usb cable or charger. In theory you can charge off of a computer and I'm assuming most usb chargers with mini plugs. Would have been nice to at least have a place to store the cable.<br /><br />-It might have been the age of my oral b, but after the quad timer was done it would stay on. I liked having a few extra seconds to swipe around my mouth just in case. This brush shuts off after the time for your setting. So I just had to go to a setting with more time on it.<br /><br />-The heads are slightly more expensive than oral b heads and don't have the range of options to use.<br /><br />A few thoughts on other reviews I have read<br />-Many people say you can't cycle through the settings you want without spraying everywhere. You can. Take the brush off the charger, cycle the power button till the setting you want comes up, and place the brush back in the charger. Brush turns off and in the handle it remembers the last setting, so now you can put toothpaste on the brush, water, and in the mouth without spraying. It's 5 more seconds of your time if you really feel you need to change settings.<br /><br />-Like in my con section this brush turns off after the time setting you set. If you don't like it change it. It seems after about a minute you can also press the button to shut it off, if you need to brush quickly for some reason.<br /><br />-Never owned a UV sanitizer, don't see the point of them, never had any problems at the dentist, never had mold in an electric brush head, handle or charging station (both whatever model before my 8000 and my 8000), and this doesn't come with one. So if that is a deal breaker for you, then this wont do.<br /><br />-Price point is high at about any given time being roughly $65 more than the oral b 5000. I do think Phillips was trying to make a trendy toothbrush. Ultimately at this point in time I'm okay with the extra cost because I am using the things that came with the brush. That is also why I gave it 4 stars out of 5. Do I feel the cost was worth it? Not entirely. Not yet convinced. However I picked it, I like it thus far, so I'm not complaining.on.<br /><br />-There is no place to put the usb cable or charger. In theory you can charge off of a computer and I'm assuming most usb chargers with mini plugs. Would have been nice to at least have a place to store the cable.<br /><br />-It might have been the age of my oral b, but after the quad timer was done it would stay on. I liked having a few extra seconds to swipe around my mouth just in case. This brush shuts off after the time for your setting. So I just had to go to a setting with more time on it.<br /><br />-The heads are slightly more expensive than oral b heads and don't have the range of options to use.<br /><br />A few thoughts on other reviews I have read<br />-Many people say you can't cycle through the settings you want without spraying everywhere. You can. Take the brush off the charger, cycle the power button till the setting you want comes up, and place the brush back in the charger. Brush turns off and in the handle it remembers the last setting, so now you can put toothpaste on the brush, water, and in the mouth without spraying. It's 5 more seconds of your time if you really feel you need to change settings.<br /><br />-Like in my con section this brush turns off after the time setting you set. If you don't like it change it. It seems after about a minute you can also press the button to shut it off, if you need to brush quickly for some reason.<br /><br />-Never owned a UV sanitizer, don't see the point of them, never had any problems at the dentist, never had mold in an electric brush head, handle or charging station (both whatever model before my 8000 and my 8000), and this doesn't come with one. So if that is a deal breaker for you, then this wont do.<br /><br />-Price point is high at about any given time being roughly $65 more than the oral b 5000. I do think Phillips was trying to make a trendy toothbrush. Ultimately at this point in time I'm okay with the extra cost because I am using the things that came with the brush. That is also why I gave it 4 stars out of 5. Do I feel the cost was worth it? Not entirely. Not yet convinced. However I picked it, I like it thus far, so I'm not complaining.
  802. I am a dental professional with more than 20 years experience. I have recommended sonicare brushes for many years and will continue to do so because they are powerful and clean well, however, I cannot recommend this brush based on my personal experience. First, I purchased the brush at a professional discount so I only paid $60 for this item. Here is why I do not like this brush:<br /><br />1. The brush head separates while using the toothbrush and I've seen this in other reviews. Anyone who paid $200.00 for a brush should expect a better quality. When I contacted sonicare they would not take back the brush because it was past 30 days, but could offer a 2 yr. warranty. I do not want a brush that does not work well so this would make no sense, They also advised I try a new brush head (additional expense) which I have done and it did not resolve the problem.<br /><br />2. The brush head itself wears too quickly. It starts to flare within a month and once a brush flares it needs to be replaced. Brush head replacements are expensive. It also does not access all areas of my teeth as well as their older brush head models.<br /><br />3. It does not clean my teeth as well as the older models. I have a problem with tartar build up on my lower front teeth and got my teeth cleaned every 3 months until I started using sonicare. I no longer had the buildup and even with 6 month cleanings there was no tartar build-up. With this sonicare I can see the build-up again and have to spend time scaling my teeth myself every few weeks.<br /><br />4. I do not see the need for all of the different speed choices and truly question the efficacy of this. Neither have I seen any journal articles comparing the different brushes which included this model.<br /><br />I will continue to use sonicare, however, I will throw this one out and purchase one of the older, less expensive models which for me last longer and do a better job cleaning.<br /><br />However, to be completely fairI need to also tell you that two co-workers bought theirs at the same time I bought mine and they like their brushes and are having no problem with them. I think it depends on the individual mouth, not all are easily accessible although I believe mine is. They may not build tartar as I do. If you do decide to try this brush I would brush 3 or more x/day for the first 30 days just to see how it is working for you and if it is holding up. If everything goes well great, if not, immediately (within the 30 days) contact sonicare and return<br /> it for a refund. Also, amazon offers warranties by square trade which I believe are very good, but then after spending this much for a toothbrush, do you really want to spend more to warranty a toothbrush?
  803. I am a huge Sonicare supporter- normally. But this toothbrush is terrible. From the beginning, I have felt that this toothbrush didn't clean as well as previous models; however, I second-guessed myself thinking &#34;how could this be? This should be the best toothbrush ever purchased with this price tag!&#34; Now, after owning it for six months, my toothbrush has a mind of its own. As if possessed by aliens, my toothbrush comes on in the middle of the night and scares me half to death. I get up to turn it off and it doesn't stay off. The other night, I had a dinner party in our smallish but adorable apartment. Good food, great company and...what's that sound? Oh, sorry, friends, that's just my toothbrush vibrating extremely loudly on the porcelain counter in the bathroom. Yikes! I mean really Sonicare? Last night, I was awoken from a peaceful slumber by the dang toothbrush vibrating by itself in the bathroom...again. I wrapped it in a towel and put it in the living room, as it would not turn off. Still kept going and I could still hear it as I tried to fall back asleep. I finally buried it under pillows on my couch and closed the door to the living room. Ah...peace. Now, I have a 2 children, people, I should not have to wake up extra times in the night by this toothbrush. Now today it is completely dead, no battery. Wonder why? Could it be because it was literally vibrating by itself the entire night, so much so that I had to wrap it in a towel and stuff it under 3 pillows in my living room in order to not hear it? Grrrrrr......!!!
  804. I have always loved Sonicare, read good reviews of this one and it was time to change my old one because after 4 years it stopped working, so I decided to go ahead and buy this one and couldn't be happier with it! even my dentist is amazed with how clean my teeth are!
  805. I can't review this product from the perspective of someone who has used other Sonicare (or other brands of sonic) toothbrushes, but as someone who has been using different incarnations of Oral B electric toothbrushes for years, I'll admit... I can't believe I held off buying one of these suckers for so long, and especially on the idea that it was \\"splurging\\" to do so. It's not splurging; for heaven's sake, it's a toothbrush, not a cosmetic gadget - how much time do -you- want to spend with your dentist?<br /><br />If you own a product like one of the Clarisonic brushes you already know how much cleaner you feel than when you wash your face without; if you don't, I can only tell you that the difference is worlds apart. The contrast I found between my old electric toothbrush and the Sonicare DiamondClean is the same - HUGE.<br /><br />As for the toothbrush's functions, I can tell you flossing isn't nearly such an arduous chore, as the toothbrush is simply that effective; the 'clean' setting does its job remarkably well... without my gums feeling like they've been given a once-over with a tiny cheese grater.<br /><br />The charging system is very simple and designed for convenience; it fits easily on my bathroom vanity (in a bathroom the size of a tiny walk-in closet, mind you), and the travel unit is great, despite the fact that I travel very little - I like the compact for storing pieces I want to keep out of the way, too.<br /><br />Also of note; for people with small mouths (like me): this compact head truly is compact! I had no problem using it, and I know I drive my dentist nuts with my juvenile-sized head, hah!<br /><br />All-in-all I heartily recommend this brush - I've had no problems with it, and the system in total has been great. Whether that remains to be the case... well, I'll update if it gives me cause.

  819. I never write reviews, but this is an amazing product and I feel compelled to share my thoughts. I've been using this for 3 months and my teeth have never felt so completely clean and smooth and my gums so healthy, with no bleeding at all, ever--and my gums sort of tingle for quite a while after brushing. I also love the convenience of the charging glass which is a really neat idea that works perfectly. You just put the toothbrush in the glass and the induction device at the bottom keeps it charged--its that simple! The vibrations of the brush mechanism are not hard to get used to or unpleasant, but it is important to brush for 2 full minutes--it beeps every 30 seconds so you can keep track of the time. I should add that I also use a water pic flosser before I brush which is not a full substitute for flossing but its amazing how much junk comes out when you use the water flosser. I've had ongoing gum issues for years but this method seems to have resolved them and my dentist concurs. There are several types of Sonicare brushes and this one is the most expensive, but this model is well worth the extra cost--you get a better brush mechanism and the very cool charging glass as well.

And of course it works really well. quieter than older models.<br /><br />Only cons: Form factor is kind of slippery, looks really cool, but need a good grip as apposed to the older models which had rubber handles. I wish it had an On/off button separate from mode selection. If you turn this on and after about a min press the main button it will turn off... which is good. But if you turn it on and turn it off after a few seconds it does not turn off but rather cycles through the various settings so you have to press the button 5 times to turn it off, which is annoying as I like to turn the brush on for a few seconds after rinsing it off to shake out excess water.

  830. Am I the only person who has had a terrible experience with the Sonic DiamondClean? I've owned it for a year and have been shocked to find it the worst toothbrush I've ever owned. It's even worse than manual brushing. I've been brushing my teeth for almost 50 years and this is the first brush I've ever used that actually leaves food between my teeth when I'm done. Only occasionally, mind you, but with every other toothbrush in my life, that has happened exactly NEVER.<br /><br />I was using a Crest SpinBrush for a decade prior to opting for the outrageously priced 'sonic' option. I purchased this product specifically because of reviews that said it was a better option for those who don't floss religiously. 'The power of a sonic toothbrush forces water between the teeth and under the gums, improving gum health for those who don't floss on a regular basis.' And that was me, so I thought it might be a good investment for my long-term dental health. My bad. Though it looks, sounds, and feels great, within one month I had my first experience of finding my teeth still dirty after brushing. WTF?? So I went online, and I wasn't the only one who had encountered this, apparently. I was following the instructions in the paperwork included with the brush, but I found something online that said also to tilt the tip of the brush toward the teeth slightly, if you encountered this, to enable the bristles to reach between teeth better. Hmmm. Never required this much instruction to clean my teeth before, but okay. And still... It's happened at least half a dozen times in the last year. Food in my teeth AFTER brushing with my $200 toothbrush. Kinda makes me think it's not super scouring my gums all those other times, either.<br /><br />And today it happened again, so I'm writing the DiamondClean off as a bad investment. I'm about to go play the market, though. I'm going to go invest in a SpinBrush.<br /><br />PS. I'm giving it two stars only because it was probably better than not brushing at all.
  831. I had the older model this brush is lighter l has a square shaped handle, and is easy to hold. the replacement brushes are very expensive, the only reason I bought this is that my old model stopped working.
  832. Philips Sonicare Electric Toothbrush does an excellent job of cleaning, whiting, gum massage and keeping the tartar build up nearly non existant. Like the options to hold the brush and the fact you can charge from the clear stand, glass, or in compact carrying case(which is awesome for travel). I would make the purchase again.

  843. I bought this toothbrush 5 months ago. Worked great at the beginning. It has a very powerful cleaning and gum massaging action. Problem is that the handle began pulsing recently and stopped working. Call Philips and they replace it, with several legitimate and relevant questions asked. Here's the catch----I am currently living overseas, after purchasing it in USA. I needed to have a USA ship address, and then arrange for shipping FEDEX from USA to my current residence. That, for a $220 unit, 5 months old. You would think an international company, Philips would be able to handle the exchange locally overseas. When I called the Netherlands, Philips, world headquarters, I was told to phone USA. In sum, friends of mine, who lived in U.K. and purchased three of the DiamondClean over the past few years have had similar problems, and threw out the broken units. I guess U.K. call centers are less user friendly than the USA. But, better quality at the get-go would eliminate this, on an expensive home appliance. I am told Braun products have leap frogged Philips in quality recently

I note this in particular, because this toothbrush is very expensive, and part of this extra cost is due to these unnecessary additions.<br />I just bough a set of two of the more basic Philips Sonicare (Philips Sonicare Elite Rechargeable Premium Edition Toothbrush) for $70 at Costco for my parents. Given the success of my checkups since then I have to agree with him.<br /><br />This is a very attractive toothbrush and works just as well or better than my old Sonicare. I only deducted one star for this, and I will let everyone know that I am re-purchasing this model (although in the black) this afternoon because 3 years is still a great run for something that gets dunked in water every morning and evening to clean, vibrates over 39k times/minute, for about 6 minutes per day, over about 985 days. I think that's pretty durable, overall, and certainly my mouth is healthier now than it was 3 years ago, with less stains than with the old sonicare.

  864. I think this is the best Sonicare product yet. Compared to the FlexCare, it has a slightly thicker diameter but is overall a bit more ergonomic. Some reviewers think the finish is too slippery. I disagree. It has a matt, eggshell-like finish and is easy to hold onto. Other reviewers have complained that they must cycle through the mode menu in order to turn off the device. Not true, as long as it runs for more than 5 seconds. Then, one press of the on/off and it stops. Because it has only one button and a relatively unbroken, uniform surface, it is easier to keep clean. As for the brush head, I find the DimondClean superior to the older ProResults syle. So, if you can manage the extra cost, my choice is the DiamondClean.

Several things that I like about this brush are that it is quiet and easy to hold. The brush head is small and easy to maneuver in tight places (I do not know why they make so many toothbrushes as big as push brooms!) We were going to a special needs dental clinic but then they lost their hygenist and my daughter's teeth cleaning had to be delayed for several months and as of yet is still not rescheduled. While this toothbrush may seem expensive to some, I am looking at it as an investment to effectively clean her teeth (in the absence of a regular professional cleaning) and hopefully prevent her needing expensive fillings and the accompanying pain and discomfort and risk of her needing to be sedated for a procedure. So far I am very impressed! After just a few days of brushing her teeth it looked like there was less buildup on her teeth. She does not like the vibration that occurs when the quadpacer pause occurs but we may get used to that in time.
  871. I've been using this toothbrush for about three weeks now. I switched from a manual toothbrush. It feels sturdy and solid in your hand. Even though it is plastic, it doesn't feel like cheap plastic at all.<br /><br />Of course, the most important thing is how it works. My dentist says my teeth and gums are noticeably better. She saw a big improvement. I didn't tell her until after her comments what toothbrush I was using. She wasn't at all surprised.<br /><br />It comes with a glass that I don't use that can be used for charging. I just use the supplied charging base. It uses induction charging, so you don't plug the brush into anything specifically. I think it's a magnetic field that charges the brush.<br /><br />I used it for almost three weeks, twice a day, off the first charge. It has a very nice travel case and combination charger. It's a very solid design all around.<br /><br />My teeth aren't pretty, but they're healthy and I want to keep them. I also want to minimize the amount of work my dentist has to do and I think it's going to work for that purpose. So this was a very good purchase.

  877. I just ordered my third Philips Sonicare DiamondClean toothbrush in the last 5 years and I have used two other Philips Sonicare toothbrush models before the DiamondClean line of products. I absolutely love using the brush, as it cleans my teeth so well and really does give you that &#34;just-after-the-dentist&#34; feeling. The handle, glass charging station, and travel case are elegant and sophisticated. This model offers an upgrade over older models in that it does not let any liquids (water, toothpaste, spit) into the handle or under the brush head attachment. A full charge can provide a few weeks of use, but the battery does begin to die more quickly the longer you use the brush (after 1 year). Also, a battery that is not fully or near-fully charged seems to provide weaker power to the brush head, so I prefer to charge mine at least once every week.<br /><br />The cons are that these handles are not made to last. As I stated, I am now on my third DiamondClean brush in 5 years. The top metal shaft that holds the brush head attachment and causes the brush to vibrate became loose over time on the first two handles that I have used. On the first handle, the entire metal shaft detached from the base and because it was 25 months old and outside of the 24-month warranty, Philips customer support refused to fix it or send me a new one. I purchased another one and after 11 months of use the metal shaft started to wiggle and the brush head barely vibrated or moved at all. This time, because I was inside the 24-month warranty period, Philips customer support sent me a new (it appears to be refurbished instead of actually new) handle, which was great, but makes me worry about its longevity.<br /><br />I still enjoy using the brush and it provides exceptional performance over manual toothbrushes, but I am disappointed that the handles do not last for very long in my experience.

After 24 hours was up I attempted to turn it on, but no luck...the light was flashing meaning it was still charging but wouldn't turn on. After 3 days of this I finally went to Phillips Sonicare's website and couldn't find help on my issue. They had a nice Chat feature so I contacted support, I believe on a Sunday even. After the usual rundown they said they'd send me a replacement....in a few weeks! I was livid, and told the rep that I didn't think it was fair to have one DOA, spend nearly $200 on a toothbrush and to wait 2 weeks. With this, he authorized a 2 day shipping and I had my product within 4 (Sunday to Wednesday). Moral of the story, it is possible to spend big money on a simple product and still have it DOA...if you do not get the answer you like, ask for a better answer. I was polite the whole time (absolute best way to deal with customer service reps) and finally got my issue resolved. Now I'm using my new product without issue and I love it.<br /><br />Highly Recommend

Either way Philips should know better/have a higher standard. For instance, I'm sure the defective unit I send them will be patched up & sent out to replace someone else's mis-functioning unit, only to stop working a short time thereafter. I also like the included charging base glass which I find very useful for those times I wake up at night to get a quick drink from the tap.<br /><br />All in all, based on the charging options alone I highly recommend this over the older FlexCare model.   936. I will start by saying that it my Sonicare DiamondClean electric toothbrush does seem to clean well. I had been using Oral B electric toothbrushes before getting this one. I switched because although my first Oral B took many years before the battery stopped recharging, the second one I bought only lasted less than 3 years, which made me want to switch. I had also heard that Sonicare did a better job at cleaning teeth. I chose the DiamondClean model based on Sonicare's website. It was the only one that said it cleaned plaque better than a manual toothbrush. I was surprised it was the only model that said that! I figured all of their electric toothbrushes ought to do that, but I digress.<br /><br />Ok, so this toothbrush has a great tendency to splatter/spray toothpaste out of my mouth to surrounding areas like my arm, hair, mirror, countertop, everywhere! It's very annoying and gross. I think I brush my teeth with it best while in the shower because I am not trying to be careful to make sure this doesn't happen, so I can focus on cleaning my teeth more. I'm constantly putting my hand over my mouth to try and block any potential spray, or trying to keep my mouth as closed as possible. But it is very hard to try to keep my mouth closed while brushing the back teeth, the front teeth or tongue. Every time I use it I end up spraying wet toothpaste somewhere around me, and it's very annoying. The different settings on the brush are all the same power level so none of them are better at preventing this than the others. The only difference on the settings is the time that I can tell. Also, you can't turn off the toothbrush on one click most of the time. Usually you have to go through all the settings to be able to get it to shut off because the shut off button is the same button for the settings. I've noticed through trial and error that if I have the brush pressed against my teeth enough that hitting the settings/on/off button will turn it off on the first try, but ifthe brush senses no pressure then you have to keep pressing the button about 4 times or so (advancing through every cleaning setting) before it shuts off, very annoying! If I had known all this I would not have asked for it as a Christmas present like I did.

  944. I had a Sonicare HealthyWhite model prior to purchasing the DiamondClean. I had this model for about four years, before it finally failed. My primary complaint with the old brush was where the brush head slid down onto the post getting moldy with the toothpaste buildup. To remedy this, I would remove the head at every charge cycle and use a q-tip to clean the inside and around the post on the toothbrush itself. After doing this for a few months, the shaft eventually broke, the the toothbrush head would just flex all over the place.<br /><br />With a coupon, sale and rebate from another vendor, off I went to buy a new Sonicare. I cannot imagine being without some form of Sonicare for the dentist clean teeth feeling everyday. I really liked the matte black model so that's what I picked up.<br /><br />Off to charge it for the first time. Gone is the white and blue charging stand, replaced by a cup. Nifty idea, but your toothbrush gets set down on the sink, where all kinds of other stuff live. So the cup is pretty much useless unless you wipe down the brush prior to charging. The cup system takes more space than the original base as well. The toothbrush also comes with a micro USB charging system, which went right into my travel bag, and it hasn't seen the light of day yet, even though I have traveled once. I ended up using a conventional toothbrush for the trip. It is a nice storage case with space for an extra head which does come with the brush.<br /><br />After letting the device charge, usability is much like any other Sonicare, multiple button pushes change the brushing mode. There is one model which I believe has a separate button for this task, and if you prefer to change options frequently, I highly suggest you opt for that model. Otherwise you need to cycle through the modes with the brush on. Do it without any toothpaste!<br /><br />Somewhere along the line, I read that this new model will hold a charge for two weeks. I brush with the Sonicare twice daily on the whitening cycle, and that gives me 8 days worth of brushing. This is a one day improvement over my old unit, which also had the same whitening cycle.<br /><br />Can you feel a difference with the Diamondclean head? Yes. A bit. Enough to upgrade? No. You can use the head on some other model brushes, and I believe they all advertise 31,000 strokes per minute or something like that.<br /><br />Time will tell if the head will break on this model as well due to the cleaning routine I utilize. With online registration, they do push the warranty to 2.5 years, which is pretty nice. The head does remove easier so I'm hopeful it will last longer.<br /><br />I certainly wouldn't replace a functioning Sonicare with this model. If you find the right sale, coupon and or rebate, it's a worthy model replacement option.the whitening cycle, and that gives me 8 days worth of brushing.   959. first came from a higher end oral-b electric toothbrush. I recently had oral surgery and beforehand had a special cleaning with a ultrasonic-esque pick. Afterwards my mouth felt more clean than it ever has even after prior dental cleanings and thus began my hunt for a brush that could come close to that feeling.<br /><br />One of my friends has been a longtime user of the diamond clean after receiving it as a gift and raved about it(not knowing it was the top model at the time). I purchased it that night and figured worst case scenario I can return it.<br /><br />Holy cow I have had it for a week and my teeth have never felt cleaner. I usually gate brushing my teeth because my teeth never really feel all that clean after. Now I find myself brushing 3 times a day. After a week I can already see a difference in how white my teeth are as can my friends and girlfriend. There is an introductory setting that can be turned off if you are familiar with electric toothbrushes or kept on if your aren't used to the \\"tickle\\" of the brush. There are multiple settings that change the length of brushing and based on the sound of the toothbrush, the frequency in which it moves. I prefer the whitening mode. I never thought of adjusting the mode mid brush. I tend to change to my desired mode before I stay brushing and just turn the brush off before applying tooth paste and thus eliminating the toothpaste all over the mirror. Why would you even consider putting toothpaste on an electric brush and turning it on when it isn't in your mouth anyway? Rookie mistake. Regardless, my parents used to rave about their top model oral b until one visit I picked up some standard sonicare brush heads to they could try my toothbrush. After using oral b for over 12 years they could not believe how much better their mouths felt after using the sonicare diamond so they decided to make the jump. I personally love the glass. I have a lot of counter space and the ability to just set it in the cup to chargeand not have to make sure is in the correct way is fantastic, besides, who doesn't like to rinse after they clean. During the summer I enjoy going camping. I just came back from my first tenting trip of the season and the charging case was fantastic. Even though I gave up electricity for a long weekend, I was able to keep my brush charged in the case so I could still have a clean mouth and still feel civilized.<br /><br />I look forward to trying some additional whitening strips as I now feel my brush can finally keep my teeth clean and white. I have not tried lower end sonicare models but I can tell you that this model won't disappoint.<br /><br />Just don't try to charge it on a metal surface as it won't charge. I won't go into the science regarding why but you have a better chance of keeping the water flowing from your faucet by blocking it with your finger.

  961. I absolutely loved this toothbrush for the last two years: my teeth were minty clean, no grimy buildup throughout the day (and even prevented it overnight); my breath was fresh for the rest of the day, and charges lasted for 2 weeks at a time so that was all great. However, this model is very poorly designed - the metal rod on which the toothbrush head is placed became loose and completely stripped the metal around it from the vibration. Toothbrush heads no longer stay, they pop right off as soon as I power on the toothbrush. I thought of trying to use some JB Weld or superglue gel to keep the metal rod in place but figured it would destroy the mechanics anyway, and could potentially damage my teeth. For almost $200, a freaking toothbrush shouldn't die so quickly from something preventable! Additionally, the cheapest I could find the toothbrush heads for was $19 for a two-pack on eBay; ridiculous!!! It's not a true dental instrument, but I'm hoping that it will help loosen plaque and whiten my teeth over time.<br /><br />In the short term, the Sonicare has made my daily routine relaxing and fun, making me more inclined to brush. The timer makes me brush thoroughly every time, breaking years of bad habits.<br /><br />I wish I'd purchased one of these years ago. Would have saved me a fortune in professional cleaning.
  978. I never thought I'd look forward to brushing my teeth, but WOW! They feeling and results simply can't be beat!
  979. I bought this to replace my older Sonicare. I like this, but I find it more difficult to grip than the flex+ and since there is only one button, sometimes instead of turning off it switches modes. It still does clean just as well.
  980. Received it right before Christmas!<br />Excellent Electric toothbrush!<br />Maybe it is a little expensive, but totally worth the money!<br />Absolutely love it!

  982. I have been using Sonicare tooth brushes since they first came out, this is my 4th.<br />I really like the carrying case although I'm not quite sold on the value of USB (a minor point though as you can still use a wall adapter).<br />I like the prop stand to support the brush upright.<br />I am not sure that the settings on the brush do anything other than extend the time of brushing. They could just list them as such.<br /><br />The brush is on par with my last brush, I like how sleek and clean the connection between the brush tip and the body of the brush is.<br />The glass to drop the brush in is just silly.<br />Would love to see a better power cord. These thick cords don't bend well which means it's gonna hang in my sink with the way my bathroom is designed.<br /><br />I do really like the brush and I agree that it's hard to improve on a product that was already so good.   983. The DiamondClean replaced my SonicCare e-series, which I wore out. The SonicCare was good, the DiamondClean is great!   987. Thrilled with this purchase. After much research online I decided this would be the best toothbrush for me and haven't been disappointed. Gives your teeth a really good clean although the battery doesn't last as long as claimed.
  988. i was hesitant to use an electric toothbrush, remembering the old one my dad used to use, so loud and messy (and ugly on the countertop), but after using the DiamondClean for about a month, I'm very happy with its results. its claims to whiten teeth after 1 week was true in my case (but i also cut out common staining consumables like teas and coffee). the DiamondClean has a mode to get you used to the ultrasonic vibrations, but i bypassed that. it did tickle one area at first, but after 2 days, i got used to it. there are five brushing modes, but i don't use all of them (only Clean and Gum Care). it has 2 brushing heads: 1 standard and 1 compact head. i rated it 4/5 stars only cuz even though i feel the brush head against the surfaces of my teeth and gum line, i still miss a few spots, but just in tiny crevices, so i think i'll be buying the sensitive brush heads since they're softer and can navigate around curves better IMO. overall, it really does leave my teeth smooth like having come from the dentist. highly recommended!
  989. love it the best toothbrush available
  990. This toothbrush is not worth the $200 retail price. My husband is finishing out dental school so got a special discount on two of these. I was thrilled because I was still using my old OralB from 8 years ago and was ready to try something new. This brush was great for about 1 year. Then the button got really hard to press - when running hot water over it brown gunk started coming out. I was disgusted, I am a freak and take the brush head off and rinse both pieces individually then dry them both after EVERY brushing. Then about 2 weeks later the brush started turning on by itself in the middle of the night, then it went dead and stopped working altogether. At the exact same time (about 1 year) my husbands just stopped working at all. We contacted customer service and although they are replacing the brushes, they were absolutely HORRIBLE to work with. Do NOT waste your money - if I could get a refund, I would buy a new OralB. I will never spend another cent on a Sonicare

  996. I read those reviews about the look & functionality of this model, and after 4 months using this I agree with most of those who said this is an &#34;apple&#34; type toothbrush. It's good-looking, and I like the weight it feels when I'm holding it. It's almost ceramic-feeling. And the charging method is also fancy enough for people who like pretty, modern design. As for it's functionality... It's been my first electronic toothbrush, and I have to admit that it's far much better than common plastic toothbrushes. My teeth have never feel so clean. I normally use the &#34;whitening&#34; mode which provide two more rounds in brushing. Not really bleaching your teeth, of course, but I do feel cleaner by brushing for slightly more time. I have been traveling for a month, and the recharger works just fine in different countries. All you need is an adaptor; or you can charge it on the computer. As a first-time user of Philip's Sonicare series, I'm happy with this toothbrush, but I'm not sure if I want to spend so much money again when I need to buy my next electronic toothbrush.
  997. One of my best friends ranted and raved over this brush. It was recommended to him by a close friend who works as a dental hygenist who was emphatic that this brush is a must. She recommends them to all her clients. I was a little hesitant because of the price. Our family is on a tight budget and I really didn't want to waste money on a product that wasn't truly worth it. However, since having a baby my gums felt horrible. I knew I had deep pockets and while pregnant I could barely tolerate keeping up with my normal regimen of cleaning. Post baby hasn't been much better as I have been absolutely sleep deprived. It had gotten to the point that certain areas were pretty painful to floss or water pik and I knew they must be getting really bad and felt just hopeless since I could barely tolerate trying to clean these areas.<br /><br />After two days I observed a noticeable decrease in pain! The first day I used the brush three times. I noticed one of the worst areas of my mouth was slightly inflammed but the next day it felt much better. Also, when I flossed, I had such a noticeable decrease of any plaque. I had no idea how poorly my manual brushing had done. I just thought that it was normal. The next day I used the brush five times, basically after eating each time, flossing and water piking as well. I just can't get over how dramatically the pain has decreased in my mouth after TWO DAYS.<br /><br />I feel very hopeful about at least stemming the tide of any damage my mouth has experienced, I have a dramatic decrease in pain after only two days. I love the sensation of this toothbrush as I clean, it is like having your mouth lovingly massaged. I will never go back to a manual toothbrush again. I actually look forward to brushing my mouth. My mouth feels so clean, soothed and refreshed that I find myself brushing after I eat to maintain that clean feeling. I only wish I had known this years ago because I would be a lot better off.<br /><br />Take it with a grain of salt, this is coming from someone who used a manual and I'm sure that's part of it. Are there cheaper electronic toothbrushes that work as well, perhaps. The design is very sleek and modern. Is that reason enough to invest this kind of money? That's up to you. I purchased this mainly because of how emphatic my friend's friend, a dental hygenist, was about the product.<br /><br />Like some other reviewers mentioned, I wish that you could shift modes before turning it on. I noticed now it seems to stay in the mode you left off at. It's not a horrible inconvenience, I can definitely live with it. Also having a way to code the heads for multiple users would be nice as well. I've just taken to using the compact head so that solves that for me.

  1014. UPDATE:<br /><br />I've now had seven of these toothbrushes trying to get one with a battery lasting anything close to the claimed life. Three of the seven came from Amazon, the other four came from Philips directly. The batery life I got from these seven brushes was typically 6 days. The life ranged from 5-10 days, but was usually 6 days--that's only 12 uses!--nowhere near the 21 days they boldly advertise. Combined with the other flaws I mentioned below and the price of this product, I now give it one star. $180 for a six-day battery in a slippery toothbrush is ridiculous.<br /><br />My last brush is going back to Philips. We'll see if they honor their \\"money back guarantee\\" or not. I can say their Customer Service was always friendly and willing to keep trying to solve the inherent design flaws of this product. Replacements did not always arrive quickly, but they were always friendly on the phone.<br /><br />**************************************<br /><br />It cleans well but there are design and production problems with this toothbrush.<br /><br />First, it is slippery. There are no rubber areas to help grip, and the shape is also not helpful for holding. Easy to have it slip.<br /><br />Switching modes using the power button is only good if you never witch modes. It you do want to switch, you need to push the power button to turn on the brush, count the number of pushed required to get to the mode you want and push that many times. Ridiculous. There should be two buttons like there are on the kids Sonicare--one for power, one for mode.<br /><br />My battery last eight days. Fortunately I reported it to Amazon within the 30 day period and so am getting a refund. If you get one, be sure to thoroughly check your right away!
