  1033. Let's deal with the elephant in the room first - this is a very expensive toothbrush. There are plenty of cheaper options (including other Sonicares) that will be just as effective in cleaning your teeth.<br /><br />So why did I rate this 5 stars?<br /><br />- Charging case. I used to travel extensively and still travel occasionally so minimizing what I need to carry when traveling is always a good thing. All I need to bring is an appropriate USB cable (I use only that is only 6\\" long instead of the supplied one). Just plug it into my laptop to avoid needing to carry the AC adapter. That might not sound like a big deal but I've had problems with old electric toothbrushes not lasting the whole trip and my work backpack already weighs nearly 30 lbs so any time I can carry less I'm all for it!<br /><br />- Charging cup. Charging stands waste space in small bathrooms. I need a cup in the bathroom anyway so it's quite convenient to have it pull double duty.<br /><br />Are those two features worth paying double for a basic Sonicare? For me they are. Your mileage may vary ;-)

  1053. I had to replace the last of my Ultrasonex II's, because they are no longer available and my wife has laid claim to our last spare once hers dies. The older battery/charging mechanism deteriorated to the point that the toothbrush no longer functioned at an acceptable level. While not a match for an Ultrasonex in working order, this Sonicare is a very good toothbrush --- probably the best of those now available. At the highest setting the brushing action is vigorous, just short of being unpleasant, and as a result it seems to be nearly as effective as the Ultrasonex in getting one's teeth clean. So, for that alone, four stars. It has a variety of lesser (selectable) cleaning cycles, but I don't use anything but the maximum. Minor aggravations include the tiny brush head, which is OK for cleaning around one's teeth but makes &#34;whole mouth&#34; brushing tedious. Also, the side to side vibration is vigorous, and one quickly learns to brush with one's lips together to keep from splattering toothpaste droplets all over the bathroom. That, I suppose, comes with the territory. On the bright side, the battery technology is modern, and with luck should last significantly longer before it deteriorates to the point of replacement.
  1054. My sister-in-law has the Sonicare and described it as giving your teeth \\"a whole other level of clean...,\\" so I decided to give it a try. I got the DiamondClean, since it seemed to be the latest-and-greatest. I got it while I was traveling on business and started using it on my trip. I must say, from the vert first use, my teeth felt much cleaner than with regular brushing or with any old-fashioned electric toothbrush I've tried. It took one or two brushings to get over the ticklish feeling, and to stop whacking my teeth with the brush, but it wasn't a hard adjustment at all. I also found the travel box to be very handy.<br /><br />I knew my teeth felt cleaner, and I thought they looked brighter, but thought perhaps it was my imagination; however, when I got home, my husband commented on how bright my smile was. I am not sure whether over the long term they will continue to get cleaner and whiter (I've only been using it for just under two weeks), but there was a noticeable difference in the first week. My husband had scoffed at the idea of buying the Sonicare. He hadn't used an electric toothbrush for decades, and thought they were not any better than brushing by hand. But, after noticing how clean my teeth were, he gave it a try and was also impressed.<br /><br />I don't know how the Sonicare will perform long term, but I'm very pleased with how it is working so far!

  1066. I absolutely LOVE this toothbrush! I've been using an electric toothbrush for many years, but never wanted to spend the extra money for one as sophisticated as the DiamondClean. After wanting it for several months I just couldn't stop thinking about it so I finally decided to take the plunge and figured if I was going to invest that much in a toothbrush then I was going to buy the very best one because my teeth are worth it and boy am I glad I did. My previous electronic toothbrushes don't even compare to this one and now I'm hooked and even the feeling afterward is different than any I've ever experienced. Not only do my teeth and gums feel super clean, but they feel healthy.<br /><br />I have only been using it for just under a month and haven't even tested all the settings, but I'm a Diet Coke drinker so I plan to start using the whitening setting this week. Another FABULOUS thing about this toothbrush is that it keeps a charge for 3 weeks which was like an answer to my prayers because I have 3 items on my bathroom sink (including my toothbrush) that have to stay plugged in so being able to eliminate an extra cord really made a difference in the neatness. Also, the noise with my previous toothbrush was very loud and if a family member was trying to talk to me while I was brushing my teeth the noise was so distracting that I couldn't even pay attention or could barely hear what they were saying so they had to wait until I finished. However, the DiamondClean is a completely different story because it's so quiet that I can hear conversations without any distraction.<br /><br />I also love the beeps that prompt you to move to another quadrant so I'm not constantly looking at the clock to see when 30 seconds are up. I also love all the charging options. The one for travel is awesome because I travel a bit then there are 2 options for charging at home and in all honesty I think the little glass idea is too cute! If you are in the market for a new toothbrush Ihighly recommend this one. I mean if you're going to spend over $100 for a brush you may as well purchase the best one for your money. Seriously this toothbrush has opened a whole new world of oral care for me and I will never go back. I'm just sorry I didn't do it much sooner!
  1067. Best Sonicare there is!
  1068. This is truly an amazing machine that removes plaque and leaves your teeth smooth and shining. You'll immediately notice the difference. It's worth it.
  1069. I owned a Flexcare system for 3 years and it started flaking out - power switch became erratic. But that had gotten a lot of use - 3 times a day at least. Before the Flexcare, I used the cheap models from the grocery store and those failed so quickly I could have paid for a Flexcare with what I spent on them - you get what you pay for in this case.<br /><br />This model is more aggressive / powerful than the Flexcare - I don't know how it compares to the Flexcare+. The brush seems stiffer too - I like it better for those reasons. But there are a few negatives as well - there's no rubber grip and the single power button / function button is not as handy as two buttons were. When turning it off, if too soon after turning it on, it will cycle through all the functions rather than turning off - which is sometimes what I want and sometimes not - seems like a form over function design decision. :(<br /><br />Pros:<br />- powerful<br />- brush seems stiff enough to work well<br />- charging setup with included &#34;cup&#34; is pretty slick<br />- carrying case with integrated USB charger - charge while in case - nice<br />- it looks nice - beautifully designed (even if slightly unhandy)<br /><br />Cons:<br />- no grip, which may look sleek, but makes it difficult to keep the thing from slipping through your hand while brushing - I may get some sort of grip tape for it.<br />- single button control for power and functions; makes quick on/off difficult as it will cycle through the settings rather than power off - not the best design<br />- no UV brush sterilizing system like the Flexcare has - I never used it that much, but liked having it integrated into the charger - now I have to keep the old charger setup as well since it still works.<br /><br />The grip issue and power button are why I didn't give this 5 stars - otherwise it is a very satisfying brush. Not sure if it is worth the price difference in the Flexcare+ since I have not tried one. Either is probably a great toothbrush and even the less expensive models are very good.<br /><br />BTW, it is essential to read the instructions and follow the usage guidelines for these Sonicare brushes to be effective. They don't work like a normal &#34;hand scrub&#34; toothbrush, but once you get used to it, they are so much better.

  1083. Sonicare was recommended by my dentist over manual brushing.<br /><br />You can go for a less expensive model if you want to use the Diamond Clean head replacements. (You don't need this DiamondClean model to use them). Some other compatible models: flexcare, healthywhite, and easyclean.<br /><br />This model basically has a &#34;coolness&#34; factor to it (Apple-ish), with the glass cup recharger and ceramic feeling handle (it's actually quality hard plastic). I consider it a splurge purchase.<br /><br />I would give this model 5-stars if not for the ironic flaw where one of the selling features, the ceramic-feeling handle, actually makes it hard to grip sometimes when brushing. I wouldn't mind some small rubber pieces of grip here and there but I guess they didn't want to ruin the aesthetics of it. I almost dropped it a couple of times when brushing.
  1084. This is personally my fourth Sonicare and is the 10th in my immediate family. This model won several design awards... It is just my opinion, but I suspect whoever bestowed those awards never actually used this brush. My first challenge is in the finish and lack of contours on the handle. When wet, the brush becomes very slippery and difficult to hold. Bear in mind I'm a middle aged man that works with hand tools all the time and has great hand/forearm strength. That said, if it's a challenge for me, anyone with grip strength challenges probably won't like this or it'll break after being dropped.<br /><br />My second issue with this brush is the elimination of the separate button for cycle selection. As others have previously mentioned, this is a big inconvenience and nuisance and tends to make quite a mess if you try to see what you are changing. There is a way to preset a favorite setting, but that is very easily erased and you're back to go.<br /><br />Others have also commented about the charging system. The travel case with a USB connection to charge is brilliant! The home charger base using a drinking glass - is &#34;Home & Garden&#34; beautiful but not very practical nor sanitary. Speaking of, my last two (top of the line when purchased) brushes both came with UV sanitizers but that &#34;option&#34; seems to be left to lesser brushes at this point.<br /><br />Short Story long, after using this brush almost two years, I'd recommend a step &#34;down&#34; to the &#34;Flexcare +&#34; model.

  1096. At approximately one foot away from the toothbrush, I measure 100 milli-gausse of AC EMF. This implies that were my gauss meter capable of measuring greater levels, closer distances would yield substantially higher measurements. As the product is only used 4 minutes per day, some users may feel comfortable with this toothbrush. However, I am returning.<br /><br />To make sure current users do not become overly worried by this post: The radiation from this type of appliance is extremely low frequency and is in no way comparable to radiation from nuclear power or x-rays. This low frequency radiation is non-ionizing. Studies do not reveal exactly what the effect, either positive or negative, of EMF radiation is on humans. However, it seems plausible that there may be some effect through a mechanism such as the interaction of the electro-magnetic force on the iron within cells.

So I have upgraded my rating from 1 star to 2, as I would rather that the product just continue to work rather than have to call support, but their support deserves 10 stars. As an FYI, if your sonic care seems to lose its vibrating power, try pressing and holding the on/off button while in the charger (plugged in of course) until it beeps.

My gums used to bleed almost every time I brushed. I heard that proper gum massage can really improve the issue, which is why I got this brush. It even has a special mode for gum care.
